item.title: Satir's Growth Model (Human Validation Process Movement)
item.description:
InterventionsCommunication StancesIndividual Client Phases of TreatmentUniversal Session TasksSession Template Based on Theory She began to observe that there were some universal unspoken rules that blocked the individual members from functioning at full capacity and also hindered the connections between members. These were: It is not okay to see what is going on in the family. It is not okay to feel what you feel. It is not okay to talk about what you see and feel. It is not okay to ask for what you want. It is not okay to take risks. She would observe the family members and their interaction and if she detected any of these rules in the family, she would help them break them by asking questions such as: "What do you see going on between your and your ?" "What are you aware of feeling at this moment?" "Can you tell your ___ what you are feeling?" "Can you ask your ___ for what you want?" "I invite you to use your courage and say what you see happening in your family." New Homeostasis takes hold. Involves trying out these learnings. Satir's most distinctive intervention Done either with the family or in a group setting Puts family members in physical positions that represent how the 'sculptor' sees each person's role in the family Bypassing Denial/Resistance: Sculpting is a highly effective nonverbal confrontation that bypasses cognitive defenses The family is currently in this process, and is leading to difficulties bringing them to therapy. Status QuoSatir's Growth Model Stages.png Family members put what they learn from therapy into practice.
Virginia Satir Eventually, the family system interprets the new information in a meaningful way; the therapist needs to be respectful of how the system uses the information and responds to therapist-client interactions, honoring and trusting the system's autonomy. Integration of New Possibilities The family's expression of the desire to change.
Virginia Satir
Experiential Family Therapy Foreign Element The therapist's introduction of novelty into the system.
Virginia Satir
Experiential Family Therapy Chaos "Making Contact" Facilitating Emotional Expression Help put difficult emotions into words Naming emotions Locating in body Metaphor Coaching clients in how to have congruent communication in session May involve the 'ingredients of an interaction' with specific coaching strategies Levels are likened to an iceberg Behavior is the only visible layer Other 5 layers unseen beneath the surface
The Iceberg Model: Used to help individuals understand their intrapsychic experience Used for couples to understand how the levels of each person's experience resonate with the other Behavior External manifestation of the person's inner world Coping
Defenses and survival stances (Placating (Placator); Blaming (Blamer); Super-Reasonable (Computer); Irrelevant (Distractor)) Feelings Present feelings that are strongly past based Using past events to interpret the present Perceptions Beliefs, attitudes, and values that inform one's sense of self Expectations Strong belief about how life should go, how people should behave, and how one should perform Yearnings Universal longings to be loved, accepted, validated, and confirmed Satir always assessed a person's level of self-esteem More useful to consider: Aspects of the self that a client values Aspects of which client are ashamed Research indicates that self-compassion, or acceptance of one's strengths and weaknesses, is a better indicator of happiness than self-esteem. As self-compassion and self-worth rise, people become more realistic and tolerant of their own and others' weaknesses Mind-Body Connection How emotional issues may manifest in the body, either symbolically or functionally Also assess the role of nutrition and exercise Example: If a person is feeling burdened, this emotional feeling may manifest symbolically as stooped shoulders. Satir maintained that the way the body is used indicates the person's communication stance
Congruent (Congruence) Communication: Open and relaxed body postures
Placating (Placator) Timid and reserved postures
Super-Reasonable (Computer): Cold and distant postures
Irrelevant (Distractor): Hyper and distracted Satir used touch in therapy to: Connect with clients Encourage and reassure clients when they were practicing new ways of communicating In today's environment: Touching less common because it can easily be misinterpreted as harassment Carefully consider trauma history, culture, gender, legal/ethical issues of using touch
Coaching clients to touch each other Iceberg Model.png
Raise awareness within and between people in hopes of increasing self-esteem and self-worth so that people feel freer to be authentic (Congruent (Congruence))
Identify communication stance Survival Stances
Utilize Self-Mandala to understand the 8 universal resources (spiritual, contextual, nutritional, interactional, sensual, emotional, intellectual, and physical) Facilitating emotional expression. Help put difficult emotions into words. Naming emotions Locating in body Metaphor
Use Ingredients of an Interaction to coach clients to have congruent communication. What do I hear and see? What meanings do I make of what I hear and see? What feelings do I have about the meanings I make? What feelings do I have about these feelings? What defenses do I use? What rules for commenting do I use? What is my response to the situation? Therapist's use of self. Being authentic in who they are Create a safe relationship in which clients can practice communicating congruently
Family Sculpting Put family members in physical positions that represent how the 'sculptor' sees each person's role in the family Touch Coach clients to touch each other.

The placator talks in an ingratiating way, trying to please, apologizing, and never disagreeing, no matter what. This is a 'yes man' who talks as though they could do nothing for themselves; they must always get someone's approval. They may experience feeling nauseous and wanting to vomit during conflict or disagreement. You may think of yourself as really worth nothing. You are lucky just to be allowed to eat. You owe everybody gratitude, and you really are responsible for everything that goes wrong. Naturally, you will agree with any criticism of you. You are grateful that anyone even talks to you, no matter what they say or how they say it. You would not think of asking anything for yourself. After all, who are you to ask? Besides, if you can just be good enough, it will come by itself. Think of yourself as being physically down on one knee, wobbling a bit, and putting out one hand in a begging fashion. Keep your head up so your neck will hurt, your eyes will strain, and in no time at all your head will ache. When you talk in this position, your voice Occurs when people discount themselves and privilege the other person and the context. Individual tends to apologize a lot, feels worthless, and may become depressed or suicidal. They tend to be quite sensitive and caring. Acknowledge Other/Context Minimizes self (sometimes context) People-pleasing tendencies Therapeutic Implications: Acknowledge own thoughts, feelings, needs Assertiveness/clear communication of needs Less directive therapy methods Multiple choice options to practice sense of agency Because placatory have people-pleasing tendencies, therapists use less directive therapy methods, such as multiple choice questions and open-ended reflections, to require them to voice their opinion and take a stand. Therapists should carefully avoid giving opinions, making it seem that they have an opinion, or offering too much personal information. Clients will use this type of information to know what parts of themselves to hide and what parts to foreground to gain therapist approval. Research indicates that some clients make up things to give the impression that therapy is progressing. Not until the placator regularly and openly disagrees with the therapist has rapport been established. Placating (Placator)
Satir likened the role of a family therapist to that of a gardener in that people are like seeds, they carry all the resources they need for growth if nurtured and protected from blocks to their growth. She believed that the key resource for each person was their Unique Spirit from which emanated other resources such as: self-awareness, self-acceptance, change, choice, compassion, curiosity, determination, hope, love, and wisdom. "The question for me was never whether (people) had spirits, but how I could contact them... It was as though I saw through to the inner core of each being, seeing through to the inner core of each being, seeing the shining light of the spirit trapped in a thick black cylinder of limitation and self-rejection. My effort was to enable the person to see what I saw; then, together, we could turn the dark cylinder into a large, lighted screen and build new possibilities." (Satir, 1988, p. 340-341) Unique Spirit Being authentically who they are is one of the most essential interventions in Satir's approach. Creates a safe relationship in which clients can practice communicating congruently. Whatever techniques the therapists uses, they are designed to help raise awareness within and between people in hopes of increasing self-esteem and self-worth so that people feel freer to be authentic. (Congruence) "Making Contact" Joining and building alliance Goal setting, what would the client like to get out of therapy? Clear presenting problem (presenting problem should be connected to goal, golden thread through all notes) Evaluating progress every session Joining and Alliance Bibliography: Satir, V. (1988). The New Peoplemaking. Type: Book Title: The New Peoplemaking Author: Satir, Virginia
Keywords: #In-Progress #Virginia-Satir To understand the world, we can study the family: issues such as power, intimacy, autonomy, trust, and communication skills are vital parts underlying how we live in the world. To change the world is to change the family. Family life is something like an iceberg: most people are aware of only about one-tenth of what is going on - the tenth that they can see and hear. Just as a sailor's fate depends on knowing that the bulk of the iceberg is under the water, so a family's fate depends on understanding the feelings and needs that lie beneath every family events. (What goes on under the table?) Over the years I have developed a picture of what human beings living humanly are like. They are people who understand, value, and develop their bodies, finding them beautiful and useful. They are real and honest to and about themselves and others; they are loving and kind to themselves and others. People living humanly are willing to take risks, to be creative, to manifest competence, and to change when the situation calls for it. They find ways to accommodate what is new and different, keeping that part of the old that is still useful and discarding what is not. The family is the context in which a person with such dimensions developers. And the adults in charge are the peoplemakers. Four aspects of family life: The feelings and ideas one has about oneself, which I call self-worth. The ways people use to work out meaning with one another, which I call communication. The rules people use for how they should feel and act, which eventually develop into what I call the family system. The way people relate to other people and institutions outside the family, which I call the link to society. In all the troubled families I noticed that: Self-wroth was low Communication was indirect, vague, and not really honest Rules were indirect, nonnegotiable, and everlasting The family's link to society was fearful, placating, and blaming In all nurturing families, I consistently see a different pattern: Self-worth is high Communication is direct, clear, specific, and honest Rules are flexible, human, appropriate, and subject to change The link to society is open and hopeful, and is based on choice The changes all rest on new learnings, new awareness, and a new consciousness. Everyone can achieve these. Families everywhere deal with the same issues. In all families... Every person communicates; the question is, How, and what happens as a result? Every person follows rules; the question is, What kind, and how well do they work for them? Every person is linked to society; the question is, In what way, and what are the results? Natural Family The man and woman who sired and conceived the child continue to care for that child until the child is grown One-Parent Family One parent leaves the family by death, divorce, or desertion, and all of the parenting is done by the remaining parent Blended Family Children are parented by step-, adoptive, foster, or gay parents Institutional Family Groups of adults rear groups of children, as in institutions, communes, or extended families The same forces will be at work in all families: Self-Worth Communication Rules Links to Society People are always doing the best they can. Developing a family is the hardest, most complicated job in the world. The very fact that you are reading this tells me that you care about yourself and the well-being of your family. Knowing something begins a change; experiencing makes it happen. If you feel shy or doubtful about inviting family members to participate in these exercises with you, become thoroughly familiar with what you are asking, feel it from your heart, and present your wish simply and directly. "Will you participate with me in an experiment that I think might be useful to use?" You maximize the opportunity for a positive response. Badgering, demanding, or nagging people to go along turns the transaction into a power struggle.
(I think this may be refer to the Battle for Structure and the Battle for Initiative) I see two kinds of pain: Pain of recognition of problems Pain of blame The first we can't avoid; the second we can. We can direct our effects to change what we can and to work out creative ways to live with what we can't change.
Serenity Prayer Grant me the serenity to accept the things I cannot change, courage to change the things I can, and wisdom to know the difference. Does it feel good to you to live in your family right now? Do you feel you are living with friends, people you like and trust, and who like and trust you? Is it fun and exciting to be a member of your family? Family that is more or less troubled does not mean you have a bad family. It only means that people aren't very happy and have not learned ways to love and value one another openly. Families can be placed somewhere along a scale from 'very nurturing' to 'very troubled' The atmosphere in a troubled family is easy to feel. I quickly sense discomfort. Sometimes it feels cold. Sometimes it feels as if everything were constantly spinning, like a top; I get dizzy and can't find my balance. Or it may be an atmosphere of foreboding, like the lull before a storm, when thunder may crash and lightning strike at any moment. Sometimes I feel very sad and cannot find an obvious reason. I realize that's because the sources are covered up. I begin to understand why so many members of troubled families were beset with physical ills. Their bodies were simply reacting humanly to a very inhuman atmosphere. Everybody has physical reactions to individuals around him or her. The first step of change is to recognize what is happening. There is little evidence of friendship among individual family members, little joy in one another. The family seems to stay together through duty, with people just trying to tolerate one another. More often humor is caustic, sarcastic, even cruel. The adults are so busy telling the child and each other what to do and what not to do that they never get to enjoy themselves as persons. In some families, people simply avoided one another. The family can be the place where one finds love and understanding and support, even when all else fails; where we can be refreshed and recharged to cope more effectively with the world outside. No one would intentionally pick this troubled way of living. Families accept it only because they know of no other way. A nurturing family is where I would be listened to and would be interested in listening to others; I would be considered and would wish to consider others. I could openly show my affection as well as my pain and disapproval. I would not be afraid to take risks because everyone in my family would realize that some mistakes are bound to come with my risk-taking - that my mistakes are a sign that I am growing. I would feel like a person in my own right - noticed, valued, loved, and clearly asked to notice, value, and love others. I would feel free to respond with humor and laughter when it fits. The houses in which these people live tend to have a lot of light and color. Clearly a place where people live, these homes are planned for their comfort and enjoyment, not as showplaces for the neighbors. When there is quiet, it is peaceful quiet, not the stillness of fear and caution. Each person seems to know that they will have the chance to be heard. If one's turn doesn't come now, it is only because there isn't time - not because one isn't loved. People seem comfortable about touching one another and showing their affection, regardless of age. People show their loving and caring by talking openly and listening with concern, being straight and real with one another, and simply being together. Members of a nurturing family feel free to tell each other how they feel. Anything can be talked about. Nurturing families can make plans. If something interferes with the plan, they can readily make adjustments, often with a sense of humor. This way they are able to handle more of life's problems without panicking. Thus the incident would be used as a learning opportunity (which raises the child's self-worth) rather than as a cause for punishment, which puts that self-worth into question. In the nurturing family it is easy to pick up the message that human life and human feelings are more important than anything else. These parents see themselves as empowering leaders, not as authoritative bosses. They see their job primarily as one of teaching their children how to be truly human in all situations. The behavior of these parents matches what they say. How different from the troubled parent who tells the children not to hurt each other, but slaps them whenever displeased. Parents are people; they learn that good leaders are careful of their timing: they watch for an opportunity to talk to their children when they can really be heard. When a child has misbehaved, the father or mother moves physically close to offer support. This helps the offending child overcome fear and guilt feelings and make the best of the teaching the parent is about to offer. We can help make new contacts with others and pave the way for better ways of dealing with each other. Parents in nurturing families know that their children are not intentionally bad. If someone behaves destructively, parents realize some misunderstanding has arisen or someone's self-esteem is dangerously low. They know people learn only when valuing themselves and feeling valued, so they don't respond to behavior in a way that will make people feel devalued. Even when it is possible to change behavior by shaming or punishing, the resulting scar is not easily or quickly healed. When a child must be corrected, nurturing parents rely on being clear: Asking for information, listening, touching, understanding, using careful timing, and being aware of the child's feelings and natural wishes to learn and to please. Children learn from the modeling of direct behavior. Parents in a nurturing family realize problems come along, simply because life offers them, and they will be alert to creative solutions as each new problem appears. Troubled families, on the other hand, put all their energies into the hopeless attempt to keep problems from happening; when they do happen - and, of course, they always do - these people have no resources left for solving the crisis. Nurturing parents realize change is inevitable. They accept change as part of being alive and try to use it creatively to make their families still more nurturing. The human heart is always seeking love. Troubled families make troubled people and thus contribute to the devaluing of self. Giving ourselves full permission to make the family a place to develop people who are more truly human will reflect itself in a safer and more humanly responsive world. We can make the family a real place for developing real people. Each of us is a discovery, and each of us makes a difference. Most of the things that caused families to be troubled are learned after birth. Since they are learned, they can be unlearned, and new things can be learned in their place. You need to recognize that your family sometimes is a troubled family. You need for forgive yourself for past mistakes and give yourself permission to change, knowing that things can be different. Make a decision to change things. Take some action to start the process of change. Whatever may have happened in the past represented the best you knew how to do at the time. Chances are that the causes of your family pain have been invisible to all of you.
Self-Esteem or Self-Worth is a concept, an attitude, a feeling, an image; and it is represented by behavior. When I was a little girl, I lived on a farm in Wisconsin. On our back porch was a huge black iron pot, which had lovely rounded sides and stood on three legs. My mother made her own soap, so for part of the year the pot was filled with soap. When threshing crews came through in the summer, we filled the pot with stew. At other times, my father used it to store manure for my mother's flower beds. We came to call it the "3-S pot." Anyone who wanted to use the pot faced two questions: What is the pot now full of, and how full is it? When people told me about themselves - whether they felt full, empty, dirty, or even 'cracked' - I thought of that old pot. Pot is a plain word in this use, almost a nonsense word. Families often find it easier to express themselves in pot terms and to understand when other people express themselves this way. When I say 'pot,' I mean self-worth or self-esteem. Every person has a feeling of worth, positive or negative. As with my old family pot, the questions are: Is my self-worth negative or positive at this point, and how much of it is there?
Self-Esteem or Self-Worth is the ability to value one's self and to treat oneself with dignity, love, and reality. Anyone who is loved is open to change. The crucial factor in what happens both inside people and between people is one's self-worth, one's pot. Integrity, honesty, responsibility, compassion, love, and competence - all flow easily from people whose self-esteem is high. We feel that we matter, that the world is a better place because we are here. We have faith in our own competence. We are able to ask others for help, yet we believe we can make our own decisions and are, in the end, our own best resources. Appreciating our own worth, we are ready to see and respect the worth of others. We radiate trust and hope. We don't have rules against anything we feel. We also know that we don't have to act on everything we feel. We can choose. Our intelligence directs our actions. We accept all of ourselves as human. Vital people feel high-pot most of the time. But vital people treat these temporary low-pot feelings as just what they are: a crisis of the moment. This crisis might well be the birth pains of some new possibility for us. We may feel uncomfortable at the time but do not have to hide. We know we can emerge from this crisis whole. When people feel they have little worth, they expect to be cheated, stepped on, and depreciated by others. This opens the way to becoming a victim. Expecting the worst, these people invite it and usually get it. To defend themselves, they hide behind a wall of distrust and sink into the terrible feeling of loneliness and isolation. Thus separated from other people, they become apathetic, indifferent toward themselves and those around them. It is hard for them to see, hear, or think clearly, and therefore they tend to step on and depreciate others. People who feel this way build huge psychological walls behind which they hide, and then defend themselves by denying they are doing this. Fear is a natural consequence of this distrust and isolation. Fear constricts and blinds us; it keeps us from risking new ways of solving our problems. Instead, we turn to still more self-defeating behavior. (Fear, incidentally, is always fear of some future thing) As soon as a person confronts or challenges whatever they are afraid of in the present, the fear vanishes. When persons with constant low-pot feelings experience defeat, they often label themselves as failures. After enough of these reactions, the self is vulnerable to drugs, alcohol, or others flights from coping. Feeling low is not the sameas low-pot. Low pot essentially means that when you experience undesireable feelings, you try to behave as though those feelings did not exist. It takes a lot of high self-worth to acknowledge your low feelings. Persons of high self-esteem can feel low. The difference is that people who are feeling low don't label themselves as worthless or pretend that their low feelings do not exist. Nor do they project their feeling on someone else. It makes a big difference whether one condemns one's self or sees this low time as a human condition with which one needs to cope. I shall be frequently calling your attention to this process of coping. Feeling low and not admitting it is a form of lying to yourself and others. Devaluing your feelings this way is a direct link to devaluing yourself, thus deepening the conditions of low pot. Much of what happens to us is the outcome of our attitude. Since it is attitude, we can change it. To build your self-worth: Relax for a moment now. Close your eyes and feel your condition now. How are you feeling about yourself? What has happened or is happening at the moment? How are you responding to what is happening? How are you feeling about how you are responding? If you are feeling tight, give yourself a message of love, physically relax yourself and consciously be in touch with your breathing. Now open your eyes. You will feel stronger as a result. We need a lot of practice to break the taboo against sharing our feelings. An infant coming into the world must rely on experiences with people and their messages about their worth as a person. For the first five or six years, the child's self-esteem is formed almost exclusively by the family. After the child starts school, other influences come into play; the family remains important. Every word, facial expression, gesture, or action on the part of a parent gives the child some message about self-worth. Tonight, when the family has settled around the table for dinner, notice what is happening to your feelings about yourself when other members speak to you. There will be some remarks to which you have no special response. However, you may be surprised to find that even "Pass the potatoes, please" can give you a feeling of or depreciation, depending on the speaker's tone of voice, facial expression, timing (did the message interrupt you, or ignore something you said?), and how good you are feeling about yourself. If you are feeling good about yourself, you may find that you have a lot of options for how you respond. If you are feeling low, however, you might find that your options are limited (see chapter 6 on communication). Halfway through dinner, change the perspective. Listen to what you are saying to others. Try to be in the other's shoes and imagine how you might feel if you were talked to as you are doing now. Would you, for instance, feel loved and valued? Tomorrow night explain this little game to the other members of the family and invite them to join you. It will be helpful to read this chapter aloud before you do this as a family. After dinner, talk together about what you discovered and how you felt. Feelings of worth can flourish only in an atmosphere in which individual differences are appreciated, love is shown openly, mistakes are used for learning, communication is open, rules are flexible, responsibility (matching promise with delivery) is modeled and honest is practiced - the kind of atmosphere found in a nurturing family. Children in troubled families often feel worthless, growing up as they must amid 'crooked' communication, inflexible rules, criticism of their differentness, punishment for their mistakes, and no experience in learning responsibility. Such children are highly at risk of developing destructive behavior toward themselves and/or others. Much of an individual's potential is held in abeyance when this happens. Parents with high self-esteem are more likely to create nurturing families, and low self-worth parents to produce troubled families. The system evolves out of the architects of the family: the parents. I do hold parents responsible for accepting the consequences of their actions and learning to do differently. This is a good first step to improving the whole family situation.
It is possible to raise anyone's Self-Esteem or Self-Worth, no matter what one's age or condition. Since the feeling of low worth has been learned, it can be unlearned, and something new learned in its place. The possibility for this learning lasts from birth to death, so it is never too late. "There is always hope that your life can change, because you can always learn new things."
My Declaration of Self-Esteem Our body language and activities reflect our thoughts and emotions. When we appreciate and love ourselves, our energy builds. When we use this energy positively and harmoniously to make a smoothly running system within each self, it creates a strong foundation from which that self can cope creatively, realistically, and compassionately with what life presents. "When I feel good about myself and life myself, the chances are excellent that I will be able to meet life from a position of dignity, honesty, strength, love, and reality." If a person's feeling toward themselves is one of depreciation, limitation, disgust, or any other negative attitude, the energy becomes diffused and fragmented. The self weakens, becoming a victim defeated by life: "If I do not like myself, I devalue and punish myself. I meet life from a position of fear and impotence, creating a state in which I feel victimized and act according. I punish myself and others blindly. I become interchangeably subservient and tyrannical. I hold others responsible for my actions." A person feels they do not count, feel a constant threat of rejection, and lacks the ability to look at themselves, others, and events in perspective. This is a state of low self-esteem. A person who does not value themselves will expect someone else to be responsible for bestowing that value. This often leads to endless manipulations that usually backfire on both parties. To avoid being against others, people have been taught to love others instead of themselves. This results in self-depreciation. The question also arises, if one does not love self, how can one know how to love others? We have plenty of evidence that loving oneself makes it possible to love others; self-worth and selfishness are not the same. I have found that the first step toward diminishing fear is to acknowledge it openly. Then check your perception: "Is that true?" Fear of Rejection Good human relations and appropriate and loving behavior stem from persons who have strong feelings of self-worth. Simply stated, persons who love and value themselves are able to love and value others and treat reality appropriately. Having a strong sense of self-worth is the way to become more fully human, to having health and happiness, gaining and maintaining satisfying relationships, and being appropriate, effective, and responsible. When one cares for oneself, one will not do anything to injure, degrade, humiliate, or otherwise destroy oneself or another, and will not hold others responsible for one's actions. People who care for themselves would not violate their relationships to others through violence. Those who do not love themselves can easily become instruments of hate and destruction by unscrupulous people. They essentially give away their power, which often leads to emotional slavery. Perpetual placating exemplifies this. The stronger one's self-worth, the easier it is to have and maintain the courage to change one's behavior. The more one values oneself, the less one demands from others. The less one demands from others, the more one can feel trust. The more one trusts oneself and others, the more one can love. The more one loves others, the less one fears them. The more one builds with them, the more one can know them. The more one knows another, the greater is one's bond and bridge with them. Self-worth behavior will thus help end the isolation and alienation between persons, groups, and nations today.
(MA: is this referencing Differentiation of Self?) Fact 1: Everyone has fingerprints and each set of fingerprints is unique, belonging to that person. I really am the only one exactly life me in this whole world. Therefore, I am guaranteed to be different from everyone in some ways
There are seemingly universal patterns in the way people communicate. Over and over again I observed four ways people had of handling the negative results of stress. These four patterns - which I call Placating (Placator), Blaming (Blamer), Super-Reasonable (Computer), and Irrelevant (Distractor) - occurred when one was reacting to stress and at the same time felt one's self-esteem was diminished——that "the pot got hooked." In addition, the "hooked" one could not say so. @satirNewPeoplemaking1988 July 9 th, 2024 Comfortability with: Universal Tasks: 8 Theory: 5 Client will increase self-worth and self-esteem as evidenced by self-report Increase positive communication as evidenced by clients being able to Interventions should be theory based Objectives theory based Based on the notion that people have many faces (or aspects of self), a parts party helps people to accept that they also have many possibilities. Some of our parts may be lying dormant, and when we access them, we increase our resources. The parts party helps people to acknolwedge, accept, transform, and integrate their parts. Other participants play the role of the various parts to help the person move from internal processes to more interpersonal processes. Parts Party This has to do with your spiritual connection. This represents your relationship to your life force. How do you regard your life? Do you honor it? Do you use your spiritual connection in your daily life? This has to do with your context. This refers to the sights and sounds, the feel of things, the temperature, the light, the color, the quality of air, and the space where you live and work. Each of these factors has an important effect on your life. This has to do with nutrition. What kind of food and drink do you put into your body? Diagnostic Assessment This shows how you interact with the people in your world. Your interaction shapes the nature of your relationships. How do you evaluate the quality of your various relationships? How do you use your power? Do you give it away and become a victim? Do you use it to become a dictator? Do you use it to develop harmony within yourself and with others, thus becoming an empowering leader? Do you use your power to nurture yourself or others, or to threaten? Do you team up with family members of others to do things together? Do you have fun, make jokes, and generally use good humor to make your life and that of others lighter and happier? Remember that humor and love are two very powerful healing forces. Initial Phase Walk the client through the ingredients of an interaction: What do I hear and see? What meanings do I make of what I hear and see? What feelings do I have about the meanings I make? What feelings do I have about these feelings? What defenses do I use? What rules for commenting do I use? What is my response to the situation? The individual is at the center, and surrounding them are the eight universal human resources: spiritual, contextual, nutritional, interactional, sensual, emotional, intellectual, and physical. Each part is interconnected. The less these 8 areas are given energy and time, the lower a person's self-esteem. This is the cohnitive part of your brain. This lens tells you about the information you take in, the thoughts you have, and the meaning you give them. From this cognitive and rational part, you can get answers to such questions as, "What do I understand? How do I learn new things? How do I analyze situations and solve problems?" This is the physical body with all its parts and systems. Find a good anatomy book in which you can see pictures of your bones, muscles, internal organs, together with all the different systems. Let yourself be awed and amazed at how wonderfully your body is engineered and what a treasure house of resources it contains. Apply this information to your own body. Are you, its owner, meeting its needs? Are you listening to it? It will tell you when you are tired, hungry, or over-stressed, or alert you to any part of you that needs special care. This is that of your emotions, your feelings. How free are you to recognize and acknowledge them? What restrictions do you put on your feelings? How do you express them? All feelings are human. They bring texture, color, and sensitivity to life. Without feelings, we would be robots.
Your feelings about these feelings show you where your self-worth is in relation to your feelings. Satir's Self-Mandala Diagram.pngFive Communication Stances.png
Virginia Satir (1916-1988)
In the late 1950 s, she joined Don Jackson, Jay Haley, and others in developing the Mental Research Institute (MRI). Satir wrote one of the first books about family therapy, Conjoint Family Therapy, in which she provided transcripts of how she worked. Every person has resources available to them, but when troubled, they do not usually utilize these resources to their utmost abilities.
Self-Mandala: The individual is at the center, and surrounding them are the eight universal human resources: spiritual, contextual, nutritional, interactional, sensual, emotional, intellectual, and physical.
Each part is interconnected. The less these 8 areas are given energy and time, the lower a person's self-esteem.
When people experience low self-esteem, they attempt to cope by using Survival Stances. These stances help people temporarily deal with presumed threats and protect their self-worth. The stances help to protect us, but do not help us or other people to grow and thrive. The four survival stances are:
Placating (Placator): Occurs when people discount themselves and privilege the other person and the context. Individual tends to apologize a lot, feels worthless, and may become depressed or suicidal. They tend to be quite sensitive and caring. The placating stance discounts self and privileges the other person and the context.
Blaming (Blamer): Privileges self and context while discounting the other. To cope with low self-esteem, the person attacks another individual. On the outside the individual seems assertive, but on the inside feel isolated and alone. Their experience leads them to sometimes feel paranoid and even potentially homicidal.
Super-Reasonable (Computer): Privileges the context and discounts the self and others. Focuses on the rules rather than on emotions and relationships. Very data driven and people appreciate them for their intellect. To offset their internal vulnerability, the super-reasonable person doesn't allow themselves to connect with any emotions. This can lead to a rigidness that may be displayed via obsessive-compulsive behaviors.
Irrelevant (Distractor): Discounts self, other, and context. Engage in distraction to avoid having to deal with their low self-esteem. People may describe them as fun and spontaneous. However, you cannot have a serious or straightforward conversation with them. This leads to a psychological orientation of confusion and possible psychosis.
The goal of Satir's therapy is to help people enhance their own and others' self-esteem. When we do so, we function from a Congruent (Congruence) communication stance. This is the healthiest position we can operate from. The Satir Growth Model is a strength-based approach, focusing on the existing resources that family members bring with them. Faulty coping strategies maintain problematic interactions. Therapy provides a safe space for people to choose alternative ways of coping. Therapy increases people's self-esteem, leading them to be able to lean into their uniqueness and provide a space for their loved ones to feel comfortable in their own uniqueness as well. Whatever techniques the therapists uses, they are designed to help raise awareness within and between people in hopes of increasing self-esteem and self-worth so that people feel freer to be authentic. (Congruence) Self-Esteem Maintenance Kit: Detective Hat: Used when there is something new that the person wants to understand better. It helped them shift away from judging an experience to exploring it. Medallion: Two-sided and says 'yes' on one side and 'no' on the other. It is intended to help the person recognize that they can say either word, depending on what they truly want, so they can maintain their integrity. Wand (Empowering wand, courage stick, wishing wand): Helps people move from inaction based on fear to action based on desire. Golden Key: Opens any door - helping the person ask questions they might not have previously, so the unsayable, and do the undoable. Wisdom Box: Helps connect the person to the wider world and all that has come before them.
Experiential therapists are interactive in the therapy room. They try to use their whole self for contact. This includes adopting an I-Thou Perspective, where they try to promote human-to-human interaction. Since one of the main goals of therapy is to help the client become more congruent, it is important for the therapist to engage the client congruently. The therapist must be a real person who helps model a way of being for the client. Experiential therapists conceptualize a few main processes: Status Quo: The family is currently in this process, and is leading to difficulties bringing them to therapy. Foreign Element: The family's expression of the desire to change. Chaos: The therapist's introduction of novelty into the system. Integration: Family members put what they learn from therapy into practice. Practice: Involves trying out these learnings. New Status Quo: - New homeostasis takes hold.
The therapist raises the intensity of interactions so that people encounter their own experiences and can thus become more authentic. Therapy then helps people to allow others to be more authentic.
Sculpting: Sculpting helps people get in touch with their inner experience and express this experience to others in a way that bypasses the typical spoken word. Sculpting can be done in one of two primary ways: The client is asked to sculpt their family based on their experience of what it is like to be part of this family now. Then the therapist can sculpt the family based on their own inner picture of the family's experience. Family members are asked to place other people in physical poses spatially located around the room and then to position themselves somewhere within. This provides the family with a new way of engaging with self and other. This allows for new meanings to come forth, where people can become more authentically themselves. The therapist will begin with one member of the family. The choice of person will depend on the family organization, the presenting problem, and the therapeutic process. Once that person has presented their image of the family, the therapist acts as a guide for each family member, bringing forth their perceptions of this picture and what it represents about the various relationships in the family. Therapist then shifts to another family member to explore their experience, as every family member unique has their own way of seeing and being in the family. Therapist may also end the sculpt by having family members sculpt their desired picture of the family. This sculpt shifts the energy in the room from a focus on past problems and dysfunction to a future functional and supportive arrangement of relationships. Satir viewed people as housing energy and as able to transfer this energy through physical connections with one another.
Family Reconstruction: Designed to help an individual connect better to the historical and psychological interconnections of their family. By seeing self and family of origin with a new perspective, the individual might then feel more freedom to engage in new possibilities for the future.
Star: The person whose relationship with the family is being explored and worked on.
The therapist prepares the reconstruction by talking with the star about their family history. This involves developing a Family Map, or the primary family that can include the grandparents, a Family Life Chronology, highlighting three generations of the star's family, including important dates and historical events (similar to the genogram), and the Wheel of Influence, a chart including all the people who influenced the star when they were growing up. The therapist ('guide') begins the family reconstruction by telling the star's story; then sculpts the family of origin, the star's parents' families of origin, and the star's parents' relationship; and then resculpts the star's family of origin. The overall goal is to increase the star's self-esteem so they are empowered to engage with themselves and others in new and more productive ways. This should engender more hope in them for their future.
Parts Party: Based on the notion that people have many faces (or aspects of self), a parts party helps people to accept that they also have many possibilities. Some of our parts may be lying dormant, and when we access them, we increase our resources. The parts party helps people to acknolwedge, accept, transform, and integrate their parts. Other participants play the role of the various parts to help the person move from internal processes to more interpersonal processes. "The Growth Model," where the focus was on helping people access their inner resources as opposed to, "The Medical Model," where the emphasis was on pathology and symptom reduction.
Satir likened the role of a family therapist to that of a gardener in that people are like seeds, they carry all the resources they need for growth if nurtured and protected from blocks to their growth. She believed that the key resource for each person was their Unique Spirit from which emanated other resources such as: self-awareness, self-acceptance, change, choice, compassion, curiosity, determination, hope, love, and wisdom. "The question for me was never whether (people) had spirits, but how I could contact them... It was as though I saw through to the inner core of each being, seeing through to the inner core of each being, seeing the shining light of the spirit trapped in a thick black cylinder of limitation and self-rejection. My effort was to enable the person to see what I saw; then, together, we could turn the dark cylinder into a large, lighted screen and build new possibilities." (Satir, 1988, p. 340-341) Her goals for family therapy included helping the individual members increase their sense of worth and value by accessing their inner resources and by decreasing any emotional blocks. And for the family as a whole, she saw the goal as being to increase congruent communication and heart connections. She began to observe that there were some universal unspoken rules that blocked the individual members from functioning at full capacity and also hindered the connections between members. These were: It is not okay to see what is going on in the family. It is not okay to feel what you feel. It is not okay to talk about what you see and feel. It is not okay to ask for what you want. It is not okay to take risks. She would observe the family members and their interaction and if she detected any of these rules in the family, she would help them break them by asking questions such as: "What do you see going on between your and your ?" "What are you aware of feeling at this moment?" "Can you tell your ___ what you are feeling?" "Can you ask your ___ for what you want?" "I invite you to use your courage and say what you see happening in your family."
She also helped them to make better connections with each other by decreasing their defensiveness. Satir identified the primary defensive stances as Blaming (Blamer), Placating (Placator), Distracting, and being Super-Reasonable (Computer). Forms of Fight:
Blaming (Blamer) (This is all your fault.)
Generalizing (You always think you are right.)
Labeling (You are so stupid.)
Threatening (You better shape up or else.) Physically Attacking the Other. Forms of Flight:
Placating (Placator) (Do what you wish, my needs don't matter.)
Being Super-Reasonable (Computer) (I don't care what you feel, just give me the facts.) Emotionally Withdrawing (Physically present but not emotionally present.) Physically Withdrawing (Leaving the room or hanging up on someone.) Cutting-Off (Refusing to talk to the other for days or longer.) Within a family system, these defenses can be played out in interactional patterns such as: Blame - Blame Blame - Withdraw Placate - Placate Blame - Placate Blame - Distract Withdraw - Withdraw Satir developed a process for helping people change and become more connected. Her process is described as having six phases: Phase 1 - Making Contact Satir would reach out using her body position, eye contact, and facial expression to make contact with each member. She would also consciously work to connect from her spirit to theirs. Phase 2 - Validating Satir worked to help people feel validated in many ways such as reflecting their feelings, affirming their values and highlighting their inner resources. Examples include: "You feel scared because your son got suspended from school." "You value education." "You are courageous to seek help." Phase 3 - Facilitating Awareness Satir had many different ways that she would attempt to bring awareness to a family about their defensive patterns in a non-blaming way.
Sculpting: Satir placed the members in body positions to give them a picture of their defensive behavior. For the blaming stance, she would position the person leaning toward another and pointing at them and for the placating stance, she would position the person down on one knee with their head down and their hand up in a pleading position. Satir would also bring awareness to members by exploring their inner experiences. She used the metaphor of an iceberg to help the family therapist to conceptualize the inner level so experience driving defensive behaviors. Above the water line were the inner levels of experience such as feelings, perceptions, expectations, beliefs, and yearnings. (What meaning are you giving to what your ___ said that is causing you to feel hurt? Is that a familiar place for you to go to when someone is disappointed in you? What is it you yearn for?) Phase 4 - Promoting Acceptance One of the ways that satir promoted acceptance was through 'normalizing,' that is, reassuring the family member that what they were experiencing was normal. ("It is normal to...") Another way that she promoted acceptance was by 'bridging' between conflicting parties. ("I am hearing that is is not easy for _, I would be interested to know how life was for you when you were their age?") Phase 5 - Eliciting Positive Choices and Changes Once Satir observed that the family members were aware of and accepting of their unhelpful patterns, she would lead them into seeing new possibilities for their interactions. After sculpting the family, she would ask them to each to stand in a balanced way and look at each other. She would then guide them in a dialogue helping them to express themselves in non-defensives ways. Other times she would simply have them sit face to face and she would guide the dialogue between them. "What happens for you when your says you choose over your ? You feel... Did you know that your felt __? What happened for you when you heard them express their feelings? You long to be more connected with them. You miss them. How do you feel to hear how much they miss you?" Phase 6 - Reinforcing Change Satir would often combine verbal responses with some supportive touch to reinforce a positive shift. The therapist also needs to work on their own personal growth. This is true for working with individuals but it is even more true when working with families as the chances of being triggered by your own family experience are even greater. As Satir used to say, "You are the most important instrument in the room!" Under threat and reward, change is painful: change is viewed as unnatural, the unknown is feared, the status quo is maintained, life's natural 'flow' is blocked, and the familiar is valued despite discomfort. The seed model has people viewing change more positively; as naturally occurring at a variety of levels (from cellular to cosmic) and as scary, but offering new opportunities. Discomfort is seen as a signal for change. Therapists using the seed model keep in mind that families entering therapy are problem-focused and will maintain the status quo as a necessary survival behavior. Therapist should make contact with each person to communicate a climate of acceptance (e.g., people do the best they can) and hear them out to discover 'what is.' Understanding the status quo stage is essential to clarify how the change process gets started or is blocked. This stage is explored further by examining resistance and readiness concepts in detail. The coin of change has resistance and readiness as its head and tail sides. Experientially, we may want to change in one moment and fear or sabotage it in the next. Then status quo is considered a trance, accounting for change resistance as well as a medium in which change may be fostered. Changing circumstances elicit shifts in perception, which in turn stimulate changes in thinking, feeling, and acting. But when circumstances shift back, behavior also reverts. Perception can appear to create change of behavior when the meaning of an event is reframed, but the underlying pattern is not altered. Altering the underlying pattern requires dealing with resistance to change. Resistance is a coping behavior intended to preserve the organism rather than obstruct change. Reframing resistance in terms of its positive intention. The way we are socialized has us, "Gradually acquiring a variety of commitments which constrain the person into following a consistent pattern of behavior." The effect is to develop a lifestyle that stabilizes the events in our lives, our interdependence of meaning of these events, and the way we define ourselves, as well as predisposing us to seek consistent situations. Experientially, change involves invoking the unfamiliar. Intellectualizing, avoiding feelings, compulsive activity, impatience about change, and dwelling in the past are all ways of dealing with the confusion by maintaining the status quo. The tasks at this stage are to cope with the threat to past security and sense of competence and self-esteem; deal with feelings of loss and longing for the past. Conservative impulse, the will to change has to overcome an impulse to restore the past, to resist the change. Survival depends on this impulse. By stabilizing perceptions, the conservative impulse enhances the ability to learn from experience. Only when it does not fit this construct is its 'newness' experienced.
Readiness refers to what Satir considered the unstable balance of elements in the Status Quo. Persons considering change are more open to consciousness-raising interventions, more aware of themselves, more conscious of their psychic distress, and more likely to seek out information about their problem. Variation in readiness for change (even in one person) depends on social circumstances, timing, opportunity, location, change goal, the degree of social pressure or support for the goal, alternations in environments circumstances, developmental crises, and physical or emotional pain. Four patterns emerge reflecting the relative influence of these readiness factors. These patters are based on the degree of difficulty involved in making the change and the degree of responsibility the person is wiling to take for making the change.
Preemptive Change: This pattern describes 'overnight' change. The inordinate strength of the motivating influences lowers the degree of difficulty in making the change. The degree of responsibility for the change is also low. The change in circumstances preempts issues of loss (leaving family and friends), self-efficacy ("Can I do it?"), and self-esteem ("Am I worth the effort?") that are ordinarily addressed in making changes. Problems maintaining the change may require attention at a later point in the change process. Change literally 'happens' to us in this pattern, but we have little sense of ownership of it.
Self-Managed Change: In this pattern, the influences motivating the change are less extreme or immediate than those noted in the preemptive patter. The person is influenced to take a conscious and self-responsible approach to change and is required to deal with one or more of the issues of loss, self-efficacy, and self-esteem in order to resolve the resistance to change.
Satir Family Therapy - YouTube Experiential family therapies include four approaches:
Satir's Growth Model (Human Validation Process Movement)
Symbolic-Experiential Family Therapy
Emotionally Focused Therapy (EFT)
Internal Family Systems Model Targeting emotional transactions Warmth, empathy, and the therapist's use of self Individual and family focus Five Communication Stances:
Congruent (Congruence) Able to acknowledge what you are thinking and feeling, what the other person may be thinking or feeling
Placating (Placator) Ignore their own thoughts and feelings and focus on the thoughts and feelings of others. Quick to put aside their own emotions for the sake of others. They often are so quick to deny their own feelings. Your job as a therapist is to help them learn to acknowledge their own thoughts and feelings but also the thoughts and feelings of others. They do not want to increase tension when needs are not met and risk having tension in the relationship. Minimizes self People-pleasing tendencies Needs less directive therapy methods
Blamer Assert their needs and desires while minimizing those of others. You will find placator and blamer married in therapy because their stances are complimentary. Your job as a therapist is to help blamer to learn how to acknowledge and develop empathy for the thoughts and needs of others. Minimizes other Needs to increase awareness of others' thoughts and feelings Direct confrontation often strengthens therapeutic relationship (they will find placators as weak)
Super-Reasonable (Computer) When they are feeling threated, they revert to the context. Some logical external system. They are typically not emotional. Minimizes self and others Logic and rules reign supreme Therapists must refer to context to gain validity Therapist should understand the logic and/or rules they use to organize their world. Therapists may need to refer to this context in order to gain validity. It is important to understand the logic of the system, but at the same time bringing in recognition and value to their own needs AND the needs and desires of others are valid. Learning how to teach them how to acknowledge all three areas of functioning.
Irrelevant (Distractor) Under distress, they distract. The class clown. When tension rises in a relationship, they distract with humor or something off-topic. They may distract. They are more likely to see this in schizophrenia. Your job as a therapist is to get the client reengaged with the difficult topic that they would prefer to just avoid in one way or another. Minimizes self, others, and context. No consistent grounding in self, other, or context Must increase ability to recognize thoughts and feelings of self and others. The focus for the therapist is on creating safety. Help them learn to recognize, and not be afraid of their thoughts and the thoughts of others. Stances acknowledge or minimize three realities: Self Other Context When we feel unsafe, we revert back to one of these communication stances. These are the stances used when someone is frightened. When we don't feel safe as children, we evolve communication stances to survive when we do not feel safe when we are young. You can use the communication stances to help better understand how to intervene, or how to communicate with your client. When you are working with a placator, be cautious if you are going to be making a suggestion it may help to give options. "Which do you think is the best fit or might work for you?" Ask them to give voice to their thoughts and opinions because they will be very quick even to please the therapist. Their task us to learn to assert themselves in a healthy way, how can they assert their needs so that they don't become resentful, depressed (needs do not get taken care of because they are not advocating for themselves) Therapy involves going through stages several times. Can be a new way of looking at the interactions and how to communicate in a more congruent way. The family is having to deal with this foreign element, this new way of interacting, this new idea, or new beliefs, this learning to tolerate direct emotional expression, etc.
That disrupts the family's Homeostasis Eventually the family integrates the new foreign element. People naturally tend toward positive growth All people possess the resources for positive growth Everything impacts and is impacted by everything else. Therapy is a process involving interaction between therapist and client; each person is responsible for themselves. Therapeutic presence (warmth and humanity) Making contact Making emotional contact. About real contact with the person at an intimate level. Contacting them in a very intimate, authentic, engaged way. Empathy Conveying hope Establishing credibility You must instill the hope to clients you can be helpful for them. Emotional Role of Symptom Symptom has a role in the family system Example: Child's exaggerated acting out may serve to reduce tension in marriage by getting parents on the same page. If the therapist can understand how symptom makes emotional sense, it will be easier to help find ways to interact successfully. Problematic family dynamics typically involve: Power struggles Parental conflicts Lack of validation Lack of intimacy Each person's role in family is assessed to understand the function of the problem. Possible roles: Martyr Victim or helpless one Rescuer Good child/parent Bad child/parent Timeline that includes major events in individual's or family's life. Births and deaths Important family events: Marriages, moves, tragedies, major illnesses, job loss Important historical events: Wars, natural disasters, economic downturns Gives both the therapist and client insight into the context of the problem as well as strengths and resources might exist. Child, mother, and father and quality of relationship between them. In this primary triad a child learns how to be human. The triad should serve as nurturing system for child. When the child is experiencing difficulty, the therapist considers how the nurturing function of these relationships can be improved. Layers of the iceberg: Behavior (Top Layer) Coping (Above) Feelings (Below) that are related to coping Perceptions, how is the person perceiving their life or how do they make meaning? Expectations, what are the expectations that are fueling all of this Yearnings (what are the primal yearnings) Helps clients transform their feelings about feelings to make change. Helps clients observe and evaluate themselves. Considers aspects of the self that the client values and aspects of which they are ashamed Self-Compassion: Better indicator of happiness than self-esteem As self-compassion and self-worth rise, Become more realistic and tolerant of their own and others' weaknesses. What extent does the client value themselves? How emotional issues may be manifesting in the body, either symbolically or functionally The way the body is used indicates a person's communication stance:
Congruent (Congruence) Communication: Open and relaxed body postures
Placating (Placator) Timid and reserved postures
Super-Reasonable (Computer): Cold and distant postures
Irrelevant (Distractor): Hyper and distracted The goal is transformation Achieve optimal realization of a person's full potential Two sets of practical goals for treatment planning: Relationally-focused goals: Congruent communication Individual-focused goals: Self-actualization Therapist's self The way the therapist is in the room. Ingredients of an interaction Whenever the therapist is talking with clients about difficult situations and interactions with others, they ask a series of questions. Go back to the iceberg. What do I hear and see? What is happening at the behavioral level without any interpretation. What are the meanings I make of this? What are they saying? What feelings do I have about these meanings I am making? What feelings do I have about those feelings? What defenses do I use/am I using? How does this trigger me and what kind of defensive behaviors might I bring, that makes them …. ? What are the rules within the system about how to comment about what's going on? What is allowed and what is appropriate? How am I responding and what part do I play in the system? Facilitating emotional expression What is allowed and what is appropriate? What is my response and what am I doing in this situation? Congruent expression, without the communication stances, turn chairs to each other directly, hold hands, make eye contact Softening family rules When families have rigid rules about who can say what, when, where, and how, she will soften some of these to create more space for everyone's particular way of communicating in a comfortable way to hopefully reduce the use of communication stances. Communication enhancement Helping each member of the family learn to communicate congruently in stressful circumstances, even when they do feel threatened by their partner or their child, Rather than reverting to a survival stance, to help them learn how to be fully congruent and present and to have more effective communications. Sculpting or spatial metaphor She would position each person in the family to metaphorically represent their role. (Example: A placator may be sculpted as being on their knees and begging, the blamer may be there pointing their finger angrily at someone, the irrelevant type might be in a strange position far off from everybody else, the super-reasonable might be sitting there in a very cold, distant, "I am citing the rulebook") Because it is more visual than verbal - you can add a verbal element to it by having each person say a motto of theirs (eg., "Please be nice to me," "Do what I say," "Follow the rules,") - that represents their position in the family. It can push past the survival stances, intellectual defenses, the family could sculpt themselves. It can be a powerful intervention. Touch Touch clients, help clients learn to hold and touch each other in nurturing ways, The therapist must be aware of cultures that have different attitudes towards emotional expression. The therapist adjusts to the client's level of intimacy. Used commonly in the LGBTQ community Focus is on the burden of societal rejection when being the authentic self. Combined main ideas from systemic and humanistic theories: Targeting emotional transactions from the interactional pattern Therapists use warmth, empathy, and self to facilitate desired change. Communication Stances: Give the therapist sense of how to most effectively communicate with the client.

Acknowledge Other/Context Minimizes self (sometimes context) People-pleasing tendencies Therapeutic Implications: Acknowledge own thoughts, feelings, needs Assertiveness/clear communication of needs Less directive therapy methods Multiple choice options to practice sense of agency Acknowledge Self/Context Minimize other Best connect with those who blame by addressing their expectations Therapeutic Implications: Generally prefer more upfront and direct communication Increase blamers' awareness of others' feelings Learn how to communicate in ways that are respectful of others Direct confrontation often strengthens the therapeutic relationship Acknowledge context Minimizes feelings/needs of self and others Prioritize a system of 'logic' (could be rational logic, religion doctrine, etc.) Therapeutic Implications: Reference and respect system of logic Help clients to also consider internal, subjective realities of self and others Might engage by starting with their bodily reactions, expectations, practical realities Avoidance No consistent grounding in self, other, or context Associated with most severe pathology Therapeutic Implications: Creates significant challenge for therapist Identify the unique 'anchors' of the client's reality Make the therapeutic relationship a place of upmost safety; less need for distracting communication Increase client's ability to recognize the thoughts and feelings of self and others Acknowledge the demands of context
Six-stage model of change that is based on research on Cybernetics systems and daws from humanistic principles. Model emphasizes that the therapist perturbs the system. 6 stages:
Status Quo Introduction of Foreign Element
Chaos Integration of New Possibilities Practice New Status Quo Satir's way of being in the world Unshakable hope and deep-felt respect for her clients Satir's presence in the room Put people at ease and allowed them to feel secure enough to relate to one another non-defensively This quality of being, or therapeutic presence, is difficult to define Few methods for systematically developing it More that therapists are congruent, the better they can create therapeutic warmth and humanity Satir et al., (1991) describe establishing a therapeutic relationship as 'making contact' Making Contact: Begins with the therapist being in contact with themselves, including all resources of the self in the self-mandala. Therapist works to make contact with each client in the room, engaging them on 'all channels': Mind Body Spirit Once the therapist has made contact with each person, the therapist works to help family members make contact with each other. Convey their understanding of clients' subjective, inner realities by expressing empathy Having empathy does NOT mean that a therapist: Takes the client's side Avoids confronting inconsistencies Ignores the client's responsibility Honoring the client's unique experience without validating it Makes it easier to move the client toward seeing that the other person has their unique experience, which is 'true' for that person Family Functioning: Role of symptom Family dynamics (power struggles, parental conflict, lack of validation/intimacy) Family Roles (Martyr, Victim, Rescuer, Good/Bad Parent/Child)
