Defenses and survival stances (Placating (Placator); Blaming (Blamer); Super-Reasonable (Computer); Irrelevant (Distractor)) Feelings Present feelings that are strongly past based Using past events to interpret the present Perceptions Beliefs, attitudes, and values that inform one's sense of self Expectations Strong belief about how life should go, how people should behave, and how one should perform Yearnings Universal longings to be loved, accepted, validated, and confirmed Satir always assessed a person's level of self-esteem More useful to consider: Aspects of the self that a client values Aspects of which client are ashamed Research indicates that self-compassion, or acceptance of one's strengths and weaknesses, is a better indicator of happiness than self-esteem. As self-compassion and self-worth rise, people become more realistic and tolerant of their own and others' weaknesses Mind-Body Connection How emotional issues may manifest in the body, either symbolically or functionally Also assess the role of nutrition and exercise Example: If a person is feeling burdened, this emotional feeling may manifest symbolically as stooped shoulders. Satir maintained that the way the body is used indicates the person's communication stance
Congruent (Congruence) Communication: Open and relaxed body postures
Placating (Placator) Timid and reserved postures
Super-Reasonable (Computer): Cold and distant postures
Irrelevant (Distractor): Hyper and distracted Goal of Satir's model is transformation To achieve the optimal realization of a person's full potential Attention to individual goals reflects their humanistic foundations 2 broad sets of practical goals for treatment planning: Systemic/family goals Individual goals Relational Goal: Congruent communication Communicating authentically while responding to the needs of self and others Goal to help the family develop ways for members to communicate so the system's homeostasis does not need the symptoms Overarching individual goal is consistent with other humanistic approaches: To promote self-actualization Self-Actualization: Fulfilling one's potential and living an authentic and meaningful life. Specific Goal Example: Increase sense of self-worth and self-compassion Reduce defensiveness and use of survival stances Therapists' use of self Being authentically who they are is one of the most essential interventions in Satir's approach Creates a safe relationship in which clients can practice communicating congruently Ingredients of an interaction: Details the internal communication process Teaches clients about internal and relational processes Ingredient Questions: Used to help people better understand their interactions with others Can be used with individuals, couples, or families Walk the client through the ingredients of an interaction: What do I hear and see? What meanings do I make of what I hear and see? What feelings do I have about the meanings I make? What feelings do I have about these feelings? What defenses do I use? What rules for commenting do I use? What is my response to the situation? Facilitating Emotional Expression Help put difficult emotions into words Naming emotions Locating in body Metaphor Coaching clients in how to have congruent communication in session May involve the 'ingredients of an interaction' with specific coaching strategies Satir's most distinctive intervention Done either with the family or in a group setting Puts family members in physical positions that represent how the 'sculptor' sees each person's role in the family Bypassing Denial/Resistance: Sculpting is a highly effective nonverbal confrontation that bypasses cognitive defenses Satir used touch in therapy to: Connect with clients Encourage and reassure clients when they were practicing new ways of communicating In today's environment: Touching less common because it can easily be misinterpreted as harassment Carefully consider trauma history, culture, gender, legal/ethical issues of using touch Coaching clients to touch each other Experiential therapies can be challenging online. Require attending to emotions and affect, which are communicated non-verbally Requires Using more verbal communication to make up for the loss of non-verbal communication Adapting non-verbal communication Sculpting: With drawings View whole Experiential approaches value: Clear, congruent, emotional expression Willingness to be vulnerable Cautions Cultural Gender Social Class/Educational Norms for emotional expression vary tremendously May initially be too threatening for clients hwo have been mandated to receive treatment. Satir's Growth Model (Human Validation Process Movement)

In Satir's Growth Model (Human Validation Process Movement), one of the four survival stances to help people temporarily deal with presumed threats and protect their self-worth. The stances help to protect us, but do not help us or other people to grow and thrive. Privileges self and context while discounting the other. To cope with low self-esteem, the person attacks another individual. On the outside the individual seems assertive, but on the inside feel isolated and alone. Their experience leads them to sometimes feel paranoid and even potentially homicidal. Assert their needs and desires while minimizing those of others. You will find placator and blamer married in therapy because their stances are complimentary. Your job as a therapist is to help blamer to learn how to acknowledge and develop empathy for the thoughts and needs of others. Needs to increase awareness of others' thoughts and feelings Direct confrontation often strengthens therapeutic relationship (they will find placators as weak) Acknowledge Self/Context Minimize other Best connect with those who blame by addressing their expectations Therapeutic Implications: Generally prefer more upfront and direct communication Increase blamers' awareness of others' feelings Learn how to communicate in ways that are respectful of others Direct confrontation often strengthens the therapeutic relationship Therapists can best connect with those who blame through addressing their expectations. The goal often is to increase blamers' awareness of others' thoughts and feelings and help them learn how to communicate their personal perspectives in ways that are respectful of others. With these clients, direct confrontation often strengthens the therapeutic relationship. Blamers generally prefer more upfront and direct communication than is generally tolerated in polite society. Blaming (Blamer)

In Satir's Growth Model (Human Validation Process Movement), one of the four survival stances to help people temporarily deal with presumed threats and protect their self-worth. The stances help to protect us, but do not help us or other people to grow and thrive. Discounts self, other, and context. Engage in distraction to avoid having to deal with their low self-esteem. People may describe them as fun and spontaneous. However, you cannot have a serious or straightforward conversation with them. This leads to a psychological orientation of confusion and possible psychosis. Avoidance No consistent grounding in self, other, or context Associated with most severe pathology Therapeutic Implications: Creates significant challenge for therapist Identify the unique 'anchors' of the client's reality Make the therapeutic relationship a place of upmost safety; less need for distracting communication Increase client's ability to recognize the thoughts and feelings of self and others Acknowledge the demands of context A client with the irrelevant stance creates a unique challenge for therapists because there is no consistent grounding in self, other, or context for the therapist to use in understanding and communicating with the client. The therapist must spend time 'floating' along with the client's distractions to identify the unique 'anchors' of the client's reality that the therapist can tap into. Bodily sensations, touch, and physical activities often work best with this client stance. As treatment progresses, the therapist works with these clients to increase their ability to recognize the thoughts and feelings of self and others and to acknowledge the demands of context. Progress is typically slower with those who use this stance frequently. Irrelevant (Distractor)
The ideal communication stance, where a person is privileging self, other, and context.
Satir's Growth Model (Human Validation Process Movement) Congruent (Congruence)

In Satir's Growth Model (Human Validation Process Movement), one of the four survival stances to help people temporarily deal with presumed threats and protect their self-worth. The stances help to protect us, but do not help us or other people to grow and thrive. Privileges the context and discounts the self and others. Focuses on the rules rather than on emotions and relationships. Very data driven and people appreciate them for their intellect. To offset their internal vulnerability, the super-reasonable person doesn't allow themselves to connect with any emotions. This can lead to a rigidness that may be displayed via obsessive-compulsive behaviors. Acknowledge context Minimizes feelings/needs of self and others Prioritize a system of 'logic' (could be rational logic, religion doctrine, etc.) Therapeutic Implications: Reference and respect system of logic Help clients to also consider internal, subjective realities of self and others Might engage by starting with their bodily reactions, expectations, practical realities Privileges the context and discounts the self and others. Focuses on the rules rather than on emotions and relationships. Very data driven and people appreciate them for their intellect. To offset their internal vulnerability, the super-reasonable person doesn't allow themselves to connect with any emotions. This can lead to a rigidness that may be displayed via obsessive-compulsive behaviors. When working with those who use a super-reasonable stance, logic and rules reign supreme. Since these clients avoid all emotions, therapists might best engage them by starting with their bodily reactions and expectations before moving onto feelings. The goal with this stance is to help clients value the internal, subjective realities of themselves and others. Super-Reasonable (Computer) This lets you know how you sense yourself. What is the physical condition of your sense organs? What freedoms do you give yourself to look, hear, touch, taste, and smell? Many of us were taught that we could only look at, touch, or listen to certain things. That often resulted in limiting our use of our senses. To acknowledge, honor, and fully and freely use our senses is the main way we interact with the outside world and stimulate ourselves internally.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Experiential Family Therapy/Satir/Satir's Growth Model (Human Validation Process Movement).canvas
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Structural Family Therapy
item.description:
Salvador Minuchin
Accommodation Elements of a system automatically adjust to coordinate their functioning; people may have to work at it.
Boundary Emotional and physical barriers that protect and enhance the integrity of individuals, subsystems, and families.
Boundary Making Negotiating the boundaries between members of a relationship and between the relationship and the outside world.
Coalition An alliance between two individuals or social units against a third.
Complementarity The reciprocity that is the defining feature of every relationship.
Empathy Understanding someone else's beliefs and feelings.
Enactment
An interaction stimulated in Structural Family Therapy in order to observe and then change transactions that make up family Structure.
Family Structure The functional organization of families that determines how family members interact.
Hierarchical Structure Family functioning based on the clear generational boundaries, where the parents maintain control and authority.
Intensity
Salvador Minuchin 's term for changing maladaptive transactions by using strong affect, repeated intervention, or prolonged pressure.
Joining
A Structural Family Therapy 's term for accepting and accommodating to families to win their confidence and circumvent resistance.
Shaping Competence Encouraging and reinforcing productive behavior rather than criticizing dysfunctional behavior.
Structure Recurrent patterns of interaction that define and stabilize the shape of relationships.
Subsystem Smaller units in families, determined by generation, sex, or function. One of the reasons family therapy can be difficult is that families often appear as collections of individuals who affect one another in powerful but unpredictable ways. Structural family therapy offers a framework that brings order and meaning to those transactions. The consistent patterns of family behavior are what allow us to consider us to have that they have structure. The emotional boundaries and coalitions that make up a family's structure are abstractions. The concept of family structure enables therapists to intervene in a systematic and organized way. Families usually seek help for a specific problem. Family therapists look beyond the specifics of those problems to the family's attempts to solve them. This leads to the dynamic of interaction. What structural family therapy adds to the equation is a recognition of the overall organization that regulates those interactions.
Families are organized in Subsystem with Boundaries regulating the contact family members have with one another. Enactments: Family members are encouraged to deal directly with one another in sessions, permitting the therapist to observe and modify their interactions.
Salvador Minuchin was born and raised in Argentina. He served as a physician in the Israeli army and then came to the US, where he trained in child psychiatry with Nathan Ackerman.
Salvador Minuchin returned to Israel in 1952 to work with displaced children. He moved back to the US in 1954 to begin psychoanalytic training at the William Alanson White Institute. After the White Institute, Minuchin took a job at the Wiltwyck School for delinquent boys, where he suggested to his staff that they started seeing families. At Wiltwyck, Minuchin and his colleagues (Dick Auerswald, Charlie King, Braulio Montalvo, and Clara Rabinowitz) taught themselves to do family therapy, inventing it as they went along.
In 1962, Minuchin met Jay Haley at Palo Alto (1952). Success with work with families led to book Families of the Slums. First outlined the structural model. By the 1970s structural family therapy had become the most widely practiced of all systems of family therapy.
The center in New York was renamed the Minuchin Center for the Family. Beginners often get bogged down in the content of family problems because they don't have a blue print to help them see the pattern of family dynamics.
Three constructs define structural theory: Structure, Subsystem, and Boundaries.
Family Structure refers to the way a family is organized into Subsystem whose interactions are regulated by interpersonal Boundaries. To grasp a family's structure, you must look beyond their interactions to the organizational framework within which they occur, and you must keep in mind that what goes on in one part of a family is affected by the organization of the whole system. As family transactions are repeated, they foster expectations that establish enduring patterns. Once patterns are established, family members use only a fraction of the options available to them. Patterns are set, roles assigned, and things take on a sameness and predictability. Family structure is reinforced by the expectations that establish rules in a family. Sequences are isomorphic: They're structured. Modifying any of them may not change the basic structure, but altering the underlying structure will have ripple effects on all family transactions. Family structure is shaped partly by universal and partly by idiosyncratic constraints. Family members tend to have reciprocal and complementary functions. Often these become so ingrained that their origin is forgotten and they are presumed necessary rather than optional. Whatever the pattern, it tends to be self-perpetuating. Although alternatives are available, family members are unlikely to consider them until changing circumstances produce stress in the system. To understand these patterns, two things are necessary: A theoretical system that explains structure Seeking the family in action Structure becomes evident only when you observe actual interactions among family members. Families are differentiated into subsystems - based on generation, gender, and function - which are demarcated by interpersonal boundaries, invisible barriers that regulate contact with others. Interpersonal boundaries vary from rigid to diffuse. Rigid boundaries: Restrictive and permit little contact with outside subsystems, resulting in disengagement. Disengaged subsystems are independent but isolated. On the plus side, this fosters autonomy. On the other hand, disengagement limits affection and support. Disengaged families must come under extreme stress before they mobilize assistance. Clear Boundary: Normal range. Diffuse Boundaries: Enmeshed subsystems offer closeness but at the expense of independence. Too much closeness cripples initiative. Although structure suggests a static condition, family structure goes through a process of development. Families begin when two people in love decide to share their lives together, but a period of often difficult adjustment is required before they complete the transition from courtship to a functional partnership. They must learn to accommodate to each other's needs and styles of interaction. The couple must also develop complementary patterns of support. Some patterns are transitory. Other patterns are more lasting. Exaggerated complementary roles can detract from individual growth; moderate complementarity enables couples to divide functions to support and enrich each other. Complementary patterns exist in all couples; they become problematic when they are so rigid that they create a dysfunctional subsystem. The spouse subsystem must also develop a boundary that separates it from parents, children, and other outsiders. A clear boundary enables children to interact with their parents but excludes them from the spouse subsystem. Parents and children eat together, play together, and share much of each other's lives; but there are some spouse functions that need not to be shared. Unhappily, the clamorous demands of children often make parents lose sight of the need to maintain a boundary around the relationship. In addition to maintaining privacy for a couple, a clear boundary supports a hierarchical structure in which parents occupy a position of leadership. Unless therapists learn to look beyond the limited slice of ecology where they work to the larger social structures within which their work is embedded, their efforts may amount to little more than spinning wheels. Structural therapists are able to explain what regulates families and why they behave as they do.
When two people join to form a couple, the structural requirements for the new union are Accommodation and Boundary Making. The first priority is mutual accommodation to manage the myriad details fo everyday living. They must coordinate daily rituals. In accommodating to each other, a couple must establish a boundary between them as well as a boundary separating them from the outside. Each partner tends to be more comfortable with the level of proximity that existed in their own family. Because these expectations differ, a struggle ensues that may be the most difficult of the new union. Couples must also define a boundary between them and their original families. The birth of a child transforms the structure of a new family into a parental subsystem and a child subsystem. Many men do not accept the role of father until their infants are old enough to respond to them. Thus, even in healthy families, children often bring stress and conflict. Children require different styles of parenting at different ages. Minuchin (1974) warns therapists not to mistake growing pains for pathology. What distinguishes normal families is not the absence of problems but a functional structure for dealing with them. Therapists should keep in mind that they may simply be in the process of modifying their structure to adjust to new circumstances. Modifications in structure are required when a family or one of its members encounters external pressure and when developmental transitions are reached. Healthy families accommodate to changed circumstances; dysfunctional families increase the rigidity of structure that are no longer working. In disengaged families, boundaries are rigid, and the family fails mobilize support when it's needed. If someone is disengaged in one relationship, they is likely to be preoccupied elsewhere. In enmeshed families, boundaries diffuse, and family members become dependent on one another. Intrusive parents create difficulties by stunting the development of their children and interfering with their ability to solve their own problems. Families as enmeshed or disengaged, it's more accurate to describe particular subsystems as being enmeshed or disengaged. Enmeshment and disengagement tend to be reciprocal. A frequently encountered pattern is the enmeshed mother/disengaged father syndrome - "The signature arrangement of the troubled middle-class family." Skewed relationships, whatever their origin, can be problematic, though no one individual should be expected to do all the changing. Hierarchies can be rigid and unfair, or weak and ineffective. In the first case, children may find themselves unprotected because of a lack of guidance; in the second, their growth as individuals may be impaired and power struggles may ensue. Just as a functional hierarchy is necessary for a family's stability, flexibility is necessary for it to adapt to change. One problem often seen by family therapists arises when parents who are unable to resolve conflicts between themselves divert the focus of concern onto a child. Instead of worrying about themselves, they worry about the child. An equally common patter is for the parents to argue through the children.
Both may be critical of the other's way, but they perpetuate each other's behavior with their own. the result is a Cross-Generational Coalition. Some families function well when the children are young but are unable to adjust to an older child's needs for discipline. Young children in enmeshed families receive wonderful care. Although such parents may be too tired from caring for the children to have much time for each other. If these doting parents don't teach their children to obey the rules and respect authority, the children may be unprepared to negotiate their entrance into school. Since they have not learned to accommodate to others, they may be rejected by their schoolmates. Such children often become depressed. In other cases, children enmeshed with their parents become discipline problems at school, in which case school authorities may initiate counseling. Blended families either readjust their boundaries or soon experience transitional conflicts. The sooner such families enter treatment, the easier it is to help them adjust to the transition. An important aspect of structural family problems is that symptoms in one member reflect not only that individual's interactions but also other relationships in the family. Structural therapy was once a strictly action-oriented approach. Family therapy pioneers differentiated themselves from psychoanalysis by aggressively ignoring emotion and cognition - why family members interact the way they do - and the past - how they learned to act that way - in order to focus on interactions in the present. Structural family therapy has evolved to consider not only how family members interact but also how and why they learned to do so. Structural treatment is designed to alter the organization of a family so that its members can solve their own problems. The goal of therapy is structural change; problem solving is a by-product. The idea that family problems are embedded in dysfunctional family structures has led to the criticism of structural family therapy as pathologizing. Structural problems are viewed as a failure to adjust to changing circumstances. Structural therapists see their work as activating latent adaptive patterns that are already in families' repertoires. Most important is the creation of an effective hierarchy. Parents should be in charge, not relate to their children as equals. With enmeshed families the goal is to differentiate individuals and subsystems by strengthening the boundaries around them. With disengaged families the goal is to increase contact by making boundaries more permeable.
A therapist produces change by Joining the family, probing for areas of flexibility, and then activating dormant structural alternatives. Joining gets the therapist into the family; accommodating to their style gives them leverage; and restructuring transforms the family structure. To join, a therapist conveys acceptance of family members and respect for their ways of doing things. Only after successful joining with a family is it fruitful to attempt restructuring - the often dramatic confrontations that challenge families and encourage them to change. The first task is to understand the family's view of their problems. This is accomplished by tracking their perspectives in the words they use to explain them and in the behavior with which they demonstrate them. Observing and modifying the structure of family transactions in the immediate context of the session. Structural therapists work with what they see, not what family members describe. Structural therapists make assessments by observing how family members respond to their dilemmas. Structural therapists make no assumptions about how families should be organized. It's the fact that a family seeks therapy for a problem they have been unable to solve that gives a therapist license to assume that something about the way they are organized may not be working for them. Because problems are a function of the entire family structure, it's important to include the whole group for assessment. But sometimes even the whole family isn't enough because the family may not be the only relevant context. Some problems may be treated as problems of the individual. "Pathology may be inside the patient, in their social context, or in the feedback between them." Making an assessment is best done by focusing on the presenting problem and exploring the family's response to it. To carry this assessment further, a structural therapist would explore the relationship between the parents. The assessment would also involve talking with the parents about growing up in their own families in order to explore how their pasts helped shaped the way they react to things now. Minuchin described the process of assessment as organized in four steps: Ask questions about the presenting complaint until family members begin to see that the problem goes beyond the symptom bearer to include the entire family. Help family members see how their interactions may be perpetuating the presenting problem. A brief exploration of the past, focusing on how the adults in the family came to develop the perspectives that influence their interactions. Explore options that family members like to interact in more productive ways to create a shifting the family structure and help resolve the presenting complaint. Opening questions should give family members a chance to tell their stories and express their feeilngs. On the other hand, a therapis tshould not accept at face value a family's description of their problems as residing entirely within one individual. The point is not to shift blame but to open a discussion about how family members' interactions may be influencing one another. In Families and Family Therapy, Minuchin (1974) listed three overlapping stages in structural family therapy. The therapist: Joins the family in a position of leadership. Maps the family's underlying structure. Intervenes to transform this structure. In general, structural family therapy follows these steps: Joining and accommodating Enactment Structural Mapping Highlighting and Modifying Interactions Boundary Making Unbalancing Challenging Unproductive Assumptions Family members expect to be told they are doing something wrong, and they are prepared to defend themselves. The therapist must first disarm defenses and ease anxiety. This is done by building an alliance of understanding with each member of the family. Greet the family, then ask for each person's view of the problem. Listen carefully, and acknowledge what you hear. The first step in breaking the cycle of misunderstanding is to offer the empathy family members may be temporarily unable to provide one another. Hearing and acknowledging each person's account of the family's sorrows provides further information - and begins to release family members from the resentment of unheard feelings. Joining opens the way for family members to begin listening to one another and establishes a bond with the therapist that enables them to accept the challenges to come. A therapist shows respect for parents by honoring their authority. Children have special concerns and capacities. they should be greeted gently and asked simple questions. Those who wish to remain silent should be allowed to do so. Important to join powerful family members as well as angry ones. Important to reconnect with such people at frequent intervals, particularly when things begin to heat up. Getting family members to talk with one another runs counter to their expectations. They expect to present their case to an expert and then be told what to do. If a therapist begins by giving each person a chance to speak, usually one will say something about another than can be a springboard for an enactment. Working with enactments requires three operations: The therapist notices a problematic sequence. The therapist initiates an enactment. The therapist guides the family to modify the enactment. Once an enactment is begun, a therapist can discover many things about a family's structure. Families demonstrate enmeshment by interrupting, speaking for one another, doing things for children that they can do for themselves, or constantly arguing. In disengaged families you may see a husband sitting impassively while his wife cries, a total absence of conflict, a surprising ignorance of important information about the children, or a lack of conern for each other's interests. When an enactment breaks down, a therapist intervenes in one of two ways: Commenting on what went wrong Pushing them to keep going Preliminary assessments are based on interactions in the first session. In later sessions these formulations are refined or revised. Families quickly induct therapists into their culture. It is important to develop structural hypotheses relatively early in the process. Structural assessments take into account both the problem the family presents and the structural dynamics it displays. And they include all family members. Once families begin to interact, problematic transactions emerge. Recognizing their structural implications requires focusing on process, not content.
The trick is to modify this pattern. This may require forceful intervening, or Intensity. Structural therapists achieve intensity by selective regulation of affect, repetition, and duration. Tone, volume, pacing, and choice of words can be used to raise the affective intensity of interventions. It helps if you know what to say.
Coalition: Intensity can also be achieved by extending the duration of a sequence beyond the point where homeostasis is reinstated. Sometimes intensity requires repitition of a theme in a variety of contexts.
An alternative strategy is to use Empathy to help family members get beneath the surface of their defensive wrangling. Once these more genuine emotions are articulated, they can serve as a basis for clients reconnecting with each other in a less defensive manner.
Shaping Competence Another method of modifying interactions. Intensity is used to block the stream of interactions. Shaping competence is like altering the direction of the flow. By reinforcing positives, structural therapists help family members use functional alternatives that are already in their repertoire. A sense of timing helps. In enmeshed families, interventions are designed to strengthen boundaries. Family members are urged to speak for themselves, interruptions are blocked, and dyads are helped to finish conversations without intrusion. Although structural therapy is begun with the whole family, subsequent sessions may be help with individuals or subgroups to strengthen their boundaries. Disengaged families tend to avoid conflict and thus minimize interaction. A structural therapist intervenes to challenge conflict avoidance and block detouring in order to help disengaged family members break down the walls between them. When beginners see disengagement, they tend to think of ways to encourage positive interaction. In fact, disengagement is usually a way of avoiding arguments. Therefore, people isolated from each other usually need to confront their differences.
Problems are usually seen as the result of what someone else is doing, and solutions are thought to require that others change. Structural therapists move family discussions from linear to circular perspectives by stressing Complementarity. In boundary making, a therapist aims to realign relationships between subsystems. In unbalancing, the goal is to change the relationship within a subsystem. What often keeps families stuck in stalemate is that members in conflict are balanced in opposition and, as a result, remain frozen in inaction. In unbalancing, the therapist joins and supports one individual or subsystem. Unbalancing is part of a struggle for change that sometimes takes on the appearance of combat. But real combat is between them and fear - fear of change - Its practitioners sometimes challenge the way clients see things. Changing the way family members interact offers alternative views of their situation. The converse is also true: changing the way family members view their situation enable them to change the way they interact. Sometimes therapists act as teachers, offering information and advice, often about structural matters. Doing so is likely to be a structuring maneuver and must be done in a way that minimizes resistance. Effective challenges describe what people are doing and its consequences. However, in order for family members to hear what is being pointed out, they must not feel attacked. Saying 'That's interesting' before pointing something out make it an object of curiosity rather than an occasion for defensiveness. Moreover, although it's tempting to tell people what they should do, doing so reduces the likelihood of them learning to see what they are doing - and its consequences. Greater emphasis on helping families understand their organization and less of the combative attitude that sometimes characterized therapists several decades ago. What's important to keep in mind is that structural family therapy isn't a set of techniques; it's a way of looking at families. Some of the strongest empirical support for structural family therapy comes from a series of studies on children with psychosomatic symptoms and young adults addicted to drugs. Family conflict can precipitate ketoacidosis crises in children with diabetes. These children's manifest distress was accompanied by dramatic increases in free fatty acid levels, a measure related to ketoacidosis. This study provided strong confirmation of the clinical observation that children with psychosomatic illnesses are involved in the regulation of stress between their parents. The 90% improvement rate is impressive, especially compared with the usual 30% mortality rate for this disorder. The positive results at termination were maintained at follow-up intervals of several years. Several more recent studies have replicated these findings and shown that structural family therapy is effective in the treatment of anorexia nervosa. Structural family therapy has also been shown to be effective in treating psychosomatic asthmatics and psychosomatically complicated cases of diabetes. Early structural family therapy studies demonstrated effectiveness in treating disruptive behavior and adolescent substance use. Example: Families of the Slums by Minuchin Duke Stanton showed that structural family therapy can be effective for people addicted to drugs and their families. Symptom reduction was significant with structural family therapy; the level of positive change was more than double that achieved in the other conditions, and these positive effects persisted at follow-up of 6 and 12 months. Structural family therapy can be effective when addressing problem behavior spanning the externalizing spectrum (e.g., disrupting behavior, adolescent substance use, conduct disorder, ADHD). Structural family therapy has been successful in reducing the likelihood that African American and Latino youth would initiate drug use, engaging and retaining families in treatment. Structural family therapy is equal in effectiveness to communication training and behavioral management training in reducing negative communication, conflicts, and expressed anger between adolescents diagnosed with ADHD and their parents. Structural family therapy has also been effective for treating adolescent disorders, such as conduct disorders. Structural Ecosystems Therapy has been shown to improve family functioning and in turn boost drug abstinence for women living with HIV or AIDS. A structural family therapy approach also yielded encouraging results in the alleviation of maternal depressive symptoms and mixed results of child functioning. The structural model directs clinicians to look beyond the content of problems and even beyond the dynamics of interaction to the underlying family organization that supports and constrains those interactions. The most important tenet of this approach is that every family has a structure, and this structure is revealed only when the family is in action. Therapists who fail to consider the entire family's structure and intervene in only one subsystem are unlikely to effect lasting change. Subsystems are units of the family based on function. Subsystems are regulated by interpersonal boundaries. In healthy families boundaries are clear enough to protect independence and permeable enough to allow mutual support. Enmeshed families have diffuse boundaries; disengaged families have rigid boundaries. Once they've gained a family's trust, therapists promote family interaction while they assume a decentralized role. From this position they can observe and make a structural assessment, which includes the problem and the organization that supports it. These assessments are framed in terms of boundaries and subsystems, easily conceptualized as two-dimensional maps used to suggest avenues for change. After they have successfully joined and assessed a family, structural therapists proceed to activate formant structures using techniques that alter alignments and shift power within and between subsystems. These restructuring techniques are concrete and sometimes forceful. However, their success depends on as much on effective joining and assessment as on the power of the techniques themselves.
Family is depicted as a system that comprised of Subsystem. A family is functional to the degree that it nurtures its members to negotiate well the demands of the outside world.
Boundaries set limits distinguishing subsystems from one another in varying permeability (from diffuse to rigid). Subsystems separated by a diffuse boundary are enmeshed, whereas subsystems separated by a rigid boundary are disengaged. Major Concepts: Family
Family Structure Structure Predictable sequences or organized patterns in which families interact A set of rules governing behavior patterns Structures typically have some form of hierarchical structure. Reciprocal and complementary functions. Parental involvement with children, over versus under involvement. Structure is expressed through transactional patterns such as:
Hierarchy Determines who (or which subsystem) has power in the system. Any structure in a family is not static, it is developed over time. Hierarchies can be rigid and unfair or weak and ineffective.
Power Alliances
Structure: The way a family is organized into subsystems whose interactions are regulated by interpersonal boundaries. The organized pattern in which families interact.
Subsystem: Subsystems are often formed based on the patterns of interactions in a family. Patterns of interaction are largely based on roles and rules. Covert coalitions are often more significant than obvious groupings. Families are differentiated into subsystems based on generation, gender, or function. Adults are the 'organizational leaders' of the family system so whatever is present in the adult subsystem relationship will be felt throughout the whole system. Children are common 'symptom bearers.' Organization is most healthy when there are 3 clearly defined systems: Marital/Couple Parental Child/Sibling
Boundaries Each subsystems is demarcated by interpersonal boundaries. Boundaries range from rigid to diffuse.
Rigid Boundaries (Disengaged Subsystem)
Rigid boundaries are restrictive and permit little contact with outside subsystems, resulting in Disengagement. Disengaged systems are independent, but isolated. On the plus side, this fosters autonomy. But limits affection and support. Diffuse Boundaries (Enmeshed Subsystem):
Diffuse boundaries are result in Enmeshment. Enmeshed systems offer closeness, but at the expense of independence. Too much closeness can cripple initiative.
Coalition
Patterns
Patterns are formed based on rules that are implicit or explicit. Over time, as patterns develop, roles for family members are established. Patterns are isomorphic (i.e., interaction patterns are repeated in different relationships in a system)
Triangles
Loyalties Assumptions: The family could have developed a structure different from the dysfunctional one now being displayed. The family processes adaptive resources in its relational repertoire that currently lie dormant. Therapy attempts to activate what is already there, but latent. Offers a framework that brings order and meaning to family transactions. The consistent patterns of family behavior reveal family structure. The emotional boundaries and coalitions that make up a family's structure are abstractions. The concept of family structure enables therapists to intervene in a systematic and organized way. Families seek help for a specific problem. Family therapists look beyond the specifics of those problems to the family's attempts to solve them. Exploring dynamics of interaction. Recognizing the overall organizations of the family regulates those interactions. The model attends to subsystems and boundaries that regulate contact between members. The model emphasizes enactments wherein family members are encouraged to deal directly with one another in session, permitting the therapist to observe and modify their interactions. Structural family therapy provides therapists with a blueprint for how to view patterns of family dynamics. Theoretical Formulations: Basic assumption is that families are organized structurally in certain ways to cope with stress. Organized patterns ensure the survival of the system, all patterns have this purpose. Systems both responds and reacts to internal and external stressors. Problems are symptomatic of the family's inability to be flexible and accommodating of changing needs. All family behavior, even destructive behavior, has the goal of balancing the system to ensure its survival. Family problems do not result from stresses in the system but from the effects of reactions and responses to the stresses. The focus of treatment is on changing the family structure rather than changing individual family members. The process of family interaction is like the patterns of conversation at the dinner table. The structure of the family is where family members sit in relation to each other. As family transactions are repeated, they foster expectations that establish enduring patterns. Family structure is reinforced by the expectations that establish rules in a family. Healthy families not defined by the abundance of problems. But rather by a functioning structure Healthy families can modify their structure to accommodate changing circumstances. Unhealthy families increase rigidity of structures that are no longer functional. Less adaptive families increase rigidity of structures and are no longer functional. Problems arise when there are: Weak hierarchies; conflict avoidance; cross-generational coalitions Inflexible structures Failure to adjust to changing circumstances Failure to reorganize themselves in order to deal with stresses in the home environment. The ultimate goal of therapy is structural changes to the family Alter the family structure so that the family can solve its own problems. General goal: create or strengthen executive subsystem Therapists have two types of assessment tools:
Enactment Spontaneous behavior sequences Enactments occur when a therapist stimulates a family to demonstrate how they handle problems Therapists guide the family how to modify the enactment, creating new behavior sequences. Joining and accommodating (effective therapy requires challenge and confrontation) "The structural therapist needs to relate to family members in a way that validates their experience but does not preclude a challenge to the status quo." Working with interaction (Use of enactments) Mapping structural patterns (Observing enmeshment and disengagement) Focus on the underlying family structure: Highlight and modify interactions Intensity (interrupt rigid and difficult patters) "Challenging to be effective must be predicated on the client's strengths. Contrary to a common misconception, it is not the 'opposite' of joining. Joining and challenging need to be seen as simultaneous qualities in any therapeutic intervention." Help people do things themselves Therapists can invite family members to participate and interact in ways that will Help them function more efficiently Transformation of family structure
Boundary Making Loosen boundaries in disengaged families Strengthen boundaries in enmeshed families Unbalancing
Reframing (adding cognitive constructions) Unbalancing Blocking Stopping usual transactions Exaggerating Encouraging or sustaining interactions Keeping silent When a response is expected, doing the unusual by not giving one, thereby demanding the family to react. Manipulating the intensity Therapist's comfort level with intense emotions
Enactment
Complementarity Summarize the cycle of interaction and clarify the systemic nature of the symptoms, relieve blame from any one person, and direct the way to change.
Boundaries:
Enmeshment:
Disengagement:
First-Order Change:
Second-Order Change:
Subsystem:
Structure:
Hierarchy
Power Alliances
Coalition
Patterns
Triangles
Loyalties

item.description:
Smaller units in families, determined by generation, sex, or function. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Boundaries
Structural Family Therapy: Families are differentiated into subsystems based on generation, gender, or function. Adults are the 'organizational leaders' of the family system so whatever is present in the adult subsystem relationship will be felt throughout the whole system. Children are common 'symptom bearers' Organization is most healthy when there are 3 clearly defined systems: Marital/Couple Parental Child/Sibling

item.title: Structure
item.description:
Recurrent patterns of interaction that define and stabilize the shape of relationships. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Structural Family Therapy Structure is: The way a family is organized into subsystems whose interactions are regulated by interpersonal boundaries. The organized pattern in which families interact Patterns are formed based on rules that are implicit or explicit. Over time, as patterns develop, roles for family members are established. Patterns are isomorphic (i.e., interaction patterns are repeated in different relationships in a system). The focus of treatment is on changing the family structure rather than changing individual family members. The process of family interaction is like the patterns of conversation at the dinner table. The structure of the family is where family members sit in relation to one another. As family transactions are repeated, they foster expectations that establish enduring patterns. Family structure is reinforced by the expectations that establish rules in a family.

item.description: Reinforcing change in small steps. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)

item.title: Shaping Competence
item.description: Encouraging and reinforcing productive behavior rather than criticizing dysfunctional behavior. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)

item.title: Joining
item.description: A Structural Family Therapy's term for accepting and accommodating to families to win their confidence and circumvent resistance. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019) Clients feel a sense of connectedness with you, which usually arises when they feel you understand, respect, and care about them. Joining is both a technique (developing rapport) and an attitude.

item.title: Intensity
item.description: Salvador Minuchin's term for changing maladaptive transactions by using strong affect, repeated intervention, or prolonged pressure. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)

item.title: Strategic Family Therapy
item.description:
Problem-centered pragmatic strategies for altering problem-maintaining sequences of interaction. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Jay Haley Lecture on Strategic Family Therapy
Strategic grew out of Gregory Bateson's project on schizophrenia at the Mental Research Institute.
The initial emphasis was on observation and research on families, but due to the influence of University Resources/HDFS Classes/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Solution-Focused Therapy/Key Figures/Milton Erickson's work, intervention strategies were also formulated. Believed in using the resources of his clients and designing a 'strategy for each specific problem.' He did not care about perspective (insight) as long as their actions produced beneficial results. Conducted therapy by paying extreme attention to details of symptoms his clients presented. IN therapy: Accepted and emphasized positive Used indirect and ambiguously worded directives. Directed routine behaviors so that the resistance is shown through change and not through normal and continuous actions. The MRI Model, Milan Model, and Haley and Madanes all overlap. The MRI Pioneers:
Don Jackson
Gregory Bateson, as a consultant
Virginia Satir (1988)
John Weakland
Jay Haley
Paul Watzlawick
Richard Fisch
Jules Riskin The hallmarks of strategic therapy are: Using a set of novel strategies to solve family problems. Generating change rather than generating insight. Circumventing resistance rather than dealing directly with it. People are always communicating. All behavior is communicative One cannot not communicate. All messages have report and command functions. Report = CONTENT = Information = WHAT IS SAID Command = PROCESS = Underlying Relationship = HOW IT IS SAID Families often perpetuate problems by their own actions. Directives tailored to the needs of a particular family can sometimes bring about sudden and decisive change. The exchange of multilayered messages between family members define their relationships. Interrupting vicious cycles that occur when attempts to solve problems only make them worse. Focuses on identifying and interrupting 'ironic processes' which occur when repeated attempts to solve a problem keep the problem going or make it worse. The aim of therapy is simply to resolve the presenting complaint as quickly and efficiently as possible, so clients can get on with life. BSCT makes no attempt to specify what constitutes a functional or dysfunctional family relationship. The therapist attends to what clients do, as well as, how they view the problem, themselves, and each other. Often see family members individually in the context of family therapy, even when the focus of the intervention is a relational complaint. If no one registers a complaint, there is no problem. Patterns (e.g., quiet detachment, volatile engagement) may be dysfunctional for some families and adaptive for others. What matters is the extent to which interaction patterns based on attempted solutions keep a complaint going or make it worse. The problems clients being to therapy persist only if they are maintained by ongoing current behavior of the family. How a problem persists is much more relevant to therapy than how the problem originated. The behavior of one member of the family is stimulated and shaped by the response of the others. Well-intentioned yet ironic solutions break the vicious cycle (positive feedback loops) that maintain an impasse. The rules or regularities of family interaction that operate to preserve family stability. The conservation aspect of family systems (similar to cybernetic concept of negative feedback). When a specific behavior within a system changes. When the rules of a system change. Rules are typically unspoken, and govern most behavior. When rules promote rigid attempted solutions, it isn't just the behavior, but the rule needs to change.
When a specific behavior within a system changes = First-Order Change
When the rules of the system change = Second-Order Change Families are stuck in a spiraling positive feedback loop. They make common sense but ineffective attempts to change responses. For example: When a younger sibling arrives, the older sibling, feeling unloved, starts screaming for attention. The parent punishes him which reinforces his feelings of being unloved, and he continues to throw tantrums. The job is simply to get the family moving again. Help families define clear and reasonable goals so that everyone knows when treatment has been successful. Alter specific patterns of communication that maintain problems. MRI: The way to resolve problems is to reverse the misguided solutions that have been maintaining them. Haley: Changes in behavior alter perceptions (rather than the other way around). Milan: Get families to see things differently (through reframing or positive connotation), rather than in getting family members to behave differently. MRI Group: Carefully defining the presenting problem and figuring out why it is perpetuated. Non-historic and symptom focused. Haley and Madanes: Examine behavioral sequences around the problem. Examine structural anomalies (weak parental hierarchies, cross-generational coalitions) Milan Group: Preliminary hypothesis tested using circular questioning (systemic explanations). Find the most motivated person in the system. Gain clear understanding of problem (symptom). "What will be the first signs that things are getting better?" Inquire about attempted solutions. Observe and interrupt problem-maintaining sequences. Use therapeutic paradox. Family encourages depressed member to be sad so he feels less guilt for not being happy. The solution is to deny that a problem exists; action is necessary but not taken. The solution is an effort to solve something that isn't really a problem; action is taken when it should not be. The solution is an effort to solve a problem within a framework that makes solution impossible; action is taken but at the wrong level. Haley joins and interviews the entire family. Social Stage -> Problem Stage -> Interaction Stage -> Goal-Setting Stage -> Task-Oriented Stage Each family member should speak and introduce themselves. Therapist should ensure problems are not discussed until everyone can speak. Therapist should examine family seating arrangements to assess organization. Keep conclusions tentative. Shift to the therapy stage. Inquire why the family is there and what the problem is. Be general and ambiguous so the family can expand. Respect the family hierarchy to gain cooperation. Treat those who have power and influence in the family with respect. Therapist should not share observations with the family. Therapist should think of the problems in terms of more than one person. It is critical family members interact with one another rather than with the therapist. Therapist should redirect family members toward each other. Assess family organization through interactions. Families need to define desired changes. Therapist can act as wise advisor and assist the family in setting goals. Use of directives (interventions aimed at targeting and changing specific behaviors). Pre-Session, Session, Intersession, Intervention, Post-Session Discussion Positive connotation (reframing without blaming) Circular questioning Team approach (Reflecting team, greek chorus) Neutrality Responsible for guidance of treatment. We are going to focus on what the problem is. Be aware of timing and pacing. Meet client where they are. Take the time (to form treatment plans) Respond to subtle pressure from clients. Avoid attempting interventions prematurely. Gather enough data about where the client is at before making attempts at intervention. Use of Qualifying Language: "I have a suggestion to make, but I am not sure how much it will accomplish. It will depend on your ability to use your imagination..." Getting client to be specific. Taking one-downmanship. The inherent power difference in therapy Determining the format of meeting. Individual vs. Conjoint In what situation will individual session be beneficial? 'Window Shopper' Client: Re-negotiate contract Working with the complainant Get them down to business Restrictive Client: Ask permission to redirect Setting specific boundary Asking a couple to deliberately have an argument during the week in order to help the therapist to understand how they get involved in such no-win encounters and how they are able to get each other to act unreasonably. Discouraging families from trying to change too fast, warning them to go slow and worrying out loud about the possibility of relapse when improvements do occur. Never tell client why we do this. The family is told to continue or embellish the behavior they complain about. Sometimes the therapist prescribes the symptom while secretly hoping the clients will rebel against the directive. As soon as a family member is overwhelmed they are instructed to make a list of all of the things that they might do to sabotage their life. Doing so can take the rebellion out of self-destructive behavior, thus making it less appealing and less impulsive. Offering a different perspective/framework to understand problem behavior. "The use of language to give a new meaning to a situation." (Piercy et al., 1996) Reframes can be offered by asking circular questions: "Who makes you depressed?" "What does dad do when you and mom are fighting?" Changing the frame of reference for understanding behavior leads to change in the rules governing interactions which in turn leads to sustainable change.

item.description: Family functioning based on the clear generational boundaries, where the parents maintain control and authority. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)

item.description: Temporary or superficial changes within a system that do not alter the basic organization of the system itself. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)

item.title: Feedback Loop
item.description:
The return of a portion of the output of a system, especially when used to maintain the output within predetermined limits (negative feedback) or to signal a need to modify the system (positive feedback). (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Positive Feedback
Negative Feedback
Cybernetics

item.title: Jay Haley
item.description:
Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019: "Jay Haley was always something of a maverick. He entered the field without clinical credentials and established his reputation as a gadfly and critic. His initial impact came from his writings, in which he infused sarcasm with incisive analysis. "
Strategies of Psychotherapy, Jay Haley Covert messages are used in the struggle for control that characterizes many relationships Symptoms represent an incongruence between levels of communication Since symptomatic behavior wasn’t reasonable, Haley didn’t try to reason with patients to help them Defined therapy as a directive form of treatment and acknowledged his debt to Milton Erickson, with whom he studied hypnosis. In what he called brief therapy, Haley zeroed in on the context and possible function of a patient’s symptoms. therapist is directing patients to do precisely what they would do anyway and thus subtly gaining the upper hand The decisive techniques in brief therapy were directives it isn’t enough to explain problems to patients; what counts is getting them to do something about them. paradox here is that you can’t accidentally make a mistake if you are doing so deliberately The cybernetic principle here: People will do anything to get out of housework
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Strategic Family Therapy/Key Figures/Jay Haley.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Solution-Focused Therapy
item.description:
Steve de Shazer's term for a style of a therapy that emphasizes the solutions that families have already developed for their problems. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Steve de Shazer
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Solution-Focused Therapy/Solution-Focused Therapy.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Visitor
item.description:
De Shazer's term for a client who does not wish to be part of therapy, does not have a complaint, and does not wish to work on anything. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Solution-Focused Therapy
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Solution-Focused Therapy/Key Terms and Concepts/Visitor.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Scaling Questions
item.description:
Solution-focused clients are asked to rate on a 10-point scale how much they want to resolve their problems, how bad the problem is, how much better it is then the last time, and so on. Designed to break change up into small steps. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Solution-Focused Therapy
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Solution-Focused Therapy/Key Terms and Concepts/Scaling Questions.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Miracle Question
item.description:
Asking clients to imagine how things would be if they woke up tomorrow and their problem was solved. Solution-focused therapists use the miracle question to help clients identify goals and potential solutions. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Solution-Focused Therapy
Steve de Shazer
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Solution-Focused Therapy/Key Terms and Concepts/Miracle Question.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Exception Question
item.description:
Used in solution-focused therapy to help clients remember times when they haven't been defeated by their problems. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Solution-Focused Therapy
Steve de Shazer
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Solution-Focused Therapy/Key Terms and Concepts/Exception Question.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Customer
item.description:
De Shazer's term for a client who not only complains about a problem ('Complainant') but also is motivated to resolve it. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Solution-Focused Therapy
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Solution-Focused Therapy/Key Terms and Concepts/Customer.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Coping Questions
item.description: Used in Solution-Focused Therapy to help clients realize they have been managing difficult circumstances. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Solution-Focused Therapy/Key Terms and Concepts/Coping Questions.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Compliments
item.description:
Used in solution-focused therapy to convey support and encouragement. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Solution-Focused Therapy
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Solution-Focused Therapy/Key Terms and Concepts/Compliments.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Complainant
item.description:
De Shazer's term for a relationship with a client who describes a complaint but is at present unwilling to work on solving it. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Solution-Focused Therapy
Steve de Shazer

item.title: Network Therapy
item.description:
A treatment devised by Ross Speck in which a large number of family and friends are assembled to help resolve a patient's problems. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Ross Speck

item.description: Treatment of several families at once in a group therapy format; pioneered by Peter Laqueur and Murray Bowen. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)

item.description: Explanations based on properties of a single individual or object: Johnny shoplifts because he is rebellious. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
