item.title: Communications Theory
item.description: The study of relationships in terms of the exchange of verbal and nonverbal messages. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Other Therapy Theories/Communications Theory.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Narrative Therapy
item.description: An approach to treatment that emphasizes the role of the stories people construct about their experience. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Narrative Family Therapy/Narrative Therapy.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Unique Outcome
item.description:
Michael White's term for times when clients acted free of their problems, even if they were unaware of doing so. Narrative therapists identify unique outcomes as a way to help clients challenge negative views of themselves. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Narrative Therapy
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Narrative Family Therapy/Keywords and Concepts/Unique Outcome.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Social Constructionism
item.description: Like constructivism, challenges the notion of an objective basis for knowledge. Knowledge and meaning are shaped by culturally shared assumptions. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Narrative Family Therapy/Keywords and Concepts/Social Constructionism.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Relative Influence Questions
item.description:
Questions designed to explore the extent to which the problem has dominated the client versus how much he or she has been able to control it. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Narrative Therapy
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Narrative Family Therapy/Keywords and Concepts/Relative Influence Questions.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Reconstruction
item.description: Reweaving narrative accounts into more palatable and coherent histories. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Narrative Family Therapy/Keywords and Concepts/Reconstruction.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Problem-Saturated Stories
item.description:
The usual pessimistic and blaming accounts that clients bring to therapy, which are seen as helping keep them stuck. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Narrative Therapy
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Narrative Family Therapy/Keywords and Concepts/Problem-Saturated Stories.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Deconstruction
item.description: A postmodern approach to exploring meaning by taking apart and examining taken-for-granted categories and assumptions, making possible newer and sounder constructions of meaning. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Narrative Family Therapy/Keywords and Concepts/Deconstruction.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Self of the Therapist Reflections
item.description:
Making Contact When are you able to make authentic contact as Satir describes? Describe relationships in which you feel most authentic and able to fully connect with another. Why does this connection matter? What helps you to 'make contact' with others? (Research Citations/Books/@gehartMasteringCompetenciesFamily2017) Communication Stances
With a partner or on your own, identify the survival communication stances that each member of your family of origin used when there was a loss of relational safety. What contexts or situations are most likely to trigger you to feel unsafe and revert to your survival stance? In what contexts have you learned to maintain congruent communication even when you feel threatened? (Research Citations/Books/@gehartMasteringCompetenciesFamily2017)
Six Levels of Experience With a partner or on your own, identify a recent stressful event that made you feel strong negative emotion of some kind. Use the iceberg to describe the multiple layers of experience related to the one event. Are some levels incongruent with other layers? Does identifying the different layers of experience help you understand the situation differently? Do you see any new options?
Building Self-Esteem or Self-Worth
@satirNewPeoplemaking1988 Relax for a moment now. Close your eyes and feel your condition now. How are you feeling about yourself? What has happened or is happening at the moment? How are you responding to what is happening? How are you feeling about how you are responding? If you are feeling tight, give yourself a message of love, physically relax yourself and consciously be in touch with your breathing. Now open your eyes. You will feel stronger as a result. Since the feeling of low worth has been learned, it can be unlearned, and something new learned in its place. The possibility for this learning lasts from birth to death, so it is never too late. Other Stop reading for a few minutes and think about some families you know that would fit the description “troubled.” Did the family you grew up in have some of these characteristics: Was your family at times cold, deadening, super polite, secretive, confusing? What are the characteristics of the family you are living in now? Can you discover any signs of trouble that you haven’t been aware of before? Can you think of a family that you would call nurturing at least part of the time? Can you remember a time recently when your family could be described as nurturing? Try to remember how it felt to be in your family then. Do these times happen often? Invite your family members to try the following experiment with you. Take a partner, then tell one another your feelings ("Right now, I feel scared/tight/embarrassed/happy/etc."). Each partner simply thanks the other without judging or commenting. You thus hear one another's feelings so you can know each other better. We need a lot of practice to break the taboo against sharing our feelings. Practice as much as you can with people you trust. Now, tell each other what makes you each feel low, or high. You may find new dimensions to the people you have been living with all these years and feel closer or more real to them as a result. When you have finished the exercise, give yourself permission to share what happened for you. Tonight, when the family has settled around the table for dinner, notice what is happening to your feelings about yourself when other members speak to you. There will be some remarks to which you have no special response. However, you may be surprised to find that even "Pass the potatoes, please" can give you a feeling of or depreciation, depending on the speaker's tone of voice, facial expression, timing (did the message interrupt you, or ignore something you said?), and how good you are feeling about yourself. If you are feeling good about yourself, you may find that you have a lot of options for how you respond. If you are feeling low, however, you might find that your options are limited (see chapter 6 on communication). Halfway through dinner, change the perspective. Listen to what you are saying to others. Try to be in the other's shoes and imagine how you might feel if you were talked to as you are doing now. Would you, for instance, feel loved and valued? Tomorrow night explain this little game to the other members of the family and invite them to join you. It will be helpful to read this chapter aloud before you do this as a family. After dinner, talk together about what you discovered and how you felt. Take a Saturday morning or a Sunday afternoon. The topic is “What new has been happening to me lately?” Everyone has a chance to share, not just the children. Leadership can rotate among the members. Don’t forget the celebration party afterward. You will probably find these times can be very enjoyable. You might try creating a funny or romantic theme, for instance.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Experiential Family Therapy/Satir/Self of the Therapist Reflections.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Satir's Growth Model (Human Validation Process Movement)
item.description:
Virginia Satir (1916-1988)
In the late 1950 s, she joined Don Jackson, Jay Haley, and others in developing the Mental Research Institute (MRI). Satir wrote one of the first books about family therapy, Conjoint Family Therapy, in which she provided transcripts of how she worked. Every person has resources available to them, but when troubled, they do not usually utilize these resources to their utmost abilities.
Self-Mandala: The individual is at the center, and surrounding them are the eight universal human resources: spiritual, contextual, nutritional, interactional, sensual, emotional, intellectual, and physical.
Each part is interconnected. The less these 8 areas are given energy and time, the lower a person's self-esteem.
When people experience low self-esteem, they attempt to cope by using Survival Stances. These stances help people temporarily deal with presumed threats and protect their self-worth. The stances help to protect us, but do not help us or other people to grow and thrive. The four survival stances are:
Placating (Placator): Occurs when people discount themselves and privilege the other person and the context. Individual tends to apologize a lot, feels worthless, and may become depressed or suicidal. They tend to be quite sensitive and caring. The placating stance discounts self and privileges the other person and the context.
Blaming (Blamer): Privileges self and context while discounting the other. To cope with low self-esteem, the person attacks another individual. On the outside the individual seems assertive, but on the inside feel isolated and alone. Their experience leads them to sometimes feel paranoid and even potentially homicidal.
Super-Reasonable (Computer): Privileges the context and discounts the self and others. Focuses on the rules rather than on emotions and relationships. Very data driven and people appreciate them for their intellect. To offset their internal vulnerability, the super-reasonable person doesn't allow themselves to connect with any emotions. This can lead to a rigidness that may be displayed via obsessive-compulsive behaviors.
Irrelevant (Distractor): Discounts self, other, and context. Engage in distraction to avoid having to deal with their low self-esteem. People may describe them as fun and spontaneous. However, you cannot have a serious or straightforward conversation with them. This leads to a psychological orientation of confusion and possible psychosis.
The goal of Satir's therapy is to help people enhance their own and others' self-esteem. When we do so, we function from a Congruent (Congruence) communication stance. This is the healthiest position we can operate from. The Satir Growth Model is a strength-based approach, focusing on the existing resources that family members bring with them. Faulty coping strategies maintain problematic interactions. Therapy provides a safe space for people to choose alternative ways of coping. Therapy increases people's self-esteem, leading them to be able to lean into their uniqueness and provide a space for their loved ones to feel comfortable in their own uniqueness as well. Whatever techniques the therapists uses, they are designed to help raise awareness within and between people in hopes of increasing self-esteem and self-worth so that people feel freer to be authentic. (Congruence) Self-Esteem Maintenance Kit: Detective Hat: Used when there is something new that the person wants to understand better. It helped them shift away from judging an experience to exploring it. Medallion: Two-sided and says 'yes' on one side and 'no' on the other. It is intended to help the person recognize that they can say either word, depending on what they truly want, so they can maintain their integrity. Wand (Empowering wand, courage stick, wishing wand): Helps people move from inaction based on fear to action based on desire. Golden Key: Opens any door - helping the person ask questions they might not have previously, so the unsayable, and do the undoable. Wisdom Box: Helps connect the person to the wider world and all that has come before them.
Experiential therapists are interactive in the therapy room. They try to use their whole self for contact. This includes adopting an I-Thou Perspective, where they try to promote human-to-human interaction. Since one of the main goals of therapy is to help the client become more congruent, it is important for the therapist to engage the client congruently. The therapist must be a real person who helps model a way of being for the client. Experiential therapists conceptualize a few main processes: Status Quo: The family is currently in this process, and is leading to difficulties bringing them to therapy. Foreign Element: The family's expression of the desire to change. Chaos: The therapist's introduction of novelty into the system. Integration: Family members put what they learn from therapy into practice. Practice: Involves trying out these learnings. New Status Quo: - New homeostasis takes hold.
The therapist raises the intensity of interactions so that people encounter their own experiences and can thus become more authentic. Therapy then helps people to allow others to be more authentic.
Sculpting: Sculpting helps people get in touch with their inner experience and express this experience to others in a way that bypasses the typical spoken word. Sculpting can be done in one of two primary ways: The client is asked to sculpt their family based on their experience of what it is like to be part of this family now. Then the therapist can sculpt the family based on their own inner picture of the family's experience. Family members are asked to place other people in physical poses spatially located around the room and then to position themselves somewhere within. This provides the family with a new way of engaging with self and other. This allows for new meanings to come forth, where people can become more authentically themselves. The therapist will begin with one member of the family. The choice of person will depend on the family organization, the presenting problem, and the therapeutic process. Once that person has presented their image of the family, the therapist acts as a guide for each family member, bringing forth their perceptions of this picture and what it represents about the various relationships in the family. Therapist then shifts to another family member to explore their experience, as every family member unique has their own way of seeing and being in the family. Therapist may also end the sculpt by having family members sculpt their desired picture of the family. This sculpt shifts the energy in the room from a focus on past problems and dysfunction to a future functional and supportive arrangement of relationships. Satir viewed people as housing energy and as able to transfer this energy through physical connections with one another.
Family Reconstruction: Designed to help an individual connect better to the historical and psychological interconnections of their family. By seeing self and family of origin with a new perspective, the individual might then feel more freedom to engage in new possibilities for the future.
Star: The person whose relationship with the family is being explored and worked on.
The therapist prepares the reconstruction by talking with the star about their family history. This involves developing a Family Map, or the primary family that can include the grandparents, a Family Life Chronology, highlighting three generations of the star's family, including important dates and historical events (similar to the genogram), and the Wheel of Influence, a chart including all the people who influenced the star when they were growing up. The therapist ('guide') begins the family reconstruction by telling the star's story; then sculpts the family of origin, the star's parents' families of origin, and the star's parents' relationship; and then resculpts the star's family of origin. The overall goal is to increase the star's self-esteem so they are empowered to engage with themselves and others in new and more productive ways. This should engender more hope in them for their future.
Parts Party: Based on the notion that people have many faces (or aspects of self), a parts party helps people to accept that they also have many possibilities. Some of our parts may be lying dormant, and when we access them, we increase our resources. The parts party helps people to acknolwedge, accept, transform, and integrate their parts. Other participants play the role of the various parts to help the person move from internal processes to more interpersonal processes. "The Growth Model," where the focus was on helping people access their inner resources as opposed to, "The Medical Model," where the emphasis was on pathology and symptom reduction.
Satir likened the role of a family therapist to that of a gardener in that people are like seeds, they carry all the resources they need for growth if nurtured and protected from blocks to their growth. She believed that the key resource for each person was their Unique Spirit from which emanated other resources such as: self-awareness, self-acceptance, change, choice, compassion, curiosity, determination, hope, love, and wisdom. "The question for me was never whether (people) had spirits, but how I could contact them... It was as though I saw through to the inner core of each being, seeing through to the inner core of each being, seeing the shining light of the spirit trapped in a thick black cylinder of limitation and self-rejection. My effort was to enable the person to see what I saw; then, together, we could turn the dark cylinder into a large, lighted screen and build new possibilities." (Satir, 1988, p. 340-341) Her goals for family therapy included helping the individual members increase their sense of worth and value by accessing their inner resources and by decreasing any emotional blocks. And for the family as a whole, she saw the goal as being to increase congruent communication and heart connections. She began to observe that there were some universal unspoken rules that blocked the individual members from functioning at full capacity and also hindered the connections between members. These were: It is not okay to see what is going on in the family. It is not okay to feel what you feel. It is not okay to talk about what you see and feel. It is not okay to ask for what you want. It is not okay to take risks. She would observe the family members and their interaction and if she detected any of these rules in the family, she would help them break them by asking questions such as: "What do you see going on between your and your ?" "What are you aware of feeling at this moment?" "Can you tell your ___ what you are feeling?" "Can you ask your ___ for what you want?" "I invite you to use your courage and say what you see happening in your family."
She also helped them to make better connections with each other by decreasing their defensiveness. Satir identified the primary defensive stances as Blaming (Blamer), Placating (Placator), Distracting, and being Super-Reasonable (Computer). Forms of Fight:
Blaming (Blamer) (This is all your fault.)
Generalizing (You always think you are right.)
Labeling (You are so stupid.)
Threatening (You better shape up or else.) Physically Attacking the Other. Forms of Flight:
Placating (Placator) (Do what you wish, my needs don't matter.)
Being Super-Reasonable (Computer) (I don't care what you feel, just give me the facts.) Emotionally Withdrawing (Physically present but not emotionally present.) Physically Withdrawing (Leaving the room or hanging up on someone.) Cutting-Off (Refusing to talk to the other for days or longer.) Within a family system, these defenses can be played out in interactional patterns such as: Blame - Blame Blame - Withdraw Placate - Placate Blame - Placate Blame - Distract Withdraw - Withdraw Satir developed a process for helping people change and become more connected. Her process is described as having six phases: Phase 1 - Making Contact Satir would reach out using her body position, eye contact, and facial expression to make contact with each member. She would also consciously work to connect from her spirit to theirs. Phase 2 - Validating Satir worked to help people feel validated in many ways such as reflecting their feelings, affirming their values and highlighting their inner resources. Examples include: "You feel scared because your son got suspended from school." "You value education." "You are courageous to seek help." Phase 3 - Facilitating Awareness Satir had many different ways that she would attempt to bring awareness to a family about their defensive patterns in a non-blaming way.
Sculpting: Satir placed the members in body positions to give them a picture of their defensive behavior. For the blaming stance, she would position the person leaning toward another and pointing at them and for the placating stance, she would position the person down on one knee with their head down and their hand up in a pleading position. Satir would also bring awareness to members by exploring their inner experiences. She used the metaphor of an iceberg to help the family therapist to conceptualize the inner level so experience driving defensive behaviors. Above the water line were the inner levels of experience such as feelings, perceptions, expectations, beliefs, and yearnings. (What meaning are you giving to what your ___ said that is causing you to feel hurt? Is that a familiar place for you to go to when someone is disappointed in you? What is it you yearn for?) Phase 4 - Promoting Acceptance One of the ways that satir promoted acceptance was through 'normalizing,' that is, reassuring the family member that what they were experiencing was normal. ("It is normal to...") Another way that she promoted acceptance was by 'bridging' between conflicting parties. ("I am hearing that is is not easy for _, I would be interested to know how life was for you when you were their age?") Phase 5 - Eliciting Positive Choices and Changes Once Satir observed that the family members were aware of and accepting of their unhelpful patterns, she would lead them into seeing new possibilities for their interactions. After sculpting the family, she would ask them to each to stand in a balanced way and look at each other. She would then guide them in a dialogue helping them to express themselves in non-defensives ways. Other times she would simply have them sit face to face and she would guide the dialogue between them. "What happens for you when your says you choose over your ? You feel... Did you know that your felt __? What happened for you when you heard them express their feelings? You long to be more connected with them. You miss them. How do you feel to hear how much they miss you?" Phase 6 - Reinforcing Change Satir would often combine verbal responses with some supportive touch to reinforce a positive shift. The therapist also needs to work on their own personal growth. This is true for working with individuals but it is even more true when working with families as the chances of being triggered by your own family experience are even greater. As Satir used to say, "You are the most important instrument in the room!" Under threat and reward, change is painful: change is viewed as unnatural, the unknown is feared, the status quo is maintained, life's natural 'flow' is blocked, and the familiar is valued despite discomfort. The seed model has people viewing change more positively; as naturally occurring at a variety of levels (from cellular to cosmic) and as scary, but offering new opportunities. Discomfort is seen as a signal for change. Therapists using the seed model keep in mind that families entering therapy are problem-focused and will maintain the status quo as a necessary survival behavior. Therapist should make contact with each person to communicate a climate of acceptance (e.g., people do the best they can) and hear them out to discover 'what is.' Understanding the status quo stage is essential to clarify how the change process gets started or is blocked. This stage is explored further by examining resistance and readiness concepts in detail. The coin of change has resistance and readiness as its head and tail sides. Experientially, we may want to change in one moment and fear or sabotage it in the next. Then status quo is considered a trance, accounting for change resistance as well as a medium in which change may be fostered. Changing circumstances elicit shifts in perception, which in turn stimulate changes in thinking, feeling, and acting. But when circumstances shift back, behavior also reverts. Perception can appear to create change of behavior when the meaning of an event is reframed, but the underlying pattern is not altered. Altering the underlying pattern requires dealing with resistance to change. Resistance is a coping behavior intended to preserve the organism rather than obstruct change. Reframing resistance in terms of its positive intention. The way we are socialized has us, "Gradually acquiring a variety of commitments which constrain the person into following a consistent pattern of behavior." The effect is to develop a lifestyle that stabilizes the events in our lives, our interdependence of meaning of these events, and the way we define ourselves, as well as predisposing us to seek consistent situations. Experientially, change involves invoking the unfamiliar. Intellectualizing, avoiding feelings, compulsive activity, impatience about change, and dwelling in the past are all ways of dealing with the confusion by maintaining the status quo. The tasks at this stage are to cope with the threat to past security and sense of competence and self-esteem; deal with feelings of loss and longing for the past. Conservative impulse, the will to change has to overcome an impulse to restore the past, to resist the change. Survival depends on this impulse. By stabilizing perceptions, the conservative impulse enhances the ability to learn from experience. Only when it does not fit this construct is its 'newness' experienced.
Readiness refers to what Satir considered the unstable balance of elements in the Status Quo. Persons considering change are more open to consciousness-raising interventions, more aware of themselves, more conscious of their psychic distress, and more likely to seek out information about their problem. Variation in readiness for change (even in one person) depends on social circumstances, timing, opportunity, location, change goal, the degree of social pressure or support for the goal, alternations in environments circumstances, developmental crises, and physical or emotional pain. Four patterns emerge reflecting the relative influence of these readiness factors. These patters are based on the degree of difficulty involved in making the change and the degree of responsibility the person is wiling to take for making the change.
Preemptive Change: This pattern describes 'overnight' change. The inordinate strength of the motivating influences lowers the degree of difficulty in making the change. The degree of responsibility for the change is also low. The change in circumstances preempts issues of loss (leaving family and friends), self-efficacy ("Can I do it?"), and self-esteem ("Am I worth the effort?") that are ordinarily addressed in making changes. Problems maintaining the change may require attention at a later point in the change process. Change literally 'happens' to us in this pattern, but we have little sense of ownership of it.
Self-Managed Change: In this pattern, the influences motivating the change are less extreme or immediate than those noted in the preemptive patter. The person is influenced to take a conscious and self-responsible approach to change and is required to deal with one or more of the issues of loss, self-efficacy, and self-esteem in order to resolve the resistance to change.
Satir Family Therapy - YouTube Experiential family therapies include four approaches:
Satir's Growth Model (Human Validation Process Movement)
Symbolic-Experiential Family Therapy
Emotionally Focused Therapy (EFT)
Internal Family Systems Model Targeting emotional transactions Warmth, empathy, and the therapist's use of self Individual and family focus Five Communication Stances:
Congruent (Congruence) Able to acknowledge what you are thinking and feeling, what the other person may be thinking or feeling
Placating (Placator) Ignore their own thoughts and feelings and focus on the thoughts and feelings of others. Quick to put aside their own emotions for the sake of others. They often are so quick to deny their own feelings. Your job as a therapist is to help them learn to acknowledge their own thoughts and feelings but also the thoughts and feelings of others. They do not want to increase tension when needs are not met and risk having tension in the relationship. Minimizes self People-pleasing tendencies Needs less directive therapy methods
Blamer Assert their needs and desires while minimizing those of others. You will find placator and blamer married in therapy because their stances are complimentary. Your job as a therapist is to help blamer to learn how to acknowledge and develop empathy for the thoughts and needs of others. Minimizes other Needs to increase awareness of others' thoughts and feelings Direct confrontation often strengthens therapeutic relationship (they will find placators as weak)
Super-Reasonable (Computer) When they are feeling threated, they revert to the context. Some logical external system. They are typically not emotional. Minimizes self and others Logic and rules reign supreme Therapists must refer to context to gain validity Therapist should understand the logic and/or rules they use to organize their world. Therapists may need to refer to this context in order to gain validity. It is important to understand the logic of the system, but at the same time bringing in recognition and value to their own needs AND the needs and desires of others are valid. Learning how to teach them how to acknowledge all three areas of functioning.
Irrelevant (Distractor) Under distress, they distract. The class clown. When tension rises in a relationship, they distract with humor or something off-topic. They may distract. They are more likely to see this in schizophrenia. Your job as a therapist is to get the client reengaged with the difficult topic that they would prefer to just avoid in one way or another. Minimizes self, others, and context. No consistent grounding in self, other, or context Must increase ability to recognize thoughts and feelings of self and others. The focus for the therapist is on creating safety. Help them learn to recognize, and not be afraid of their thoughts and the thoughts of others. Stances acknowledge or minimize three realities: Self Other Context When we feel unsafe, we revert back to one of these communication stances. These are the stances used when someone is frightened. When we don't feel safe as children, we evolve communication stances to survive when we do not feel safe when we are young. You can use the communication stances to help better understand how to intervene, or how to communicate with your client. When you are working with a placator, be cautious if you are going to be making a suggestion it may help to give options. "Which do you think is the best fit or might work for you?" Ask them to give voice to their thoughts and opinions because they will be very quick even to please the therapist. Their task us to learn to assert themselves in a healthy way, how can they assert their needs so that they don't become resentful, depressed (needs do not get taken care of because they are not advocating for themselves) Therapy involves going through stages several times. Can be a new way of looking at the interactions and how to communicate in a more congruent way. The family is having to deal with this foreign element, this new way of interacting, this new idea, or new beliefs, this learning to tolerate direct emotional expression, etc.
That disrupts the family's Homeostasis Eventually the family integrates the new foreign element. People naturally tend toward positive growth All people possess the resources for positive growth Everything impacts and is impacted by everything else. Therapy is a process involving interaction between therapist and client; each person is responsible for themselves. Therapeutic presence (warmth and humanity) Making contact Making emotional contact. About real contact with the person at an intimate level. Contacting them in a very intimate, authentic, engaged way. Empathy Conveying hope Establishing credibility You must instill the hope to clients you can be helpful for them. Emotional Role of Symptom Symptom has a role in the family system Example: Child's exaggerated acting out may serve to reduce tension in marriage by getting parents on the same page. If the therapist can understand how symptom makes emotional sense, it will be easier to help find ways to interact successfully. Problematic family dynamics typically involve: Power struggles Parental conflicts Lack of validation Lack of intimacy Each person's role in family is assessed to understand the function of the problem. Possible roles: Martyr Victim or helpless one Rescuer Good child/parent Bad child/parent Timeline that includes major events in individual's or family's life. Births and deaths Important family events: Marriages, moves, tragedies, major illnesses, job loss Important historical events: Wars, natural disasters, economic downturns Gives both the therapist and client insight into the context of the problem as well as strengths and resources might exist. Child, mother, and father and quality of relationship between them. In this primary triad a child learns how to be human. The triad should serve as nurturing system for child. When the child is experiencing difficulty, the therapist considers how the nurturing function of these relationships can be improved. Layers of the iceberg: Behavior (Top Layer) Coping (Above) Feelings (Below) that are related to coping Perceptions, how is the person perceiving their life or how do they make meaning? Expectations, what are the expectations that are fueling all of this Yearnings (what are the primal yearnings) Helps clients transform their feelings about feelings to make change. Helps clients observe and evaluate themselves. Considers aspects of the self that the client values and aspects of which they are ashamed Self-Compassion: Better indicator of happiness than self-esteem As self-compassion and self-worth rise, Become more realistic and tolerant of their own and others' weaknesses. What extent does the client value themselves? How emotional issues may be manifesting in the body, either symbolically or functionally The way the body is used indicates a person's communication stance:
Congruent (Congruence) Communication: Open and relaxed body postures
Placating (Placator) Timid and reserved postures
Super-Reasonable (Computer): Cold and distant postures
Irrelevant (Distractor): Hyper and distracted The goal is transformation Achieve optimal realization of a person's full potential Two sets of practical goals for treatment planning: Relationally-focused goals: Congruent communication Individual-focused goals: Self-actualization Therapist's self The way the therapist is in the room. Ingredients of an interaction Whenever the therapist is talking with clients about difficult situations and interactions with others, they ask a series of questions. Go back to the iceberg. What do I hear and see? What is happening at the behavioral level without any interpretation. What are the meanings I make of this? What are they saying? What feelings do I have about these meanings I am making? What feelings do I have about those feelings? What defenses do I use/am I using? How does this trigger me and what kind of defensive behaviors might I bring, that makes them …. ? What are the rules within the system about how to comment about what's going on? What is allowed and what is appropriate? How am I responding and what part do I play in the system? Facilitating emotional expression What is allowed and what is appropriate? What is my response and what am I doing in this situation? Congruent expression, without the communication stances, turn chairs to each other directly, hold hands, make eye contact Softening family rules When families have rigid rules about who can say what, when, where, and how, she will soften some of these to create more space for everyone's particular way of communicating in a comfortable way to hopefully reduce the use of communication stances. Communication enhancement Helping each member of the family learn to communicate congruently in stressful circumstances, even when they do feel threatened by their partner or their child, Rather than reverting to a survival stance, to help them learn how to be fully congruent and present and to have more effective communications. Sculpting or spatial metaphor She would position each person in the family to metaphorically represent their role. (Example: A placator may be sculpted as being on their knees and begging, the blamer may be there pointing their finger angrily at someone, the irrelevant type might be in a strange position far off from everybody else, the super-reasonable might be sitting there in a very cold, distant, "I am citing the rulebook") Because it is more visual than verbal - you can add a verbal element to it by having each person say a motto of theirs (eg., "Please be nice to me," "Do what I say," "Follow the rules,") - that represents their position in the family. It can push past the survival stances, intellectual defenses, the family could sculpt themselves. It can be a powerful intervention. Touch Touch clients, help clients learn to hold and touch each other in nurturing ways, The therapist must be aware of cultures that have different attitudes towards emotional expression. The therapist adjusts to the client's level of intimacy. Used commonly in the LGBTQ community Focus is on the burden of societal rejection when being the authentic self. Combined main ideas from systemic and humanistic theories: Targeting emotional transactions from the interactional pattern Therapists use warmth, empathy, and self to facilitate desired change. Communication Stances: Give the therapist sense of how to most effectively communicate with the client.
Satir Family Therapy | Part 1 - YouTube Satir brought an unparalleled warmth and enthusiasm for human potential Focused on: Fostering individual growth Improving family interactions In order to facilitate change: - Used experiential exercises, metaphors, coaching, and self-of-the-therapist e
Healthy communication is 'congruent' Acknowledges perspective/needs of 'self' Acknowledges perspective/needs of 'other' Appropriate to context Development: Minimizes one or more essential parts of the total picture Develop in childhood when feel threatened Survival Stances:
Placating (Placator)
Blaming (Blamer)
Super-Reasonable (Computer)
Irrelevant (Distractor) One can use more than one stance, but usually use one style predominantly. Acknowledge Other/Context Minimizes self (sometimes context) People-pleasing tendencies Therapeutic Implications: Acknowledge own thoughts, feelings, needs Assertiveness/clear communication of needs Less directive therapy methods Multiple choice options to practice sense of agency Acknowledge Self/Context Minimize other Best connect with those who blame by addressing their expectations Therapeutic Implications: Generally prefer more upfront and direct communication Increase blamers' awareness of others' feelings Learn how to communicate in ways that are respectful of others Direct confrontation often strengthens the therapeutic relationship Acknowledge context Minimizes feelings/needs of self and others Prioritize a system of 'logic' (could be rational logic, religion doctrine, etc.) Therapeutic Implications: Reference and respect system of logic Help clients to also consider internal, subjective realities of self and others Might engage by starting with their bodily reactions, expectations, practical realities Avoidance No consistent grounding in self, other, or context Associated with most severe pathology Therapeutic Implications: Creates significant challenge for therapist Identify the unique 'anchors' of the client's reality Make the therapeutic relationship a place of upmost safety; less need for distracting communication Increase client's ability to recognize the thoughts and feelings of self and others Acknowledge the demands of context
Six-stage model of change that is based on research on Cybernetics systems and daws from humanistic principles. Model emphasizes that the therapist perturbs the system. 6 stages:
Status Quo Introduction of Foreign Element
Chaos Integration of New Possibilities Practice New Status Quo Satir's way of being in the world Unshakable hope and deep-felt respect for her clients Satir's presence in the room Put people at ease and allowed them to feel secure enough to relate to one another non-defensively This quality of being, or therapeutic presence, is difficult to define Few methods for systematically developing it More that therapists are congruent, the better they can create therapeutic warmth and humanity Satir et al., (1991) describe establishing a therapeutic relationship as 'making contact' Making Contact: Begins with the therapist being in contact with themselves, including all resources of the self in the self-mandala. Therapist works to make contact with each client in the room, engaging them on 'all channels': Mind Body Spirit Once the therapist has made contact with each person, the therapist works to help family members make contact with each other. Convey their understanding of clients' subjective, inner realities by expressing empathy Having empathy does NOT mean that a therapist: Takes the client's side Avoids confronting inconsistencies Ignores the client's responsibility Honoring the client's unique experience without validating it Makes it easier to move the client toward seeing that the other person has their unique experience, which is 'true' for that person Family Functioning: Role of symptom Family dynamics (power struggles, parental conflict, lack of validation/intimacy) Family Roles (Martyr, Victim, Rescuer, Good/Bad Parent/Child)
Family Life Chronology Survival Triad Assess Individual Functioning Survival Stances 6 Levels of Experience Self-Worth/Esteem Mind-Body Connection

Family Life Chronology Timeline of key events: Birth Death Moves School Job Changes
Survival Triad Each Child + Mother + Father Levels are likened to an iceberg Behavior is the only visible layer Other 5 layers unseen beneath the surface
The Iceberg Model: Used to help individuals understand their intrapsychic experience Used for couples to understand how the levels of each person's experience resonate with the other Behavior External manifestation of the person's inner world Coping
Defenses and survival stances (Placating (Placator); Blaming (Blamer); Super-Reasonable (Computer); Irrelevant (Distractor)) Feelings Present feelings that are strongly past based Using past events to interpret the present Perceptions Beliefs, attitudes, and values that inform one's sense of self Expectations Strong belief about how life should go, how people should behave, and how one should perform Yearnings Universal longings to be loved, accepted, validated, and confirmed Satir always assessed a person's level of self-esteem More useful to consider: Aspects of the self that a client values Aspects of which client are ashamed Research indicates that self-compassion, or acceptance of one's strengths and weaknesses, is a better indicator of happiness than self-esteem. As self-compassion and self-worth rise, people become more realistic and tolerant of their own and others' weaknesses Mind-Body Connection How emotional issues may manifest in the body, either symbolically or functionally Also assess the role of nutrition and exercise Example: If a person is feeling burdened, this emotional feeling may manifest symbolically as stooped shoulders. Satir maintained that the way the body is used indicates the person's communication stance
Congruent (Congruence) Communication: Open and relaxed body postures
Placating (Placator) Timid and reserved postures
Super-Reasonable (Computer): Cold and distant postures
Irrelevant (Distractor): Hyper and distracted Goal of Satir's model is transformation To achieve the optimal realization of a person's full potential Attention to individual goals reflects their humanistic foundations 2 broad sets of practical goals for treatment planning: Systemic/family goals Individual goals Relational Goal: Congruent communication Communicating authentically while responding to the needs of self and others Goal to help the family develop ways for members to communicate so the system's homeostasis does not need the symptoms Overarching individual goal is consistent with other humanistic approaches: To promote self-actualization Self-Actualization: Fulfilling one's potential and living an authentic and meaningful life. Specific Goal Example: Increase sense of self-worth and self-compassion Reduce defensiveness and use of survival stances Therapists' use of self Being authentically who they are is one of the most essential interventions in Satir's approach Creates a safe relationship in which clients can practice communicating congruently Ingredients of an interaction: Details the internal communication process Teaches clients about internal and relational processes Ingredient Questions: Used to help people better understand their interactions with others Can be used with individuals, couples, or families Walk the client through the ingredients of an interaction: What do I hear and see? What meanings do I make of what I hear and see? What feelings do I have about the meanings I make? What feelings do I have about these feelings? What defenses do I use? What rules for commenting do I use? What is my response to the situation? Facilitating Emotional Expression Help put difficult emotions into words Naming emotions Locating in body Metaphor Coaching clients in how to have congruent communication in session May involve the 'ingredients of an interaction' with specific coaching strategies Satir's most distinctive intervention Done either with the family or in a group setting Puts family members in physical positions that represent how the 'sculptor' sees each person's role in the family Bypassing Denial/Resistance: Sculpting is a highly effective nonverbal confrontation that bypasses cognitive defenses Satir used touch in therapy to: Connect with clients Encourage and reassure clients when they were practicing new ways of communicating In today's environment: Touching less common because it can easily be misinterpreted as harassment Carefully consider trauma history, culture, gender, legal/ethical issues of using touch Coaching clients to touch each other Experiential therapies can be challenging online. Require attending to emotions and affect, which are communicated non-verbally Requires Using more verbal communication to make up for the loss of non-verbal communication Adapting non-verbal communication Sculpting: With drawings View whole Experiential approaches value: Clear, congruent, emotional expression Willingness to be vulnerable Cautions Cultural Gender Social Class/Educational Norms for emotional expression vary tremendously May initially be too threatening for clients hwo have been mandated to receive treatment. Theory: Describe the following elements of the Satir model and emotionally focused therapy: Process of therapy Therapeutic relationship Case conceptualization Goal setting Interventions Case Conceptualization and Treatment Plan Complete a theory-specific case conceptualizations and treatment plans for Satir family therapy and emotionally focused couples therapy using templates that are provided. Research Provide an overview of significant research findings for Satir family therapy and emotionally focused couples therapy. Diversity Analyze strengths, limitations, and appropriate applications for using experiential approaches with clients in relation to their social location/diverse identities, including but not limited to ethnic, racial, and/or sexual/gender identity diversity. Cross-Theoretical Comparison Compare how experiential therapies utilize interpersonal patterns (IPs) with other approaches described in this book. Integrating systemic theory with humanism, experiential family therapists are noted for their warmth and direct emotional engagement with clients. These approaches include: The Satir Model
Emotionally Focused Therapy (EFT) EFT integrates experiential, systemic, and attachment theories to help couples and families create emotional safety to foster wellness interaction patterns.
Symbolic-Experiential Family Therapy
Carl Whitaker developed symbolic-experiential therapy, which focuses on symbolic meanings and emotional exchanges within the family using a balance of warmth and confrontation to promote change. Whereas systemic, strategic, structural, and cognitive-behavioral family therapists primarily track behavior interaction sequences, experiential family therapists focus more on the affective or emotional layer of those same interactions - while still attending to behavior and cognitions. Assessment and interventions target the emotional exchanges between family members and significant others in relation to the presenting problem. Experiential family therapists use warmth and empathy in building relationships with clients. Therapists use themselves - their personhood - to make this strong affective connection with clients. This approach creates a sense of safety that allows clients to explore areas of emotional vulnerability. Experiential family therapies affress individual and family concerns as distinct sets of problems. In contrast, systemic, structural, and integenerational therapies conceptualize individual systems as part of the family system. They assume that individual symptoms will resolve if the family system is treated.
She began her career in family therapy at the Mental Research Institute (MRI) working alongside Jay Haley, Paul Watzlawick, Richard Fisch, and the other leading family therapists in Palo Alto. Her therapy focused on fostering individual growth as well as improving family interactions.
The Communication Stances in the Satir model offer a clinician an efficient and effect means of conceptualizing how best to communicate and interact with the client. She describes 4 communication survival or coping stances:
Blaming (Blamer)
Placating (Placator)
Super-Reasonable (Computer)
Irrelevant (Distractor) These stances develop in childhoodand reveal how a person communicates under stress, especially when they do not feel emotionally safe in intimate relationships. A person can use more than one, but typically a person uses one style predominantly. Each stance acknowledges or minimizes three basic realities: Self Other Context
The goal is to move people toward Congruent (Congruence) communication in which they respectfully balance the needs of self and others while responding appropriately within and acknowledging the context .
Each survival stance minimizes one or more essential part of the total picture.
Because placatory have people-pleasing tendencies, therapists use less directive therapy methods, such as multiple choice questions and open-ended reflections, to require them to voice their opinion and take a stand. Therapists should carefully avoid giving opinions, making it seem that they have an opinion, or offering too much personal information. Clients will use this type of information to know what parts of themselves to hide and what parts to foreground to gain therapist approval. Research indicates that some clients make up things to give the impression that therapy is progressing. Not until the placator regularly and openly disagrees with the therapist has rapport been established.
Therapists can best connect with those who blame through addressing their expectations. The goal often is to increase blamers' awareness of others' thoughts and feelings and help them learn how to communicate their personal perspectives in ways that are respectful of others. With these clients, direct confrontation often strengthens the therapeutic relationship. Blamers generally prefer more upfront and direct communication than is generally tolerated in polite society.
When working with those who use a super-reasonable stance, logic and rules reign supreme. Since these clients avoid all emotions, therapists might best engage them by starting with their bodily reactions and expectations before moving onto feelings. The goal with this stance is to help clients value the internal, subjective realities of themselves and others.
A client with the irrelevant stance creates a unique challenge for therapists because there is no consistent grounding in self, other, or context for the therapist to use in understanding and communicating with the client. The therapist must spend time 'floating' along with the client's distractions to identify the unique 'anchors' of the client's reality that the therapist can tap into. Bodily sensations, touch, and physical activities often work best with this client stance. As treatment progresses, the therapist works with these clients to increase their ability to recognize the thoughts and feelings of self and others and to acknowledge the demands of context. Progress is typically slower with those who use this stance frequently.
Virginia Satir She began her private practice in 1951, and by 1955, she was training therapists at the Illinois Psychiatric Institute to work with families. She then joined MRI in Palo Alto. 1962 was the year she received a grant from the NIMH that provided funding to establish the first family therapy training program.
Satir uses a six-stage model of change that is based on research on Cybernetics systems conducted by Satir while at the MRI.
Her six-stage model describes how the therapy process helps families move toward a Second-Order Change in the family structure. The model emphasizes that the therapist perturbs the system (Shaking it up and respecting its ability to naturally reorganize itself in a more useful way) rather than attempting to direct and control the system from the outside. Even though Satir uses education and coaches clients on how to better communicate, the aim is not for clients to follow her instructions literally but rather to adapt and respond to the instructions in a way that works for their system. The six-stages:
Status Quo This is a state of homeostasis that includes at least one symptomatic member.
Foreign Element May be a life crisis, tragedy, or therapeutic intervention, gets the system off balance.
Chaos
The new perspective creates a Positive Feedback loop that throws the system into a state of chaos. At this point, the 'natural' response is to feel uncomfortable, and in almost all cases the family tries to regain the Status Quo, which may or may not be possible.
Integration of New Possibilities Eventually, the family system interprets the new information in a meaningful way; the therapist needs to be respectful of how the system uses the information and responds to therapist-client interactions, honoring and trusting the system's autonomy. Practice The system develops a new set of interaction patterns based on the new information. This may or may not look like what the therapist expects, but the therapist asks two key evaluative questions: Are the symptoms improving? Is each person able to self-actualize and grow? New Status Quo This is a state of new homeostasis that does not include a symptomatic member and that allows all members to grow and flourish. Therapy involves going through these 6 stages several times, with the discomfort and relative sense of chaos diminishing each time the client cycles through, becoming increasingly comfortable with change. Four primary assumptions about people and therapy: People naturally tend toward positive growth (humanistic principle). All people possess the resources for positive growth (humanistic principle). Every person and every thing or situation impacts and is impacted by everyone and everything else (systemic principle) Therapy is a process that involves interaction between a therapist and a client. In this relationship, each person is responsible for themselves (systemic and humanistic principle). These assumptions clarify the therapist's role in the process (the therapist is 'responsible for themself'), but also how the therapist believes the therapeutic process works: Clients already possess the natural inclination toward growth and the resources for it, and it is the therapist's job to activate these tendencies. The role of the therapist is that of a guide to the process of becoming more fully human. Carl Rogers, a leader in humanistic, experiential therapies, based his client-centered approach on three therapist qualities:
Congruent (Congruence) or Genuineness
Accurate Empathy Unconditional Positive Regard These conditions are the theoretical foundations of warmth and humanity. This quality of being, or therapeutic presnce, is difficult to define, and there are methods for systematically developing it.
The more therapists are Congruent (Congruence) - that is being able to communicate authentically while responding to the needs of both self and others - the better they can create the therapeutic warmth and humanity. Satir describes establishing a therapeutic relationship as 'making contact,' which refers to a series of connection both within the therapist and between the therapist and client.
Making contact begins with the therapist being in contact with themselves, including all resources of the self as defined in the Self-Mandala: physical, intellectual, emotional, sensual, interactional, nutritional, contextual, and spiritual. The therapist also prepares to meet another 'miracle,' a fellow human being. The therapist then works to make contact with each client in the room, engaging them on 'all channels': Mind Body Spirit Open body position and congruent communication are critical. Once the therapist has made contact with each person, the therapist works to help family members make contact with each other and ultimately with others in their broader social system. The therapy process cannot move forward until the therapist has made contact with the client. When contact is made, clients feel valued for who they are, regardless of their problem, and they feel free to make mistakes in the therapist's presence. Making contact involves: Making direct eye contact Touching clients (e.g., shaking hands) Sitting or standing at the same physical level so that eye contact is easy (i.e., leaning down to talk with children) Asking each person's name and how he or she prefers to be called
Satir practitioners convey their understanding of clients' subjective, inner realities by expressing Empathy, an accurate understanding of another's emotional reality. Clients like therapists who take their side, don't confront them, and ignore their responsibility in the problem situation. This type of validation is detrimental to therapeutic progress. Comments that imply a client has a right to feel a certain way can also shut down the process of reflecting on the client's responsibility for their half of an interaction. Expressing empathy emphasizes that is not wrong or right, not normal or abnormal, to feel a certain way - it is simply how the client feels and means that this is their 'truth,' at least for the moment (e.g., "It sounds as though you felt betrayed") Honoring the client's unique experience without validating it as right or normal makes it much easier to move the client toward seeing that the other person has their unique experience that is also 'true' for that person, creating a context from which to understand how these two (or more) realities may collide and create problematic interactions. In joining with clients, therapists instill hope that they can change and that the situation can be better, even if it seems hopeless at the moment. Satir et al., (1991) emphasize that clients must have faith that change is possible before they can move forward with treatment. Clients need to believe that therapy and their therapist can help them resolve their problems. Therapists establish credibility by making a personal connection (making contact) and by being confident and competent (modeling high self-esteem). Both family functioning and individual functioning are assessed.
Role of the Symptom in the System
Describe how the symptom maintains the family's homeostasis at an emotional level, often regulating closeness and distance (Distance Regulation; Differentiation of Self) Family Dynamics Identify salient dynamics Power struggles Parental conflict Lack of validation Lack of intimacy Family Roles Identify possible family roles.
Martyr
Victim or Helpless One
Rescuer
Good Child or Parent
Bad Child or Parent
Family Life Chronology Describe key historical events, deaths, births, divorces, major life changes.
Survival Triad Describe the emotional and nurturing relationships between each child and parents.
Communication Stances Identify the survival stance of each person in the system
Placating (Placator)
Blaming (Blamer)
Super-Reasonable (Computer)
Irrelevant (Distractor)
Congruent (Congruence)
Six Levels of Experience
Iceberg Model For symptomatic behavior, describe: Behavior Coping Feelings Perceptions Expectations Yearnings
Self-Esteem or Self-Worth Describe each person's level of self-worth.
Mind-Body Connection Satir viewed the symptom as having a role in the family system. Symptoms always have an emotional function in the family system, even if they are consciously and logically unwanted. Why is this particular symptom manifesting in this particular family (or relationship)? If the therapist can understand how the symptom makes emotional sense in the family dance, it will be easier to help the family find ways to interact successfully without the need for the symptom. Along with assessing family roles, identify problematic family dynamics: Power Struggles These can be within the family and couple or with extended family members. Parental Conflicts These can involve parents disagreeing about how to parent and care for children. Lack of Validation The family openly expresses little emotional support or validation. Lack of Intimacy There is minimal sharing of significant personal information and one's emotional life. Satir assessed each person's role in the family system to understand the function of the problem. Possible roles include:
Martyr
Victim or Helpless One
Rescuer
Good Child or Parent
Bad Child or Parent The family life chronology is a timeline that includes the major events in an individual's or family's life. Births and deaths Important family events (i.e., marriages, moves, tragedies, major illnesses, job loss) Important historical events (i.e., wars, natural disasters, economic downturns) This chronology gives both the therapist and the client a 'big picture' view of the context for the potential problem and provides clues as to what old wounds may be fueling the current problems, as well as what potential strengths and resources might exist. Another area for assessment is the survival triad - the child, mother, and father - and the quality of the relationship between all three. Satir asserted that it was in this primary triad that a child learns how to be human. Is there an emotional bond between each parent and the child, or do the parents have significantly different levels of connection with the child? Because the survival triad should serve as a nurturing system for the child, when the child is experiencing difficulty, the therapist considers how the nurturing function of these relationships can be improved. One of Satir's last theoretical developments and central focus of contemporary work was the six levels of experience. Satir use these to help clients transform their feelings about feelings to make lasting change. These levels are likened to an iceberg, with the behavior the only visible layer and the other five layers unseen beneath the surface. At any moment, all six aspects are in play, but often we are not conscious of most of them. The iceberg model is used to help individuals better understand their intrapsychic experience and for couples to understand how the levels of each person's experience resonates with the other. Contemporary Satir practitioners help clients achieve intrapsychic congruence by identifying contradictions between these layers, such as taking actions one does not ultimately believe in. The six layers of the iceberg: Behavior The behavior on the surface; the external manifestations of the person's inner world. Coping
Defenses and Communication Stances:
Placating (Placator)
Blaming (Blamer)
Super-Reasonable (Computer)
Irrelevant (Distractor) These come out in times of stress, and a person may use different stances in different relational contexts. Feelings Present feelings that are strongly past-based, using past events to interpret the present. Contemporary practitioners also ask about a person's feelings about their feelings, which invites clients to relate to their feelings differently. Perceptions Beliefs, attitudes, and values that inform one's sense of self (most people form their perceptions when very young, and they are based on a limited view of reality). Expectation A strong belief about how life should go, how people should behave, and how one should perform (most people form their expectations when young, and they are often unrealistic and/or may not apply to a particular situation). Yearnings Universal longings to be loved, accepted, validated, and confirmed. This level closely parallels the emphasis on secure attachment emotionally focused therapy. Satir practitioners use the six levels of experience to assess the motivation behind problematic behaviors and interactions. By understanding the yearnings as well as perceptions and expectations that fuel problematic behavior, coping, and feelings, therapists are able to help clients transform their feelings about their feelings (for example, being embarrassed about feeling angry) to more effectively meet the underlying longing for love and acceptance. It is more useful to consider the specific aspects of the self that a client values and the aspects of which he or she is ashamed.
More recent research on self-esteem indicates that Self-Compassion self-compassion, or acceptance of one's strengths and weaknesses, is a better indicator of happiness than self-esteem, which can be artificially high. People who overestimate their abilities and worth often have high self-esteem but significant problems in their interpersonal and work or school relationships because they have unrealistic expectations of 'what is due to them.' The best indicator of health, self-compassion is one's ability to accept strengths and weaknesses are almost always equally harsh on themselves. Conversely, those who are hard on themselves are almost always equally harsh on others, even if it is not verbalized. As self-compassion and self-worth rise, people become more realistic and tolerant of their own and others' weaknesses while realistically assigning and assuming responsibility for their actions. The mind-body connection considers how emotional issues may manifest in the body, either symbolically or functionally. The role of nutrition and exercise is assessed.
Satir maintained that the way the body is used indicates the person's Communication Stances :
Congruent (Congruence) Communication and Self-Esteem or Self-Worth Open and relaxed body postures
Placating (Placator) Timid and reserved postures
Blaming (Blamer) Pointing, angry, and stiff postures
Super-Reasonable (Computer) Cold and distant postures
Irrelevant (Distractor) Hyper and distracted The goal of Satir's model is transformation: To achieve optimal realization of a person's full potential. This goal translates into two broad sets of practical goals for treatment planning: Relational, family, or systemic goals Individual goals The heart of relational goals in Satir's approach is congruent communication: The ability to communicate authentically while responding to the needs of both self and others. The goal is to help the family develop ways for all members to communicate so that the system's homeostasis no longer needs the initial symptoms (problems) to maintain balance. Increase congruent communication in relationships with spouse, parent, child, etc. Change family rules and shoulds to general guidelines. The overarching individual goal is consistent with other humanistic approaches: To promote the self-actualization of all members of the system. Therapists' use of self - being authentically who they are - is one of the most essential interventions. By being authentic, therapists provide a role model for how to communicate congruently and also show the effects of increased self-actualization. The use of the therapist's self in therapy, which may include self-disclosure, creates a safe relationship in which clients can practice communicating congruently without negative consequences and learn to tap into more authentic modes of expression.

item.title: Super-Reasonable (Computer)
item.description: In Satir's Growth Model (Human Validation Process Movement), one of the four survival stances to help people temporarily deal with presumed threats and protect their self-worth. The stances help to protect us, but do not help us or other people to grow and thrive. Privileges the context and discounts the self and others. Focuses on the rules rather than on emotions and relationships. Very data driven and people appreciate them for their intellect. To offset their internal vulnerability, the super-reasonable person doesn't allow themselves to connect with any emotions. This can lead to a rigidness that may be displayed via obsessive-compulsive behaviors. Acknowledge context Minimizes feelings/needs of self and others Prioritize a system of 'logic' (could be rational logic, religion doctrine, etc.) Therapeutic Implications: Reference and respect system of logic Help clients to also consider internal, subjective realities of self and others Might engage by starting with their bodily reactions, expectations, practical realities Privileges the context and discounts the self and others. Focuses on the rules rather than on emotions and relationships. Very data driven and people appreciate them for their intellect. To offset their internal vulnerability, the super-reasonable person doesn't allow themselves to connect with any emotions. This can lead to a rigidness that may be displayed via obsessive-compulsive behaviors. When working with those who use a super-reasonable stance, logic and rules reign supreme. Since these clients avoid all emotions, therapists might best engage them by starting with their bodily reactions and expectations before moving onto feelings. The goal with this stance is to help clients value the internal, subjective realities of themselves and others.

item.title: Irrelevant (Distractor)
item.description: In Satir's Growth Model (Human Validation Process Movement), one of the four survival stances to help people temporarily deal with presumed threats and protect their self-worth. The stances help to protect us, but do not help us or other people to grow and thrive. Discounts self, other, and context. Engage in distraction to avoid having to deal with their low self-esteem. People may describe them as fun and spontaneous. However, you cannot have a serious or straightforward conversation with them. This leads to a psychological orientation of confusion and possible psychosis. Avoidance No consistent grounding in self, other, or context Associated with most severe pathology Therapeutic Implications: Creates significant challenge for therapist Identify the unique 'anchors' of the client's reality Make the therapeutic relationship a place of upmost safety; less need for distracting communication Increase client's ability to recognize the thoughts and feelings of self and others Acknowledge the demands of context A client with the irrelevant stance creates a unique challenge for therapists because there is no consistent grounding in self, other, or context for the therapist to use in understanding and communicating with the client. The therapist must spend time 'floating' along with the client's distractions to identify the unique 'anchors' of the client's reality that the therapist can tap into. Bodily sensations, touch, and physical activities often work best with this client stance. As treatment progresses, the therapist works with these clients to increase their ability to recognize the thoughts and feelings of self and others and to acknowledge the demands of context. Progress is typically slower with those who use this stance frequently.

item.title: Family Life Chronology
item.description:
An exploration of a person's family, usually entailing three generations (similar to a genogram) Satir's Growth Model (Human Validation Process Movement) The family life chronology is a timeline that includes the major events in an individual's or family's life. Births and deaths Important family events (i.e., marriages, moves, tragedies, major illnesses, job loss) Important historical events (i.e., wars, natural disasters, economic downturns)
This chronology gives both the therapist and the client a 'big picture' view of the context for the potential problem and provides clues as to what old wounds may be fueling the current problems, as well as what potential strengths and resources might exist. (Research Citations/Books/@gehartMasteringCompetenciesFamily2017)

item.title: Blaming (Blamer)
item.description: In Satir's Growth Model (Human Validation Process Movement), one of the four survival stances to help people temporarily deal with presumed threats and protect their self-worth. The stances help to protect us, but do not help us or other people to grow and thrive. Privileges self and context while discounting the other. To cope with low self-esteem, the person attacks another individual. On the outside the individual seems assertive, but on the inside feel isolated and alone. Their experience leads them to sometimes feel paranoid and even potentially homicidal. Assert their needs and desires while minimizing those of others. You will find placator and blamer married in therapy because their stances are complimentary. Your job as a therapist is to help blamer to learn how to acknowledge and develop empathy for the thoughts and needs of others. Needs to increase awareness of others' thoughts and feelings Direct confrontation often strengthens therapeutic relationship (they will find placators as weak) Acknowledge Self/Context Minimize other Best connect with those who blame by addressing their expectations Therapeutic Implications: Generally prefer more upfront and direct communication Increase blamers' awareness of others' feelings Learn how to communicate in ways that are respectful of others Direct confrontation often strengthens the therapeutic relationship Therapists can best connect with those who blame through addressing their expectations. The goal often is to increase blamers' awareness of others' thoughts and feelings and help them learn how to communicate their personal perspectives in ways that are respectful of others. With these clients, direct confrontation often strengthens the therapeutic relationship. Blamers generally prefer more upfront and direct communication than is generally tolerated in polite society.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Experiential Family Therapy/Satir/Key Terms and Concepts/Blaming (Blamer).md
