item.title: Lecture on (CBT) Cognitive-Behavioral Family Therapy
item.description:
Read Nichols & Davis (Chapter 9) Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019
@dattilioIntroductionSpecialSection2005
@epsteinCognitiveBehaviorTherapiesCouples2014
IBCT – Integrative Behavioral Couple Therapy
Our Relationship®
The Gottman Institute | A research-based approach to relationships Behavior therapists first began working with families in the 1970s. Was limited in its approach to families because it often did not consider the complicated nature of family systems. Based on learning theories; was aimed at parent training and couple communication. The approach is now making changes to be more adaptive to the: Complex systems imbedded in families Classical Conditioning: Unconditioned Stimulus (UCS) Food Unconditioned Response (UCR) Salivation Conditioned Stimulus (CS) Ringing Bell Systematic Desensitization De-conditions anxiety through reciprocal inhibition. Operant Conditioning: Responses that are positively reinforced will be repeated more frequently Behaviors that are punished or ignored will be reduced or extinguished
Developed behavioral parent training Behavioral approaches to couple and family therapy Introduced cognitive elements into behavioral therapy. Cognitive triangle: Thoughts -> feelings -> behaviors -> thoughts Behavior is maintained by its consequences. Behavior problems are caused by: Dysfunctional patterns of reinforcement between parents and children. Behavior will remain resistant to change until more rewarding consequences are introduced.
Social Exchange Theory: People strive to maximize rewards and minimize costs in relationships. Cognitive theorists emphasized the need for attitude changes to: Promote and maintain behavior change. Behavioral approaches are typically limited to two party relationships: Parent/child, spouses. Fail to take into account the triadic nature of relationships. Cognitive techniques became more prominent as behavior therapists realized: An exclusive focus on behavior often failed to address the complicated dynamics of couple and family interaction. CBT/CBFT is a highly efficacious intervention to assist families in a variety of contexts (this model has empirical support) CBT has focused on family's cognitive processing and behavioral interactions, while minimizing the influences of individual differences between family members. CBT also addresses characteristics that each family member brings to their relationships, explaining why family members behave and interpret events in maladaptive ways. Healthy families are those in which positive behaviors are maintained by: Appropriate consequences Negative behaviors are extinguished through the use of punishment Healthy families have high rations of benefits to costs (Philippines, there is no such thing as divorce) Healthy couples will be able to engage in: Effective communication skills, problem-solving skills, and conflict resolution. Healthy families and couples could adapt, be flexible, and change. Behavioral Family Therapy: Symptoms are viewed as learned responses. For behavioral therapists, no underlying meanings of symptoms are sought. Attention is focused on the symptoms themselves and the environmental responses that reinforce behavior. Cognitive behavioral therapists will include ideas about dysfunctional schemas: Regarding family roles and relationships that are learned in one's family-of-origin, Cognitive Distortions: Arbitrary Inference: Conclusions are drawn in the absence of supporting evidence. Selective Abstraction: Certain details are highlighted while other important information is ignored. Overgeneralization: Isolated incidents are taken as general patterns. Magnification and Minimization: The significance of events is unrealistically magnified or diminished. Personalization: Events are arbitrarily interpreted in reference to oneself. Dichotomous Thinking: Experiences are interpreted as all good or all bad. Labeling and Mislabeling: Behavior is attributed to undesirable personality traits. Mind Reading: This is the magical gift of knowing what other people are thinking about without the aid of verbal communication. Behavior and cognitive changes in the way one behaves toward/thinks about family. Increase the rate of rewarding interactions in family relationships. Decrease the use of negative family interactions; increase positive interaction. Teach effective communication and problem-solving skills. Alter negative thought patterns; promoted or maintain ineffective family interactions. Behavior will change when the contingencies of reinforcement are altered. Identify behavioral goals. Learn techniques to achieve these goals. Facilitate social reinforcement of change. A hallmark of behavioral therapy. Families and couples - questionnaires and home observations are conducted. For sex therapy, clinical interviews are the main assessment tool. Treatment goals are set based on results of assessment. 2-4 sessions (About 1.5-2 hours each) Main Point: To gather information as much as possible at the beginning to form treatment plan. Each person takes turn to respond. Gather information, perspective-taking and avoid escalation. Information Gathering: Self-report questionnaires, clinical interviews, observation of interactional patterns. Initial Conjoint Interviews (Couple): CBCT: How the couple met, what attracted them to each other, how they developed a deeper involvement, positive and negative life events, prior experiences in therapy. Initial Conjoint Interviews (Families): Inquired about the family members' current concerns and strengths of the relationship. Orients the family to the process of therapy by describing the structure and course of CBFT and the roles of therapist and family. Individual family members vary in the extent to which they have a clear understanding of the factors affecting their relationships and clear goals for treatment, and how their own contributions affect the achievement of their goals. Therapist determines the appropriate sequence of addressing goals in therapy. Extinguish undesired behavior and reinforce positive alternatives. Ignoring the tantrum; rewarding the child for putting feelings into words. Redefine the family's goals of decreasing negative behavior into increasing positive responses. Families have difficulty describing the behavior they want to see more of. The therapist helps by asking families to make a list of things the other person did that they liked throughout the week. Reviewing the list in session the next week provides an opportunity to emphasize the importance of positive feedback The agenda of therapy is educational. Teach communication, problem-solving, and negotiation. Didactic role early on to strike a balance between directiveness and collaboration. Reviews homework assignments, models skills, coaches family members in practicing them, and fosters motivation. Balances alliances and interventions with all the family members or subsystems, so that they feel supported and remain equally invested in improving relationships. Directive Role of the Therapist: Sets the pace of sessions so that the goals of treatment are addressed in a timely and sequential fashion. Sets the agenda each session. Monitors the use of time. Responsible to stay on task and address the goals of session. Teaches the clients to self-monitor as well. Maintains control of the session with confidence and credibility. Assumes multiple roles: Director, educator, facilitator, collaborator, advocate Balances the alliance and interventions with all members, so they feel supported and invested. Collaborate with families in designing homework to complete between sessions. Homework is based on the learning principle that to replace existing ingrained dysfunctional interaction patterns with new ones, families need to rehearse the new patterns repeatedly, particularly under 'real life conditions.' Couples are taught to express themselves in clear, behavioral descriptions, rather than in vague complaints. Couples are taught new behavior exchange procedures, emphasizing positive reinforcement. Couples are helped to improve their communication. Couples are encouraged to establish clear and effective decision-making. Couples are taught strategies to problem-solve future complaints to extend the benefits of therapy. Ask each partner to list three things they would like the other to do more often. Imagery Roleplay Coaching (to switch places, to increase their empathy for one another's feelings) Communication training: For example, engaging in an argument without attacking, 'I-statements', and Speaker/Listener exercises Problem-solving training Homework Assignments Mindfulness and Meditation Parents have control over the rewards and punishment of children. If parents change the contingencies of reinforcement, the child's behavior will change. Skills are taught in sequence (shaping). Help parents define the child's positive and problematic behaviors in specific observable actions. Tracking target behaviors. Reinforcing desired behavior through contingent encouragement with incentive charts. Disciplinary techniques include time out, ignoring problem behavior. Observe/Assess the frequency of problem behavior, what precedes it, and what reinforcement follows (Behavior Chaining) Shaping (reinforcing small steps toward change) Token economies (reward good behavior) Contingency contracting (agreements by parents to make certain changes following changes made by their child) Time out

item.title: Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (CBT)
item.description:
Treatment that emphasizes attitude change as well as reinforcement of behavior. Aversion Control Using punishment and criticism to eliminate undesirable responses; commonly used in dysfunctional families.
Behavior Exchange Theory Explanation of behavior in relationships as maintained by a ratio of costs to benefits.
Classical Conditioning
A form of respondent learning in which an unconditioned stimulus (UCS), such as food, which leads to an unconditioned response (UCR), such as salivation, is paired with a conditioned stimulus (CS), such as a bell, the result of which is that the CS begins to evoke the same response; used in the behavioral treatment of anxiety disorders.
Contingency Contracting A behavior therapy technique whereby agreements are made between family members to exchange rewards for desired behavior.
Contingency Management Shaping behavior by giving and taking away rewards.
Functional Analysis of Behavior In operant behavior therapy, a study of a particular behavior, what elicits it, and what reinforces it.
Operant Conditioning A form of learning whereby an individual or animal is rewarded for performing certain behaviors; the major approach in most forms of behavior therapy.
Premack Principle Using high-probability behavior (preferred activities) to reinforce low-probability behavior (nonpreferred activities).
Reinforcement An event, behavior, or object that increases the rate of a particular response. A positive reinforcer is an event whose contingent presentation increases the rate of responding; a negative reinforcer is an event who contingent withdrawal increases the rate of responding.
Reinforcement Reciprocity Exchanging rewarding behaviors between family members.
Schemas Underlying core beliefs that an individual has developed about the world and how it functions.
Shaping Reinforcing change in small steps.
Social Exchange Theory Thibaut and Kelley's theory according to which people strive to maximize rewards and minimize costs in a relationship.
Time-Out A behavioral technique for extinguishing undesirable behavior by removing the reinforcing consequences of that behavior; typically, making the child sit in a corner or go to their room.
Token Economy A system of rewards using points, which can be accumulated and exchanged for reinforcing items or behaviors. When they first began working with families, behavior therapists applied learning theory to train parents in behavior modification and teach communication skills to couples.
The early principles of behavior therapy were developed by two key figures: Joseph Wolpe and B. F. Skinner. In 1948, Wolpe introduced systematic desensitization. Systematic desensitization deconditions anxiety through reciprocal inhibition by pairing responses incompatible with anxiety to previously anxiety-arousing stimuli.
Skinner's Operant Conditioning: Behavior is regulated by its consequences. Responses that are positively reinforced will be increased; those that are punished or ignored will be extinguished. The operant conditioner carefully observes target behavior and quantifies its frequency and rate. Then, to complete a functional analysis of behavior, the consequences of the behavior are noted to determine the contingencies of reinforcement. Operant conditioning is particularly effective with children because parents have control over their rewards and punishment. Gerald Patterson, at the Oregon Social Learning Center pioneered behavioral parent training. Patterson's treatment was based on the premise that if parents change their contingencies of reinforcement, then their children's behavior will change.
Shaping: Skills taught in sequence. Teach parents to reinforce prosocial behavior through contingent encouragement with incentive charts. This process also promotes positive relationships between parents and children. Children earn rewards while they learn prosocial skills, and in the process, their self-esteem grows with their success and their parents' positive attention.
Gerald Patterson: Took the lead in introducing disciplinary techniques, such as time-out, because he discovered that ignoring the problem behavior is not always sufficient, especially with aggressive children. During the 1970s, behavioral and emotional responses, along with the interpersonal transactions that occur within their family, social, vocational, political, and culture networks.
Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (CBT): Refers to those approaches inspired by the work of Albert Ellis (1962) and Aaron Beck (1976) that emphasize the need for attitude change to promote behavior modification. According to the cognitive mediation model, emotions and actions are mediated by specific cognitions. Understanding these cognitions (beliefs, attributions, and expectancies) makes it possible to identify factors that trigger dysfunctional emotional and behavioral patterns. This boils down to uncovering hidden assumptions that keep people stuck. Rational-emotive therapists help family members see how illogical beliefs serve as the foundation for their emotional distress. According to the A-B-C Theory, family members blame their problems on certain events in the family (a) and are taught to look for irrational beliefs (b), which are then challenged (c). The therapist's role is to teach the family how emotional problems are caused by unrealistic beliefs and that by revising these self-defeating ideas, they may improve the quality of family life. Cognitions, emotions, and behavior are seen as exerting mutual influence on one another, so that a cognitive inference can evoke emotion and behavior, and emotion and behavior can influence cognition. The late 1980 s and early 1990 s saw the cognitive behavior approach applied more widely in family therapy. Edited books by Epstein, Schlesinger, and Dryden (1988) and a short text by Huber and Baruth (1989) were among the first works to address the cognitive approach to family therapy. This was elaborated in subsequent articles by Schwebel and Fine (1992), Dattilio (1994, 1997), and Teichman (1992). Dattilio (1998) produced a major casebook that discusses the integration of cognitive-behavioral strategies with various modalities of couples and family therapy, as well as a comprehensive textbook describing the cognitive-behavioral approach (Dattilio, 2010). Among the leaders in cognitive-behavioral family therapy are Donald Baucom at the University of North Carolina, Norman Epstein at the University of Maryland, and Frank Dattilio at Harvard Medical School and the University of Pennsylvania. The basic premise of behaviorism is that behavior is maintained by its consequences. Consequences that increase behavior are reinforcers; those that decrease behavior are punishers. Some responses may not be recognized as operants - something done to get something - because people aren't away of the reinforcing payoffs.
Thibaut and Kelley's (1959) Social Exchange Theory, according to which people strive to maximize rewards and minimize costs in relationships. In a successful relationship, partners work to maximize mutual rewards. In successful relationships from getting hurt to consider how to make each other happy. Integrate stimulus-response behaviorism with cognitive theories. The central tenet of the cognitive approach is that our interpretation of other people's behavior affects the way we respond to them.
Among the most troublesome of automatic thoughts are those based on arbitrary inference, distorted conclusions, shaped by a person's Schemas, or core beliefs. What makes these underlying beliefs problematic is that although they are generally conscious, they bias how we respond to everything and everyone. Hidden assumptions have a potent impact on how people perceive and react to each other.
Behavior Exchange Theory: A good relationship is one in which giving and getting are balanced - or, in the model's terms, there is a high ratio of benefits to costs. Thus it is the balance of costs and rewards that determines family satisfaction. Weiss and Isaac (1978) found that affection, communication, and child care are the most important elements in marital satisfaction. Earlier, Wills, Weiss, and Patterson (1974) found that unpleasant behavior reduced marital satisfaction more than positive behavior increased it. Good relationships are under positive reinforcement control. A critical skill in maintaining family harmony is conflict resolution. Some people assume that good relationships will evolve naturally if people love each other. Behaviorists emphasize the need to develop relationship skills. Neil Jacobson (1981): Successful couples... Expand their reinforcement power by frequently acquiring new domains for positive exchange. Spouses who depend on a limited quantity and variety of reinforcers are bound to suffer the ill effects of satiation. As a result, over time their interaction becomes depleted of its prior reinforcement value. Successful couples cope with this inevitable reinforcement value. Successful couples cope with this inevitable reinforcement erosion by varying their shared activities, developing new common interests, expanding their sexual repertoires, and developing their communication to the point where they continue to interest one another. Behaviorists view symptoms as learned responses. They look for specific responses that reinforce problem behavior. People often aren't aware that they reinforce those responses that cause them the most distress. Attention is a powerful social reinforcer. The problem is most parents have trouble ignoring misbehavior. E.g. How quickly children learn that certain words get a big reaction. (some of these children grow up to become stand-up comedians) Even when parents try to ignore misbehavior, they usually don't do so consistently. This can make things worse, because intermittent reinforcement is the most resistant to extinction. Others persist because parents don't know how to make effective use of punishment. They make threats they don't follow through on; they punish too long after the fact; they use punishments so mild as to have no effect; or they use punishments so severe as to generate more anxiety than learning. A spiral of undesirable behavior is maintained by reciprocal reinforcement. Parents often unintentionally reinforce temper tantrums by giving in or merely by giving the tantruming child extra attention.
The use of Aversion Control - crying, nagging, withdrawing - is a major determinant of marital unhappiness. Spouses tend to reciprocate their partners' use of aversive behavior, and a viscous cycle develops. People in distressed relationships also show poor problem-solving skills. Most behavioral analyses point to a lack of reinforcement for positive behavior in distressed families. ('The squeaky wheel gets the grease') Depression, headaches, and tempter tantrums tend to elicit concern and therefore get more attention than pleasant behavior.
The schemas that plague relationships are learned in the process of growing up. These schemas are the basis of biased assumptions that poison relationships by distorting family members' responses to each other. The following are typical Cognitive Distortions cognitive distortions:
Arbitrary Inference: Conclusions are draw in the absence of supporting evidence. Example: A man whose wife arrives home late from work concludes, 'She must be having an affair.'
Selective Abstraction: Certain details are highlighted while other important information is ignored. Example: A woman whose husband fails to answer her greeting first thing in the morning concluded, "He must be angry at me again."
Overgeneralization: Isolated incidents are taken as general patterns. Example: After being turned down for a date, a young man decides that 'Women don't like me; I'll never get a date.'
Magnification and Minimization: The significance of events of unrealistically magnified or diminished. Example: A husband considers the two times in one month he shops for groceries as fulfilling his share of the household duties, while his wife thinks, 'He never does anything.'
Personalization: Events are arbitrarily interpreted in reference to oneself. Example: A teenagers wants to spend more time with his friends, so his father assumes his son doesn't enjoy his company.
Dichotomous Thinking: Experiences are interpreted as all good or all bad. Example: A couple has some good times and some bad times, but he remembers only the good times, while she remembers only the bad times.
Labeling and Mislabeling: Behavior is attributed to undesirable personality traits. Example: A woman who avoids talking with her mother about her career because her mother always criticizes is considered 'withholding.'
Mind Reading: This is the magical gift of knowing what other people are thinking without the aid of verbal communication. Example: A husband doesn't know asks his wife what she wants because he 'knows what's going on in her mind' Cognitive restructuring is useful to the extent that it leads to changed behavior, which can be reinforced. The general intent is to extinguish undesired behavior and reinforce positive alternatives. Soemtimes it may be necessary to redefine a family's goal of decreasing negative behavior in terms of increasing incompatible, positive responses. Most people have difficulty describing behavior they want their mates to accelerate. Cognitive-behavior therapy also has an educational agenda. Cognitive-behaviorists also teach communication, problem-solving, and negotiation skills. These therapists not only help clients reexamine distorted beliefs to solve specific complaints but also make an effort to teach families how to use cognitive strategies to resolve problems in the future. The basic premise of behavior therapy is that behavior will change when the contingencies of reinforcement are altered. Behavioral family therapy aims to resolve targeted family problems through identifying behavioral goals, learning theory techniques for achieving these goals, and social reinforcers to facilitate this process. The first task of the therapist is to observe the frequency of behavior as well as the stimulus conditions that precede it and the reinforcement that follows it. In addition to the reinforcing responses that immediately follow a specific behavior, more remote reinforcers also play a part. Behavior that is reinforced by peers may be difficult to modify at home. The primary approach in behavioral parent training is operant conditioning, where the reinforcers employed may be tangible or social. Praise and attention have been found to be as effective as money or candy. Operant techniques may be further divided into shaping, token economies, contingency contracting, contingency management, and time-out.
Shaping: Consists of reinforcing change in small steps.
Token Economy: Use points to reward children for good behavior.
Contingency Contracting: Agreements by parents to make certain changes following changes made by their children.
Contingency Management: Giving and taking away rewards based on children's behavior.
Time-Out: Punishment where children are made to sit in the corner or sent to their rooms. Barton and Alexander call their approach functional family therapy Point out that members of unhappy families tend to attribute their problems to negative traits in others. Such negative attributions leave family members with a limited sense of control over their lives. Restructuring distorted beliefs is thought to play a pivotal role in changing dysfunctional behavior. Uncovering and reevaluating schemas, or core beliefs, of family members is thought to be essential in helping them modify emotions and interactions that surround problem behavior. Most assessments are based on Kanfer and Phillip's (1970) SORKC model of behavior. S for stimulus O for the state of the organism R for the target response KC for the contingency of consequences Applying the SORKC model is straightforward, but it quickly becomes more complex with families, in which there are long chains of interrelated behavior. Assessment in behavioral parent training entails observing and recording the frequency of the behavior to be changed, as well as the events that precede it and those that follow. Interviews, usually with the mother, are designed to provide a definition of the problem and a list of potential reinforcers. Observations may be conducted behind a one-way mirror or during home visits. Once the assessment is complete, the therapist decides which behaviors should be increased and which decreased.
To accelerate behavior, the Premack Principle is applied. High probability behavior (popular activities) is chosen to reinforce behavior with a low probability of occurrence. As the Premack principle demonstrates, to be effective, reinforcers must be popular with the child. Once effective rewards are chosen, parents are taught to shape desired behavior by reinforcing successive approximation to their goals. They are taught to raise the criteria for reinforcement gradually and to present reinforcement immediately after the desired behavior. Once a child is regularly performing the desired response, reinforcement becomes intermittent in order to increase the durability of the new behavior. The importance of immediate proximity is what makes time-out such an effective punishment and grounding such an ineffective one. Disciplinary techniques are usually instituted after the progress has been made in reinforcing positive behavior. For preadolescent children, the most widely used punishment is time-out.
Time-Out involves removal to a boring place for five minutes. Older children are sent to graduate school and required to sit through lectures. When a child refuses to go to time-out, parents are taught to add additional time, up to a 10-minute maximum. If the child continues to refuse, a privilege's is removed. Other techniques used to decelerate behavior include verbal reprimand and ignoring. Simply repeating commands to children is the most ineffective way to change their behavior. Chores are broken down into steps with points given for each step. Rewards include food treats, special time with a parent, household resources (e.g. computer or TV time), privileges, and toys. Rewards are changed reguarly to keep things interesting. Because of the inconvenience of reinforcing behavior immediately, token systems have been popular with parent trainers. Points are earned for desirable behavior and lost for undesireable behavior. Case Study: Ignore fits of temper whenever they occurred. If they occurred at bedtime, child was to be put to bed; if they continued to cry and fuss, they was to be left alone until they have stopped. Only when they stopped were their parents to talk with them about what was on her mind. The tantrums indeed decreased, except for one night when they took on a new and more troubling form. With teenagers, contingency contracting is more widely used. Contracting is introduced as a way for everybody in the family to get something by compromising. Parents and teenagers are asked to specify what behavior they'd like each other to change. These requests form the nucleus of an initial contract. In order to help family members arrive at contracts, the therapist encourages (1) clear communication of wishes and feelings, (2) clear presentation of requests, leading to (3) negotiation, with each person receiving something in exchange for some concession. The most widely used in the Locke-Wallace Marital Adjustment Scale, a 23-item questionnaire covering various aspects of marital satisfaction, including communication, sex, affection, social activities, and values. Assessments are designed to reveal strengths and weaknesses of a couple's relationship and the manner in which rewards and punishments are exchanged. Interviews and questionnaires are used to specify and elaborate target behaviors. Jacobson's (1981) Pretreatment Assessment for Marital Therapy: Strengths and skills of the relationship: What are the major strengths of this relationship? What behaviors on the part of each spouse are highly valued by the other? What shared activities does the couple currently engage in? Presenting Problems: What are the major complaints, and how do these complaints translate into explicit behavioral terms? What are the reinforcers maintaining these behaviors? What behaviors occur at less than the desired frequency or fail to occur at appropriate times from the standpoint of each spouse? What are the consequences of these behaviors currently, when they occur? Sex and Affection: Is either spouse currently dissatisfied with rate, quality, or diversity of sex life together? If sex is currently a problem, was there a time when it was mutually satisfying? What are the sexual behaviors that seem to be associated with current dissatisfaction? Are either or both partners dissatisfied with the amount or quality of nonsexual physical affection? Future Prospects: Are the partners seeking therapy to improve their relationship, to separate, or to decide whether the relationship is worth working on? What are each spouse's reasons for continuing the relationship despite the current problems? Assessment of Social Environment: What are each person's alternatives to the present relationship? How attractive are these alternatives to each person? Is the environment (parents, relatives, friends, work associates, children) supportive of either continuance or dissolution of present relationship? Individual Functioning of Each Spouse: Does either spouse exhibit emotional or behavioral problems? Have they been in therapy before, either alone or together? What kind of therapy? Outcome? What is each spouse's past experience with intimate relationships? How is the present relationship difference? Richard Stuart (1975) lists five strategies that summarize the behavioral approach to troubled marriages: Couples are taught to express themselves in a clear, behavior descriptions rather than in vague complaints. Couples are taught new behavior exchange procedures, emphasizing positive control in place of aversive control. Couples are helped to improve their communication. Couples are encouraged to establish clear and effective means of sharing power and making decisions. Couples are taught strategies for solving future problems as a means to maintain and extend gains initiated in therapy. Behavior exchange theory procedures are taught to increase the frequency of desired behavior. A typical device is to ask each partner to list three things they would like the other to do more often. Couples are implicitly learning ways of influencing each other through positive reinforcement. Stuart (1976) has couples alternate 'caring days,' where on partner demonstrates caring in as many ways as possible. Gottman and Krokoff (1989) found that arguments and angry exchanges, which have often been considered destructive to relationships, may not be harmful in the long run. These patterns were correlated with immediate dissatisfaction but were predictive of improved satisfaction after 3 years. Defensiveness, stubbornness, and withdrawal from conflict, on the other hand, did lead to long-term deterioration in marriages. Confrontation is effective only if it doesn't make the partner defensive. It isn't just honesty that counts but honesty expressed in a way the partner can tolerate. Training in communication skills may be done in a group format or with individual groups. Couples are taught to be specific, phrase requests in positive terms, respond directly to criticism instead of cross-complaining, talk about the present and future rather than the past, listen without interruption, minimize punitive statements, and eliminate questions that sound like declarations. Treatment that emphasizes attitude change as well as reinforcement of behavior.

item.title: Triangulation
item.description:
Detouring conflict between two people by involving a third person, stabilizing the relationship between the original pair. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
University Resources/Research Citations/M/@markScopingReviewPractice2020: Occurs when third member is drawn into the dyad in an effort to either stabilize a conflicted system or manage the stress associated with the conflict. May be helpful if therapist stabilizes the dyad, but can result in hard if the therapist, wittingly or unwittingly, colludes with one member of the couple. But can result in harm if the therapist, wittingly or unwittingly, colludes with one member of the couple.

item.title: Triangle

item.title: Multigenerational Transmission Process
item.description:
Bowen's concept for the process, occurring over several generations, in which poorly differentiated individuals marry equally immature partners, ultimately resulting in children suffering from severe psychological problems. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
The concept of multigenerational transmission process describes how small differences in the levels of Differentiation of Self between parents and their offspring lead over many generations to marked differences in differentiation among the members of an extended family. The information creating these differences is transmitted across generations through relationships. The transmission occurs in several interconnected levels, ranging from the conscious teaching and learning of information to the automatic and unconscious programming of emotional reactions and behaviors. Relationally and genetically transmitted information interact to shape an individual's 'self.' The combination of parents actively shaping the development of their offspring, offspring inately responding to their parents' moods, attitudes, and actions, and the long dependency period of human offspring results in people's developing levels of differentiation of self similar to their parents'. However, the relationship patterns of nuclear family emotional systems often result in at least one member of a sibling group developing a little more 'self' and another member developing a little less 'self' than the parents. People predictably select mates with levels of differentiation of self that match their own. Therefore, if one offspring's level of 'self' is higher than the parents' and another is lower, one offspring's marriage is more differentiated and the other's marriage is less differentiated than the parents' marriage. If each offspring then has a child who is more differentiated and a child who is less differentiated than himself, one three generational line becomes progressively more differentiated (the most differentiated child of the most differentiated offspring) and one line becomes progressively less differentiated (the least differentiated child of the least differentiated offspring). As these processes repeat over multiple generations, the differences between family lines grow increasingly marked. Levels of differntiation of self can affect longevity, marital stability, reproduction, health, educational accomplishments, and occupational successes. This impact of differentiation on overall life functioning explains the marked variation that typically exists in the lives of the members of a multigenerational family. The highly differentiated people have unusually stable nuclear families and contribute much to society. The poorly differentiated people have chaotic personal lives and depend heavily on others to sustain them. A key implication of the multigenerational concept is that the roots of the most severe human problems, as well as of the highest levels of human adaptation, are generations deep. The multigenerational transmission process not only programs the levels of 'self' people develop but also how people interact with others. Both types of programming affect the selection of a spouse For example, if a family programs someone to atta

item.title: Fusion
item.description: A blurring of psychological boundaries between self and others and a contamination of emotional and intellectual functioning; opposite of differentiation. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Bowen Family System Theory/Key Terms and Concepts/Fusion.md

item.title: Emotional Reactivity
item.description: The tendency to respond in a knee-jerk emotional fashion rather than calmly and objectively. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)

item.title: Emotional Cutoff
item.description: Bowen's term for flight from an unresolved emotional attachment. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)

item.title: Differentiation of Self
item.description: Bowen's term for psychological separation of intellect and emotions and independence of self from others; opposite of fusion. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)

item.title: 6. Assessment and Conceptualization
item.description:
Read Patterson et al. Chapter 4 @pattersonEssentialSkillsFamily2018
Read Patterson et al. Chapter 10 @pattersonEssentialSkillsFamily2018
Read Patterson et al. Appendix @pattersonEssentialSkillsFamily2018
Read Gerhart Chapter 11 Research Citations/Books/@gehartMasteringCompetenciesFamily2017
Read Gerhart Chapter 12 Research Citations/Books/@gehartMasteringCompetenciesFamily2017 Read Collaborative Assessment and Management of Suicidality (CAMS Framework) Read and Review: “Media/Clinic Media/(CAMS) Collaborative Assessment and Management of Suicidality.pdf” could not be found.
Read (https://www.etr.org/blog/deescalation-techniques-coping-with-students-clients-coping-with-our-lives/)
Watch (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=h1xGjKuDAaQ&ab_channel=DianeR.Gehart%2CPh.D.)
Watch (https://youtu.be/R2PSExM-NhULinks to an external site.)
Watch (https://youtu.be/6B9Kqg6jFeILinks to an external site. Review Diagnostic Assessment Outline:“Diagnostic Assessment Outline.pdf” could not be found. Review Non-Violence Agreement: “Non-Violence-Agreement (4).pdf” could not be found. Review Intimate Justice Scale: “Intimate-Justice-Scale.pdf” could not be found. Review Gender Inclusive Power and Control Wheel: “PowerandControlWheel- gender inclusive.pdf” could not be found. Review LGBT Power and Control Wheel for Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, and Trans Relationships: “LGBT power and control wheel.pdf” could not be found. Review Safety Plan How-To Guide for Clinicians:“Safety Plan How-To Guide for Clinicians.pdf” could not be found. Review Cultural Formation Interview: “APA_DSM5_Cultural-Formulation-Interview (3).pdf” could not be found. Review How to Create a New Client in Therapy Notes: “How To_ Create a New Client in Therapy Notes.pdf” could not be found. MAKE SURE TO COMPLETE OBSERVATION FORM AFTER OBSERVATION Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD7): “GAD-7 (1).pdf” could not be found. Patient Health Questionnaire: “PHQ9.pdf” could not be found. Experiences in Close Relationships Scale - Short Form (ECR-SF):“ECR-S.pdf” could not be found.
Description: https://novopsych.com.au/assessments/formulation/experience-in-close-relationship-scale-short-form-ecr-s/Links to an external site. How do we not make assumptions on how people feel? We can only guess, but that can come off. - Don't want to jumpt to conclusions. Allow the client to describe it. Can you tell me what it looks like for you? Use open ended questions. using states like "I have heard people describe this before, how does it feel for you? What is just suicidal ideation? What if Types of Clinical Assessment: Two broad approaches to assessment: Systemic Approach Postmodern Approach Formal Assessments: Formal assessment involves the use of tools such as tests, questionnaires, checklists and rating scales. Formal assessments often have data to determine their reliability and validity. Examples: Generalized Anxiety Disorder 7 Questionnaire (GAD7) - Individual
GAD-7 (1).pdf Patient Health Questionnaire 9 (PHQ9) - Individual
PHQ9.pdf Experiences of Close Relationships Scale - Couple Informal Assessments: Unstructured: Writing or drawing activities Journals Games Observation Structured: Checklists Rating Scales Interviews Questionnaires The mental status examination is a structured assessment of the patient's behavioral and cognitive functioning. In general, the components of a mental status exam include descriptions of the following: Appearance: Casual dress, normal grooming and hygiene. Attitude: Calm and cooperative General Behavior: Unusual movements or psychomotor changes Speech and Language: Normal rate/tone/volume and without pressure Emotions: Reactive and mood congruent, labile, tearful, blunted, normal range, depressed, constricted, flat Mood: Euthymic, irritable, elevated, anxious, depressed Thought and Perception: Goal-directed and logical or disorganized Suicidal ideation: passive, active, plan? Homicidal ideation: passive, active plan? Hallucinations or delusions during interview Cognition Orientation: oriented to time, place, person, self Biopsychosocial Model: “Screenshot 2023-09-27 at 10.25.48 AM.png” could not be found. A Biopsychosocial Assessment is an assessment typically conducted by therapists at the beginning of therapy, which assesses for biological, psychological, and social factors that can be contributing to a problem or problems with a client. Biopsychosocial Assessments enable therapist to diagnose and effectively treat clients. Tasks and Process of Assessment: Make Initial Contact Develop a collaborative therapeutic relationship Use a bio-psycho-sociocultural-spiritual assessment: Person-in-Environment Defining problems Assessing safety Accessing and appreciating patient/clients' strengths Assess systems collaboration issues and strengths Expand awareness and perspectives Assess goals Biopsychosocial Assessment Areas: Demographic Information (Age, Ethnicity, Religion, Relational Status, Referral Status, etc.) History of the Presenting Problem Psychiatric History Trauma History Family Psychiatric History Medical History Medication Use Substance Use Family History (Family of Origin, Relationship with Parents, Siblings, etc.) Social History Spiritual/Cultural Factors Developmental History Educational/Vocational History Legal History SNAP (Strength, Needs, Abilities, Preferences) Other Important Information Guiding Principles for Assessment: A systemic view: Everything is connected Foundational importance of bio-physiological, psychological, sociocultural, and spiritual domains in relation to multiple service systems A strengths-based perspective Assessment as an ongoing process Regular screening and tracking during sessions of the following: Health status Mobility Wellness Exercise Nutrition Sleep Ensure that client has primary care physician Communicate with primate care physician or other health providers as needed. General Psychological Issues: Cognitive skills and ability (e.g.. thought process, problem-solving/decision-making skills) Behavioral skills Emotional competencies: Affect regulation Capacity for relating Motivational factors Overall mental status Risk Assessment Specific Mental Health Concerns: Depression Anxiety Substance Use Appropriate referral if needed Ongoing communication between external providers (collaboration of care) Risk Assessment includes consideration of psychological and social factors as part of a comprehensive review to capture client needs, and to assess their risk of harm to themselves or others. Assessments often aim to categorize patients as at high, medium, or low risk Examples of risk areas include: Suicidal ideation Homicidal ideation Child abuse/neglect Intimate partner violence Physical health issues or crises Inability to care for self or others Animal abuse Substance abuse Important factors: Level of risk Intent to act Plan to act Means to act Risk and protective factors Assessing Strengths: Personal and Relational Strengths: Bio-physiological Psychological Sociocultural Spiritual 'Strengths' of the problem/symptoms Strengths in systems collaboration Exploring the 'Strengths' and Potential 'Contributions' of the Problem When was the last time that you realized that the problem was helpful to you? If your problem has a voice, what do you think it is trying to share or communicate with you? How might the problem be helpful to you? If we could get rid of the problem, what might be some aspect of it that you might want to retain? Useful Questions for Assessing Strengths: What has been helpful so far? What are some of your successes? What are the achievements that you are most proud of having accomplished? What little things are you doing that make life a little better for you? What kinds of things do people compliment you on? When have you stopped doing something that was difficult for you to stop? When have you made an important change in your life that was difficult to make? When have you broken a habit that was hard to break? Outcomes of Assessment: Problems: Bio-psycho-sociocultural-spiritual perspective Problem and attempted solutions specifically and behaviorally described (SOLVABLE). Goals: Desired future outcomes Specifically and behaviorally described (ATTAINABLE) Professional and the patient/client mutually agree to the described problems and goals. Treatment plan and interventions based on mutual consensus of problem and goal David A. Jobes, Ph.D. Creator of CAMS Framework Collaborative Assessment and Management of Suicidality (CAMS) It is a therapeutic framework for suicide-specific assessment and treatment of a patient's suicidal risk. It is a flexible approach that can be used across theoretical orientations and disciplines for a wide range of suicidal patients across treatment settings and different treatment modalities. Every session of CAMS intentionally utilizes the patient's input about what is and is not working. All assessment work in CAMS is collaborative. The clinician's honesty and forthrightness are key elements. The CAMS clinician endeavors to understand their patient's suffering from an empathic, nonjudgemental, and intra-subjective perspective. The clinician never shames or blames a suicidal person for being suicidal. Evidence-Based Psychological Treatments for Suicide: Three evidence-based (randomized controlled trials) interventions and treatments that are designed to directly target suicide at risk. Dialectical Behavioral Therapy (DBT) Cognitive Behavior Therapy (CBT): Suicide Prevention (CT-SP) and Brief CBT. Collaborative Assessment and Management of Suicidality (CAMS) Suicide-Specific Brief Interventions: Evidence-Based (Random Controlled Trial): Teachable Moment Brief Intervention (TMBI): A one-time intervention 2 dats after an attempt. Motivational Interviewing: In-patient settings Crisis Response Planning & Safety Planning (6 Steps) Attempted Suicide Short Intervention Program (ASSIP): 3 Sessions in-patient settings Malpractice Liability, Competent Practice, and Cases of Suicide: Know the three 'pillars' for reducing malpractice liability (i.e. malpractice wrongful death torts): Foreseeability: Treatment Planning: Follow-Up/Follow-Through:

item.title: 2. Strategic Family Therapy
item.description:
Strategic grew out of Gregory Bateson's project on Schizophrenia at the Mental Research Institute (MRI). The initial emphasis was on observation and research on families, but due to the influence of Milton Erikson's work, intervention strategies were also formulated. Believed in using the resources of his clients and designing a 'strategy for each specific problem' He did not care about perspective (insight) as long as their actions produced beneficial results. Conducted therapy by paying extreme attention to details of the symptoms his clients presented. In therapy: Accepted and emphasized positive Used indirect and ambiguously worded directives Directed routine behaviors so that the resistance is shown through change and not through normal continuous actions. The MRI Pioneers:
Don Jackson
Gregory Bateson (As a consultant)
Virginia Satir
John Weakland
Jay Haley
Paul Watzlawick
Richard Fisch
Jules Riskin Strategic Therapy is any type of therapy where the therapist initiates what happens during therapy and designs a particular approach for each problem. Strategic therapy isn't a particular approach or theory, but a name for the types of therapy where the therapist takes responsibility for directly influencing people. Families often perpetuate problems by their own actions. Directives tailored to the needs of a particular family can sometimes bring about sudden and decisive change. The exchange of multilayered messages between family members define their relationships. Interrupting vicious cycles that occur when attempts to solve problems only make them worse. People are always communicating. All behavior is communicative. One cannot not communicate. All messages have report and command functions Report = Content = information = (What is said) Command = Process = underlying relationship = How it is said If no one registers a complaint, there is no problem. Patterns (e.g., quiet detachment, volatile engagement) may be dysfunctional for some families and adaptive for others. The approach is non-normative and complaint-based. Focuses on identifying and interrupting 'ironic processes' which occur when repeated attempts to solve a problem keep the problem going or make it worse. The aim of therapy is simply to resolve the presenting complaint as quickly and efficiently as possible, so clients can get on with life BSCT makes no attempt to specify what constitutes a functional or dysfunctional family relationship. The therapist attends to what clients do, as well as how, they view the problem, themselves, and each other. Often see family members individually in the context of family therapy, even when the focus of the intervention is a relational complaint. The model is called 'Strategic' because the therapist intervenes to interrupt ironic processes deliberately, on the basis of a case-specific plan that sometimes includes counter-intuitive suggestions Go slow Engage in behavior they want to eliminate What matters is the extent to which interaction patterns based on attempted solutions keep a complaint going or make it worse. The problems clients bring to therapy persist only if they are maintained by ongoing current behavior of the family. If problem-maintaining behavior is appropriately changed or eliminated, the problem will be resolved or vanish, regardless of its nature, origin, or duration. How a problem persists is much more relevant to therapy than how the problem originated. The persistence of the problem depends mainly on social interaction. The behavior of one member of the family is stimulated and shaped by the response of the others. How a family goes about trying to solve a problem usually plays a crucial role in perpetuating it.
Well-intentioned yet ironic solutions break the vicious cycle (Positive Feedback loops) that maintain an impasse.
Families are stuck in a spiraling Positive Feedback loop. They make common-sense but ineffective attempts to change responses. For example: When a younger sibling arrives, the older sibling, feeling unloved, starts screaming for attention. The parent punishes him which reinforces his feelings of being unloved, and he continues to throw tantrums.
Family Rules: The rules or regularities of family interaction that operate to preserve family stability.
Homeostasis:
The conservative aspect of family systems (similar to Cybernetics concept of Negative Feedback)
Circular Causality
Feedback Loops
First-Order Change
Second-Order Change
Hierarchical Structure
Prescribing Ordeals Rules are typically unspoken, and govern most behavior When tules promote rigid attempted solutions, it isn't just the behavior but the rule needs to change.
When a specific behavior within a system changes (First-Order Change)
When the rules of the system change (Second-Order Change) Rules are changed through reframes. Centerpiece of the model Families encounter many difficulties over the course of their lives, whether a difficulty becomes a problem depends on how fmaily members respond to it. Families often make misguided attempts to solve their difficulties and, on finding that the problem persists, apply more of the same attempted solutions. This produces an escalation of the problem, which provokes more of the same, in a vicious cycle. What often needs to happen? Reverse the solution!
Paradoxical Injunction:
A technique used in Strategic Family Therapy whereby the therapist directs family members to continue their symptomatic behavior. If they conform, they admit control and expose secondary gain; if they rebel, they give up their symptoms. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019) Not to point out that an individual is fighting going under, but instead tell the individual to keep their eyes open until they become unbearably heavy.
Reframing: Changing the interpretation.
Identify Feedback Loop s that maintain problems. Determine the rules that support those interactions. Find a way to change the rules in order to interrupt problem-maintaining behavior. Do not regard any particular way of functioning, relating, or living as a problem if the client is not expressing content with it. How problems develop: Cybernetic:
Difficulties turn into chronic problems by misguided solutions, forming Positive Feedback escalations. Structural: Problems are the result of incongruous hierarchies. Functional: Problems result when people try to protect or control one another covertly, so that their symptoms serve a function for the system. Once the presenting problem is resolved, therapy is concluded. If a family didn't ask for help with other issues, they aren't targeted. The job is simply to get the family moving again. Help families define clear and reasonable goals so that everyone knows when treatment has been successful. In pushing family members to set concrete goals, they are forced to clarify vague dissatisfactions. The primary goal is behavior change. Alter specific patterns of communication that maintain problems.
Mental Research Institute (MRI): The way to resolve problems is to reverse the misguided solutions that have been maintaining them.
Jay Haley: Changes in behavior alter perceptions (rather than the other way around) Milan: Get families to see things differently (through reframing or positive connotation), rather than in getting family members to behave differently. Define a resolvable complaint. Obtain a very specific behavioral picture of the complaint. Who sees it as a problem? Why is it a problem now? "What is the problem that brings you here today?" is too vague. Inquire about exactly what these complaints mean. Identify attempted solutions that maintain the complaint. Once the problem had been defined, the therapist tries to determine who has tried to solve it and how. The solution is part of the problem. Prescribe some alternative behavior! The key is to stop the performance of the problem-maintaining solution. MRI Approach: Introduction to the treatment setup Inquiry and definition of the problem Estimation of the behavior maintaining the problem Setting goals for treatment Selecting and making behavioral interventions Termination Attempted solutions: The solution is deny that a problem exists; action is necessary but not taken. For instance, parents do nothing necessary despite the growing evidence that their teenage son is using drugs. The solution is an effort to solve something that isn't really a problem; action is taken when it shouldn't be. For example, parents punish a child for masturbating. The solution is an effort to solve a problem within a framework that makes a solution impossible; action is taken but at the wrong level. For instance, a husband buys gifts for his wife when what she wants is affection. Solutions that perpetuate problems fall into three categories: When clients deny that a problem exists (example: anorexia) ACT When clients try to solve something that really isn't a problem (example: punishing a child for masturbating) STOP ACTING When clients try to solve a problem within a framework that make a solution impossible (example: husband buys gifts for his wife, rather than giving her the affection she desires) DIFFERENT ACTIONS Understand the clients' unique language for describing the problem. To interrupt problem-maintaining sequences, therapists may try to do something that runs counter to common sense. Paradoxical interventions: The therapist directs the family members to continue their symptomatic behavior. If they conform, they admit control and expose secondary gain. If they rebel, they give up their symptom(s). Most common symptom prescriptions where the family is told to continue or embellish the behavior they complain about. Hope is that the family will comply and then be forced to reverse their attempted solution. May also hope the client rebels against the therapist's advice. Restraining technique: Warning clients against changing to fast and relapse; reinforced the therapist's one-down position. The family is told to continue or embellish the behavior they complain about. Sometimes the therapist prescribes the symptom while secretly hoping the clients will rebel against the directive. As soon as a family member is overwhelmed, they are instructed to make a list of all the things that they might do to sabotage their life. Doing so can take the rebellion out of self-destructive behavior, thus making it less appealing and less impulsive. Asking a couple to deliberately have an argument during the week in order to help the therapist understand how they get involved in such no-win encounters and how they are able to get each other to act unreasonably. Discouraging families from trying to change too fast, warning them to go slow and worrying out loud about the possibility of relapse when improvements do occur. Perhaps you should continue to wake Ricky up for school, after all, you don't want to push him to be too responsible too soon. The main thing is to discover what families are doing to perpetuate the problem and then get them to do something different. Co-founded the Family Therapy Institute of Washington D.C. (1974) Hayley learned from:
Milton Erikson
Gregory Bateson
Salvador Minuchin
He adopted and modified Milton Erikson 's individual emphasis to work with families. Concerned with the function a symptom served.
Examined rules and structure of a family (influenced by Salvador Minuchin). Hayley was particularly concerned with power struggles, and often prescribed the symptom such that the cost of keeping it up outweighed the gains. Madanes was concerned with incongruence hierarchies, where a child uses symptoms to change the behavior of the parent. Family Life: Over and covert rules families use to govern themselves
Family Homeostasis: Tendency of the family to remain in its same pattern of functioning unless challenged to do otherwise.
Quid Pro Quo: The responsiveness of family members to treating others in the way they are treated.
Redundancy Principle: Fact that a family interacts within a limited range of repetitive behavioral sequences.
Punctuation: Idea that people in a transaction believe what they say is caused by what others say.
Symmetrical Relationship s: Relationships within a family are both among equals (symmetrical) and unequals (complementary).
Circular Causality: Idea that one event does not 'cause' another but that events are interconnected and there are multiple factors behind a behavior. To resolve, remove, or ameliorate the problem the family agreed to work on. Behavioral, concerned with the immediate problem, and anti-insight. Structural re-organization of the family, like the structural therapies, but with sub-goals to deal with the presenting problem. Process, not content-focused. Emphasize short term treatment (10 sessions) Define a problem clearly Investigating all solutions that have previously been tried Defining a clear and concrete change to be achieved Formulating and implementing a strategy for change Therapists must be innovative Therapy must be customizable to families (technique driven) If families are going to change, alterations in ways their members act must precede new perceptions or feelings Focus on interpersonal payoff of psychiatric symptoms Social Stage: Introduction and setup Help everyone relax, greet each family member, make sure everyone is comfortable. Problem Stage: Definition of the problem in clear behavioral terms Ask each individual for their perspective, speak to the less involved parent/partner first to get their involvement, listen carefully to the way each family member describes the problem, make sure no one interrupts until each has a turn, make observations. Emphasize the use of directives. If therapy is to end well, it must begin proper. Interaction Stage: Estimation of the behaviors maintaining the problem Encourage family members to discuss their points of view among themselves, observe rather than just hearing about the interchanges that surround the problem, look for coalitions between family members against others, how functional is the hierarchy and do family members work together as a team or undercut one another? Goal Setting Stage Providing directives Give the family a task, directives Offering a different perspective/framework to understand problem behavior. "The use of language to give a new meaning to a situation." For instance, a child's misbehavior can be reframed as his way of asking for attention, not an indication of disrespect. Reframes can be offered by asking circular questions: "Who makes you depressed?" "What does dad do when you and mom are fighting?" Changing the frame of reference for understanding behavior leads to change in the rules governing interactions which in turn leads to sustainable change. Where a symptom is often seen as a metaphor for an underlying problem. Example: A school problem in a child may mirror a work problem in a parent. Mandanes talked about how one relationship may metaphorically replicate another and power struggles in couples (money, education, control of children, etc.) Negotiation (pg. 90)
Quid Pro Quo (pg. 91) Pretend techniques (pg. 91) Ordeals (pg. 91) Hayley believed that telling people what they're doing wrong only mobilizes resistance. Changes in behavior alter perceptions. Milan group was interested in getting families to see things differently through (reframe) positive connotation. Which then gets family members to behave differently. Shift from behavior to cognition set stage for constructivist/narrative movements. Families should have clear generational boundaries. Therapists should be 'neutral' and not have expectations for families. Therapy helps the family by simply examining the family, asking questions to help them examine their own family structure, and exposing games after which they can redesign their family into a better structure on their own.
Mara Selvini Palazzoli
Gianfranco Cecchin Presession: Generate initial hypothesis of presenting problem. Session: Validate, modify, and change the hypothesis. Intersession: Team discussion of hypothesis and arrival at an intervention. Intervention: Delivery of the intervention to the family. Postsession: Team discussion to analyze the family's reactions and to plan for next session. Highly scripted. Families treated by co-therapists and observed by other members of the team.
Positive Connotations Must include the entire family system and confirm the behavior of all family members as maintaining the stability and cohesion of the group.
Rituals: Engage families in a series of actions that ran counter to or exaggerated rigid family rules. Define the complaint in specific behavioral terms. Set minimum goals for change. Investigate solutions to the complaints. Concentrate on the 'less of the same.' Understand clients' preferred views. Use these views to suggest 'less of the same' Nurture and solidify initial change. Frequency of sessions intended to maximize the likelihood that change will be durable. Typically patter of brief (e.g., weekly, tapering off) Therapy ends when the treatment goals have been attained (and change seems reasonably stably?) Co-therapists work as a team (e.g., observing behind the mirror, leaving the room to consult) Late in session, the therapist may leave so the team can help the therapist plan a homework assignment or framing intervention. The essential role of the therapist is to persuade the family to 'do less of the same' solution that keeps the complaint going. Treatment is likely to go awry if the therapist is not in control of it. Good strategic therapists rarely exert control directly in the sense of offering authoritative prescriptions or assuming the role of an expert. Taking a 'one down position' and a stance of empathetic curiosity. I'm a little slow on the uptake here, so could you help me understand again what it is you do when he raises his voice that way? I don't know if doing this when he walks through the door will make much of a difference, but if you could try it once or twice this week, at least we'll have an idea what we're up against. Emapthetic restraint (e.g., go slow) is used to neutralize apprehension and resistance to change. When clients fail to follow a suggestion, a common response is for the therapist to take the blame (e.g., I think I suggested that prematurely) and seek alternative routes to the same strategic objective. While the model does not emphasize the importance of the therapeutic relationship, this does not mean that strategic therapists come across as cold, manipulative, or uncaring. On the contrary, many receive high ratings on rapport and alliance. Define a resolvable complaint. Identify solution patterns (problem-solution loops) that maintain the complaint. Understand clients' unique language and preferred views of the problem, themselves and each other. The first two goals provide a template for where to intervene and the third goal is relevant to how to intervene. Gather a specific behavioral picture of the complaint Who is doing what? If I had a video of this, what would I see? Assess who sees the complaint as a problem and why it is a problem now? Determine a minimum change goal What would you be doing, or the two/three/four of you be doing differently that will let you know this problem is taking a turn for the better. Inquire into behaviors that are closely related to the problem: What has the family is done to handle, prevent, or resolve the complaint? What happens after these attempted solutions? Develop a picture of what 'less of the same' will look like: What behavior, by whom, in what situation, will suffice to reverse the problem-maintaining solution? The key element to stopping the performance of the attempted solution, so as not to perpetuate 'more of the same' problem-maintaining solution. The final assessment goal is grasping the clients' unique views. This is crucial to the later task of framing suggestions: How do they see themselves and want to be seen by others? What do they hold near and dear? When are they at their best, and what do others notice about those times? What is their best guess about why a particular problem is happening - and why they handle it the way they do? Whose idea was it to come? Why now? Who is most optimistic that therapy will help? How will you know the situation is improving? What kinds of change will you settle for? What will need to happen (or not to happen) to let you know that, even if you are not out of the woods entirely, you're at least on the right path? What will each of you settle for? Therapeutic restraint: Telling clients to 'go slow' Cautioning them about the dangers of improvement Giving insturctions about how to make the problem worse Go slow is used to prepare clients for change, to convey acceptance of reluctance to change, and to solidify change once it begins to occur. Asking the family to collaborate in performing the problem patterns (e.g., an argument) deliberately. Identify problem-solution feedback loops: Demand-Refuse Discuss-Acoid Criticize-Defend Accuse-Deny Encourage the family to do less of the same: When members felt the need to talk about their relationship, they would first go bowling.
Reframing: For a small set of family complaints, the goal is to help families reevaluate their problem as 'no problem,' or as a problem they can live with. Acknowledging (Reinforcing): When a small change occurs, the therapist acknowledges and emphasizes the clients' part in making it happen, but avoids encouraging further change directly. Predicting or Prescribing: Exploring the dangers of movement. Therapeutic restraint / going slow Prescribing the symptom / performing the problem / predicting Jamming / experiment Reframing Less of the same Acknowledge / reinforce Critics sometimes regard strategic therapy as 'manipulative' because the therapist does not usually make the rationale for particular interventions explicit to clients. The therapist may say things that they do not truly believe to achieve an effective framing. Proponents counter that responsible therapy is inherently manipulative and that therapeutic candor can be disrespectful. Good therapy shows profound respect for clients' subjective experiences. Critics suggest strategic therapists may ignore problems such as intimate-partner violence or substance abuse, if clients do not perceive or present them as overt complaints in session. The model does not attempt at helping families with personal growth or solving underlying emotional issues. The central curative factor is interruption of 'ironic processes' which depends on: Accurate identification of the particular solution efforts that maintain or exacerbate the problem. Specifying what less of those same solution behaviors might look like. Designing one intervention that will persuade at least one of the people involved to do less or the opposite of what they have been doing. Applicable to any family that presents with a clear complaint. Particularly relevant for families that seem resistance to change. Most qualitative research (case reports) and follow-up quantitative data. Historically, most of the research on the effectiveness of Strategic Therapy wasn't very rigorous. Mostly case report format. Anecdotal support for its efficacy, although people tend not to write about their failed cases.
Case reports with Anorexia Nervosa, Schizophrenia, and delinquency (pg. 96) Brief Strategic Family Therapy for adolescent substance abuse and behavior problems Treatment engagement, family functioning Focuses on the process of communication rather than its content. Clever, prescriptive, expedient Critiqued as manipulative Therapist is responsible for the outcome of therapy. Families are stuck in well-intentioned but ineffective attempts to solve problems.
Paradoxical Injunction: To shake the status quo of the system Circular questioning and team supervision from the Milan group. Team approaches to therapy As a treatment for families, strategic differs from most other approaches in that the therapist is willing, and sometimes prefers, to see family members (particularly partners) individually.
