item.title: 5. Solution-Focused Therapy
item.description:
Steve de Shazer
Insoo Kim Berg Miracle question Rating/Scaling (1 to 10) Break After intermission, the therapist will give the client/family compliments, sometimes followed by a suggestion or homework. If it ain't broken, don't fix it. Once you know what works, do more of it. If it doesn't work, don't do it again, do something different. Solution-focused family therapy begins with clients' descriptions of how they want their lives to be different. It can be understood as beginning with the end of the story, rather than the beginning of the problem. The basic idea is to avoid escalating problem talk by instead focus on eliciting movement in a helpful direction (i.e., focusing on solutions). Focus is on solutions, on what works for clients. Respect clients own resources. Directed toward building solutions rather than increasing insight into punitive maladaptive psychological mechanisms. Future-oriented Focusing on those times when the problem was not present (exceptions). The task of therapy is to do something different. What is happening in your lives that you want to continue to have happen? The most fundamental difference between the emphasis between problem-focused therapy and solution-focused therapy is the emphasis each give to the concept of 'solution.' Solution-focused family therapy seeks to identify exceptions to the problem and develop new solutions that work. What brings you in? What are your best hopes for this meeting? Therapists avoid diagnostic categories and preconceived notions of what may be healthy or unhealthy. Accept the client's version of what is, and what is not, the problem. It isn't necessary to know what causes problems in order to make things better. Families that come to therapy are capable of behaving effectively, but their effectiveness has been blunted by a negative mind-set. The model draws attention to forgotten capabilities, which release families from preoccupation with their failures and restores them to their capable selves. Problems are seen as overwhelming because families see them as always happening, times when problems are not happening, aren't noticed, or are dismissed. People are constrained by narrow views of their problems that perpetuate rigid patterns of false solutions. The meanings people attribute to behavior limit the range of alternatives they will use to deal with a situation. Changing the way people talk about their problems. The language of problems tends to be different from the language of solutions. Problem talk: Negative Focuses on the past Implies permanence of problems. Clients are experts in their own lives. Clients know what they need Is there anything else I should have asked you or that you need to tell me? The therapist needs to know how to set aside their own frame of reference as much as possible and explore those of their clients. People are resourceful. Problems are normal life-cycle complications. Families have the abillity to construct solutions that can enhance their lives. Solution-focused therapists steer families away from speculating about problem formation. Problems persist in the way people define situations and in the misdirected actions they persist in taking. Set clear goals and build on exceptions to problems. Good therapy is more than implementing specific techniques, it also involves therapeutic alliance. The goal of solution-focused therapy is to resolve the presenting problem as expeditiously as possible. The goal is not about how families should be structured, but only what they want different in their lives. The model emphasizes the importance of assisting clients in creating well-defined goals, framed in positive terms and modest enough to be achievable. What will you be doing instead? The model works by helping clients amplify exceptions to their problems – effective solutions already in their repertoire. Changing the way people talk about their problems is all that needs to be accomplished. As the family and therapist talk more and more about the solution they want to construct together, they come to believe in what they are talking about. It is easier to get people to talk differently about their problems than it is to get them to change their behavior. Getting people to talk positively will help them think positively and ultimately act positively to solve their problems. Change perception helps with the change of behavior. As a picture of positive future develops, the family begins to see themselves differently and they respond to what they see. They begin living in the solution, not the problem. The 'virtuous cycle' gets going, the family gets unstuck, and they move forward. Time limited Sessions are made one at a time One may be enough Typical course includes 3-5 sessions Clients can return as-needed Often a week to a few weeks apart Once you know more of what works, do more of it Gather a brief description of the presenting problem. Move to directly asking clients about how things will be different in their lives then their probelms are solved. Ask about times in the clients' lives when their problems do not happen or are less severe. What do you think the problem is now? How will you know when the problem is solved? How will you know when you don't have to come here anymore? What will the signs be? What will have to be different about others involved in the situation? What is your wildest fantasy about what you want to happen? What would it take to get your family member (or the court) off of your back? Takes little intake information because they want to hear clients' constructions of their problems firsthand (in session). Asks more about perceptions than feelings. Affirms clients' positions by conveying understanding of their point of view. Doesn't function as an expert; clients are experts on what they want to change. Takes an active position in moving clients away from worrying about their predicament and toward steps to solution. Anyone who is concerned about the problem should attend sessions and are part of the solution. Consultant Guardian of the conversation Don't get bogged down in 'problem talk' Focus on what is right Direct clients away from the problem-saturated narrative. Therapist attempts to create a context for the family to develop more useful ways of responding. Focus on the 'here and now' The future provides a blank canvas on which the family can paint a picture of their wishes and hopes. Assumes a position of 'not knowing.' What needs to happen as a result of coming here so that afterward you will look back and be able to say it was a good idea? What needs to happen as a result of coming here so that this will not have been a waste of your time? Often in our experience, we have found that in between scheduling an appointment and coming in, something happens that contributes to making a problem better. Has anything happened to improve the problems that brought you here today? Constructing a more detailed description of the therapeutic goal. Once a description of the goal has been developed, the therapist asks the client to assess their current level of progress toward that goal by imagining a scale of 1-10, where 1 represented the problem at its worst, and 10 is the point at which the problem is gone. So, what has to happen to get your mother off of your back? What is the minimum we need to accomplish so that you won't have to keep coming for more sessions? What would it take to get your family (or court) off of your back? Developing well-focused goals within the clients' frame of reference Generating solutions based on exceptions Goal setting
Miracle Question
Exception Question
Coping Questions
Scaling Questions
Compliments Before Session Between now and next time we meet, I would like you to observe what happens that you want to continue to have happen? In-Session What brings you here today? How can I be helpful to you? What changes have you noticed since you first made the call to set up this appointment? Exceptions When in the past might the problem have happened but it didn't? Solution-focused therapists intervene and interrupt 'problem talk' before it escalates into demoralizing bickering, blaming and defending, accusations, etc. Agency How did you do that? How did you get that to happen? Coping How have you managed to cope, endure, keep going? Scaling (i.e., making numbers talk) What will it take to move from a 3 to a 4? On a scale of 1 to 10, 1 being absolutely no hope, and 10 being complete hope, what number would you give your current level of hope? Therapy begins with a description of the clients' problem. How were you hoping I could help you? Asking for clients' perceptions Acknowledge clients' perceptions, using clients own language as much as possible. As clients what they've already tried to resolve their difficulties. How do we know when to stop meeting like this? Goals should be: Small Salient to clients Concrete, behavioral, measurable Achieveable Involve hard work Start of something Involving new behaviors What will be present? What will be happening? After hearing and acknowledging the clients' description of the problem and what they've tried to do about them, next step is to establish clear and concrete goals. Specifically, how will you be doing this? How will the two of you know when you solved your problems? How will things be different? What will be the first sign (or smallest step) that will tell you that you're moving in the right direction? What else? The clearer the goal, the easier to measure progress. Can you tell me more specifically what will be happening when you two are getting along better? What will you be doing differently? Modest enough to be achievable. Now, I want to ask you a strange question. Suppose that while you are sleeping tonight and the entire house is quiet, a miracle happens. The miracle is that the problem which brought you here is solved. However, because you are sleeping, you don't know that the miracle has happened. So, when you wake up tomorrow morning, what will be different that will tell you that a miracle has happened? Invite clients to envision positive outcomes and to activate problem-solving by giving them a mental picture of their goals. Helps clients to look beyond the problem to see that what they really want might not be the elimination of the problem per se but to be able to do things that the problem has been obstructing. Suppose one night there is a miracle and while you are sleeping the problem that brought you into therapy is solved. How would you know? What would be different? What will you notice the next morning that will tell you there has been a miracle? What will your [family member] notice? Helping families see that their problems have exceptions - times when they don't occur. Exceptions are solutions that families already have in their repertoire. Probing for exceptions (e.g., times when the family didn't have the problem) invites them to recognize that some potential solutions may already be in their grasp. Finding exceptions in the recent past is most useful because clients can remember them in greater detail; also since these exceptions just happened, it is more plausible they could happen again. When in the recent past might the problem have happened but didn't (or was less intense or more manageable)? What's different about those times when the problem doesn't happen? How have you let your partner know when they do something that makes a positive difference to you? How did you manage that? What keeps you going under such difficult circumstances? How come things aren't worse? Punctuate with enthusiasm and support Work to keep solution talk in the forefront. Listen carefully for an exception to the problem, then punctuate that exception by getting more details about it and congratualating the family on it. Connect the exception to the family's goals by asking how the goal would be reached if this exception were to occur more often. The therapist asks: On a scale of 1-10, with 1 being how depressed you felt when you called me and 10 being how you feel the day after the miracle, how do you feel right now? "It is a 2." "So, you feel a little better than when you called. How did you achieve this improvement?" "What do you think you need to do to achieve a 3?" Used to get clients to quantify their confidence that they can maintain their resolve. On a scale of 1-10, how confident are you that you will be able to avoid losing your temper this week? What do you have to do to stick to your guns this time? Wow! How did you do that? To be effective, compliments should point toward what to do more, not what to eliminate. Compliments can be used to highlight successful strategies and keep clients focused on those that work Team approach with therapist in session and colleagues behind the mirror. Therapist usually takes a 10 minute break near the end of the session to compose a summary message to the clients. The summary messages begins with a recap of what the therapist heard the clients say during the interview, including the problem, its background, the client's goals, and presession progress and strengths. What I heard you tell me today is that... Did I hear all of you correctly? A statement reflecting the therapist's reaction, including an expression of empathy. "I'm not surprised you are so depressed." A reflection of the emotional impact on the client. "My sense is that you must really be hurting." Compliments on pre-session changes or strengths "I was impressed by how many things you've tried to make things better." Some content on the client's goals Suggestions for building on positives Formula first-session task Do more of what works Do something different Go slow Do the opposite The prediction task Devoted to finding, amplifying, and measuring progress Inquire about progress, seeking detailed descriptions of any movement toward the family's goal and the clients' role in attaining it. What's better? What happened that you liked? Tell me more. Walk me through how the two of you did that. Wow. That sounds great. What part did you especially enjoy? And what else is better? What do you think the next step might be? How did you keep things from getting worse? What's your idea about what might be helpful? Sometimes the model is portrayed as an approach that does not permit discussion of the problem, but this is not accurate. When done skillfully, families do not feel rushed. Emotion is not avoided, but it is also not sought or elicited. Therapist is present as a real, genuinely concerned person, but does not engage in unneeded personal self-disclosure. How can we know when to stop meeting like this? What needs to be different in your life as a result of coming here for you to say that meeting with me was worthwhile? If you wait till all of the family's problems are solved, you will never stop seeing them.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Family Theory I (8874)/Lecture/5. Solution-Focused Therapy.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 1. Introduction
item.description:
In many contexts, the term 'couple' has replaced 'marriage' because of its emphasis on the bond between family members/individuals. This shift in language is important - taking a non-judgmental approach. There is a social value implied by the more traditional terms (which privileges marriage). Use the most inclusive term possible (e.g., family) With respect to all types of relationships, use the term 'couple' as it broadly encompasses those within a committed relationship (regardless of marital status). With respect to persons of various gender identities and sexual orientations, use the term 'partner' rather than gendered language (whenever possible). While the terms such as spouse, wife, husband, boyfriend, girlfriend may be preferred by clients - intentionally using the term 'partner' may be more inclusive. With respect to those we serve, we will refer to them as clients as opposed to patients (whenever possible). Psychiatrists are physicians whoo specializes in the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of mental health and emotional problems. (M.D. needed) Psychologist study the human mind and behavior. (Masters needed) Social Workers help people function the best way they can in their environment, deal with their relationships, and solve problems. (Bachelors degree needed, unless clinical social work which needs a masters level degree) Counselors assist people with personal, family, educational, mental health, and career decisions and problems. (Masters needed) All: Diagnose Individual/relational intervention Psychiatry Diagnose Prescribe Psychology Assessment Intra Marriage and family Therapy Family intervention Inter Social Work Case management A family's patterns of behaviors influences the individual and therefore may need to be a part of the treatment plan. In CFT, the unit of treatment isn't just the person - even if only one person is 'the client'; it is the set of relationships in which the person is embedded. Brief Solution-focused Specific with attained therapeutic goals Designed with attainable therapeutic goals Designed with the 'end in mind' MFTs treat a wide range of serious clinical problems including: Depression Relationship issues Anxiety Biopsychosocial-rooted problems Research has shown that CFT is as effective or more effective than standard individual treatments for many mental health problems including: Schizophrenia Affective Mood Disorder Substance (Ab)use Child Conduct Disorder Anorexia Autism Chronic Illness Couple/Partner Distress Psychiatry raised concern about scope of practice Wanted to keep MFTs from diagnosis Psychology sought amendments to the scope to place restrictions on psychological testing, and some oppose licensure in general. Social Work concerned with title restriction Wanted to call its members MFTs Counselors (ACA) historically most active opponents Opposed MFT licensure all together Labeled the discipline as a subspecialty of counseling Professionals from many different disciplines may at times utilize family-based interventions, or work from theories or models that are core to the CFT discipline. Does that mean they are CFTs? Profession vs. Practice AAMFT's response 'It's not our intent to define the standards or the scope of practice of any other discipline - social work or psychology, for example, by saying what services they can perform or what training is need to perform those series. "We assume those professions will be diligent in ensuring that their practitioners will only deliver services for which they have had training, and are competent to perform, and that the regulatory boards for those professions will police those who go beyond their competence." Classic Schools Bowen Strategic Family Therapy
Jay Haley Depathologize problems by viewing them as normative life-cycle complications. Consider possible adaptive functions for the family. Acknowledge the helpful, alberit misguided, intentions of individuals within a family to help one another. In such reformulations, new solutions can more readily become apparent.
Structural Family Therapy
Salvador Minuchin No family style is inherently normal or abnormal. Whether organizational patterns are functional or dysfunctional depends largely on their fit with the family's developmental and social demands. The strength of the system requires clear yet flexible boundaries and subsystems for the ability to shift organizational patterns to accommodate needed change.
Experiential Family Therapy
Virginia Satir
Carl Whitaker
Psychoanalytic Family Therapy
Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (CBT) Developments
Contextual Therapy
Solution-Focused Therapy Focus on solutions (i.e., what works), future-oriented. Focusing on exceptions (i.e., those times when the problem was not present). Direct toward building solutions rather than increasing insight into punitive maladaptive psychological mechanisms.
Narrative Therapy
Michael White
David Epston Families have good intentions and neither want nor need problems. Families can develop empowering stories when separated form their problems and constraining cultural beliefs. Redirect focus from causal assumptions of dysfunction to appreciate the toxic effects of many dominant discourses in the social world. Others
Internal Family Systems (IFS) Therapy Evidenced-based treatments Couples
Emotionally Focused Therapy (EFT)
Gottman Therapy Relationship Education there Marital Preparation Multi-group Couples Therapy Does family therapy work? Therapeutic processes (e.g., how it works) Therapeutic outcomes (e.g., what results) How large are the effects of family therapy in terms of their impact on families? Are these effects sometimes negative? What are the efficacy and effectiveness of different models of family therapy? What therapist and family factors predict responsiveness to treatment? Is family therapy helping in treatment individual problems? What interactional patterns or characteristics of the family? How healthy and satisfied is the family? How did the relational patterns develop? How are they maintained? Risk factors for family functioning? How do cultural and contextual factors (e.g., age, gender, identity, class, race, etc.) play into the family's functioning? How has the family adapted to transitions, change, and crises? Frequency, setting, and duration of symptoms? Who besides the family is included in the problem? Are psychotropic medications being used? Are individual sessions held? And under what conditions? Co-therapists? Is therapy time limited? How long does it last? How often are sessions? What is the therapist's role? Consultant? Teacher? Healer? What is the role of the therapist-couple alliance? How is a working alliance fostered? To what degree does the therapist direct sessions? How does the therapist direct sessions? How does the therapist handle escalations? Do clients talk to one another or the therapist? Do clients talk to one another or the therapist? Does the therapist use self-disclosure? What are the limits? Does the therapist's role change during the course of therapy? What are the treatment goals? How are the goals determined or prioritized? Who determines the goals of therapy? How are 'mixed agendas' handled? How structured are therapy sessions? Pacing or rhythm? What techniques are used to join with the family? Is psychoeducation included? Is homework included? If secrets are revealed individually, how are secrets handled? What are the common errors that a therapist can make? How is termination determines and handled? Why is family therapy important? Why might clients choose family therapy over other approaches (i.e., individual, couple, group therapy)? When might family therapy be preferred to other treatment modalities? Under what circumstances or presenting problems might family therapy be most appropriate? What is your assessment of the problem? What is the presenting problem? Who is defining it? How is it defined? Who is the identified client? How does each member of the family view the problem? Do they share the defition? What solutions have been attempted? What are the family's beliefs, values, and cultural strengths for dealing with the problem? Reaction to psychoanalytic traditions Research on schizophrenia Acknowledge of family and contextual factors in mental illness Adoption of systems theories 1920s Group Therapy Movement 1940-1950
The Child Guidance Movement (1940s-1950s) 1950s Communication and role theories 1970s Brief therapy theories Therapists first encountered families as adversaries. Therapists begin to notice that often when a client got better, someone else in the family got worse, almost as though the family needed a symptomatic member. Clients improved in the hospital only to get worse when they went home. Parents sometimes use their children as a buffer to protect themselves from intimacy/ I.e., You're scratching your eyes for your mother so she'll have something to worry about. You're a good boy. Good children sacrifice themselves for their parents. I.e., Minuchin: As a father of a child in danger, what you're doing isn't enough. Father: What should I do? Minuchin: I don't know. Ask your son. Groups dynamics are applicable to family therapy because group life is a complex blend of individual personalities and properties of the group. The process/context distinction in group dynamics had a major impact on family therapy. Attend to how family members talk as much as to what they say. Family members have a long history and a future together. Continuity, commitment, and shared distortions all make family therapy different from group therapy. Concluded that the real problem wasn't a child's symptoms, but rather the tensions in the family that were the source of those symptoms. Tendency to blame the parents, especially mothers (this was an evolutionary misdirection that haunts the field). We need to understand the family in order to diagnose problems. Many do not distinguish between couple and family therapy. Couples therapy is just family therapy applied to a particular subsystem. However, there is a case to be made that couples therapy is a distinct enterprise (see Gurman texts) For many years, therapists resisted the idea of seeing clients' families in order to safeguard the privacy of the therapeutic relationship. Converging developments in the 1950s led to a new view that the family was an organic whole. What they observed was that the behavior of schizophrenia fit with their families; what they concluded was that the family was the cause of schizophrenia. Champions of family therapy challenged the assumption that schizophrenia was a biological disease. Psychological healers everywhere cheered. Unfortunately, we were wrong. The observation that schizophrenic behavior seems to fit in some families doesn't mean that families caused schizophrenia. Families of schizophrenic members suffered for years from the assumption that they were to blame for their child's psychoses. Modern Model Events and Timeline 1942: Founding of the American Association of Marriage Counselors 1945:
Ludwig von Bertalanffy presents General Systems Theory 1950s: Intergenerational
Family Systems Theory
Contextual Therapy
Psychoanalytic Family Therapy
Experiential Family Therapy
Brief Strategic (Mental Research Institute (MRI)) 1960s:
Structural Family Therapy
Satir's Growth Model (Human Validation Process Movement) 1970s: Founding of the American Association for Marriage and Family Counselors Strategic (Milan)
Strategic (Jay Haley) 1978: Founding of the American Association for Marriage and Family Therapy Post-Modern Model Events and Timeline 1980s
Emotionally Focused Therapy (EFT) Feminist Models Collaborative Language Systems Solution-Focused Therapy 1990s Integrative Couples Therapy
Internal Family Systems (IFS) Therapy
Narrative Therapy Solution-Oriented Therapy Multiculturalism 2000s Managed care/ empirically validated treatments To understand this better, consider the example of a mobile. When you move any one piece of a mobile, all the other pieces move too. They do not exist in isolation from one another, and movement in any one part of the system will affect all the rest of the parts of the system. The study of feedback mechanisms in self-regulating systems.
Feedback Loop: The process by which a system gets the information necessary to maintain a steady course. If you see behavior persist over time, there is likely something maintaining that behavior. Feedback loops can be negative or positive.
Negative Feedback: Indicates that a system is straying off the mark and that corrections are needed to get back on track.
Positive Feedback Reinforces the direction a system is taking. What shows up as one individual's behavior may be a product of the relationship. Family therapists use concepts to describe how people in a relationship contribute to what goes on between them (e.g., pursuer/distancer; overfunctioning/underfunctioning) At the core, the theory is about: Structure Functioning The whole is greater than the sum of its parts. Mapping sequences of interaction (which reveal how a system works)
Homeostasis: The self-regulation that keeps the system stable Families tend to resist change, which explains why so many clients remain stuck despite heroic efforts to improve. A system is, 'Any entity maintained by the mutual interaction of its parts.' A system can be composed of smaller subsystems. Every system is a subsystem of larger systems. Open vs. Closed systems Unlike machines, families change when necessary to adapt to new circumstances.
Social Constructionism: Seeing the world through a pair of glasses.
Reframing: Relabeling behavior to shift how family members respond to it. The goal of therapy shifted from interrupting problematic patterns of interaction to helping clients find new perspective on their lives. When they said reality was constructed, they meant socially constructed. Interpretations are shaped by our context. Interpretation of our experience mediates behavior. Social constructionists place more emphasis on the intersubjective influence of language and culture. Therapy becomes a process of deconstruction, freeing clients from the tyranny of entrenched beliefs. Inherent in most forms of therapy is the idea that before you can solve a problem, you must figure out what is wrong. But solution-focused turns this assumption on its head. The best way to solve problems is to discover what people do when they are not having the problem. Exceptions to a complaint. Therapists create a shift in their clients' experience by helping them reexamine how they look at things.
Externalization: Redefining problems not as properties of the individuals who suffer them, but as alien oppressors. The focus of therapy has expanded toward the wider context. This process started when therapists looked beyond individuals to their families. Suddenly unexplained behavior made sense. Early on, family therapists focused on behavioral interactions surrounding problems. Next, they recognize that those interactions were manifestations of a family's underlying structure. Structure became the target of change. Later, family structure was seen as the product of multigenerational processes that were governed by belief systems. Then, therapists aimed their interventions at those underlying beliefs. More recently, it dawned on therapists that those belief systems do not arise in a vacuum Behavior is shaped by transactions we don't always see. Systems concepts help make complex interactions predictable.
Family Structure: Defines the organization within which interactions take place. Interactions shape structure, but once established structure shapes interactions.
Subsystems
Boundaries
Family Life Cycle Context: People are products of their context. Behavior is powerfully influenced by interactions with other family members.
Circular Causality: Problems are sustained by an ongoing series of actions and reactions.
Triangles Process/Content Focus on the process of communication (how people talk), rather than the context (what they talk about) The goal is to get an overview of the presenting problem and arrange to meet. Listen to the description of the problem and identify all members of the family, household, and others who might be involved. Establish connection and engagement. Ask how the problem is affecting other members of the family. You'd like to hear from everyone, at least initially, in order to get as much information as possible. Reminder calls help increase likelihood of attendance. Build alliance with the family. Develop hypothesis about what is maintaining the presenting problem. Establish rapport. Gather information. Introduce yourself. Orient the family to the therapy room (physical or virtual) and the format of sessions. Invite family members to speak one at a time. Give everyone a chance to be heard. Establish a bond of understanding with each member of the family.
Process: How did you feel about coming in? What were your reactions to coming in? Take a family history. Conduct the genogram to diagram the family network. Listen for family life cycle transitions. Search for strengths and resilience. Remain curious and respectful. Explore the process of family interaction by asking questions about how family members relate to one another and inviting them to discuss their problems with one another in session. What is keeping the family stuck? Share recommendations for treatment. What is maintaining the problem? Maintain therapeutic alliance. Listen to and acknowledge family members' points of view. Through empathic understanding, family members feel respected and become open to being challenged. When one person is presented as the problem, challenge linearity by asking how others are involved or affected? What role do others play in creating or maintaining the problem? How have they responded to it? Challenge unhelpful interactions by pointing out patterns that seem to be keeping the family stuck. The more you do X, the more they do Y - and the more you do Y, the more they do X. Listen to people's feelings. Listening is a silent activity, rare in our time, even among therapists. Family members are not likely to reconsider their assumptions until they've been heard and understood. Help family members deal with one another more effectively in session. Take a less active role and encourage family members to interact more with one another. Step back and observe. When family members address their conflicts directly, they tend to become reactive; anxiety is the enemy of listening - help them listen and manage anxiety. Stay calm: You are not responsible for solving the family's problems. Just look for the constraints that are keeping them stuck. Be curious. Display empathy and respect. Review the therapeutic relationship. Say goodbye. Reinforce progress. Review what the family has accomplished. Anticipate and plan for upcoming challenges. How will you know when things are heading backwards? And what will you do? How will you know if it is time to come back to therapy? Check-in with the family following treatment, if possible. The presenting problem Understanding the referral route Identifying the systemic context Stage of family life cycle Family structure Communication Substance use/abuse Domestic violence and sexual abuse Affairs/infidelity Cultural context (race, ethnicity, culture, gender identity, sexual orientation, class, disability, etc.) Explore the presenting problem. Explore attempts to deal with the problem. What have they tried? What has been helpful? What hasn't been helpful? Has anyone who is not present been trying to help or hinder? Who referred the clients and why? What are their expectations? What expectations have they communicated to the family? Is participation voluntary or mandated? Who recognized the need for treatment? What other agencies are or will be involved with the case? Obtain a clear understanding of the interpersonal context of the problem. Who is in the family? Are there other important figures in the life of the problem who aren't present? Family of origin, immediate family, extended family, family of choice, etc. Are there other agencies involved? What is their input? Does the family see them as helpful? Remember that family therapy is an approach to people in context. Family problems become entrenched because they are embedded in powerful but unseen structure. What is the family's structure? What are the subsystems?
What is the nature of Boundaries between the subsystems?
What Triangles are present? Assess for substance use, IPV, and affairs. Consider assessment tools if needed. Be aware of mandated reporting. General Practitioner What is your scope of practice? Specialist Do you specialize in particular populations? Or problems? Most family therapists assume their approach can be applied to any problem. Of course their may be exceptions. The whole is greater than the sum of its parts. Systems can be viewed in terms of hierarchy, organization, and subsystems. Systems strive toward self-preservation and therefore its members work in service of the system, as well as themselves. All behavior makes sense in context. No one family member is responsible for the family's distress. Family therapists work to see the big picture. Even when a client presents with an individual issue (e.g., depression, anxiety), family therapists view it within the larger relational context. Share the following assumptions: A person's lived reality is relationally constructed. Personal identity and individual symptomology are related to the social systems in which they are embedded. Changing one's language and description of the problem alters how it is experienced. Truth can be determined only within relational contexts. Systems theory Systems metaphor A family is a system, a group of individuals who coordinate meaning and their understanding of the world. Social constructionist Textual metaphor People narrate their lives to create meaning using the social discourses available to them. Skeptical of objective reality. Reality is constructed. Reality is constructed through language. Reality is negotiated through relationships. Shared meanings coordinate social action. Founded upon the logical-positivist assumptions of an external, knowable truth. Therapist assumes expert role. Therapist is an expert who assumes the primary responsibility for identifying problems and goals, often assumes the role of a teacher or mentor. Theory and research are the primary sources of information for identifying problems and diagnosis. Therapist uses theory and research to select treatment approaches. Humans are essentially good. All people naturally tend toward growth and strive for self-actualization. Focus on treatment is the subjective, internal world of clients. Therapeutic interventions target emotions with the goal of promoting catharsis (release of repressed emotions). A supportive, nurturing environment promoted therapeutic change.
Examples such as Carl Whitaker and Virginia Satir One cannot communicate; all behavior is a form of communication. An individual's behavior and symptoms always make sense in context.
All behaviors and symptoms serve a purpose within the system, allowing the system to maintain Homeostasis. No one individual controls behavior in a system and therefore no one individual can be blamed for problems in the family. Problematic behavior emerges from the interactions between members of the system. Therapeutic change involves altering the interaction patterns within the system. Objective truth can never be fully known because it must always pass through subjective and intersubjective filters. The human mind does not have access to an outside reality independent of human interpretation. Knowledge and truth are culturally, historically, and relationally bound. Personal reality and truth are shaped by language and relationships. Language affects how identity is shaped and experienced. The identification of the problem is a social process that occurs through language. Therapy is a process of co-constructing new realities. As therapists become more aware of theories, they learn to skillfully integrate ideas from other approaches in a way that is philosophically congruent with their own approach. However, therapists who are 'eclectic' or 'integrative' in a way that is not grounded in a single philosophical set of assumptions will confuse their clients. Clients will be confused if each week the client is required to relate differently to the therapist and to assume a different level of participation (i.e., sending contradictory messages). If the therapist is able to keep the philosophical assumptions consistent throughout therapy, then the therapist can adapt concepts and techniques from other approaches without sending conflicting messages. Standard I: Responsibility to Clients Non-discrimination, informed consent, multiple relationships, reporting, abuse, referrals, non-abandonment, consent to record. Standard II: Confidentiality Limits to confidentiality, releases, access to records. Standard III: Professional Competence and Integrity Competency, conflicts of interest, records maintenance, harassment, exploitation, gifts, scope of practice, misconduct. Standard IV: Responsibility to Students and Supervisees Exploitation, confidentiality Standard V: Research and Publication Protection of participants, informed consent, right to withdraw, confidentiality, publication, authorship, plagiarism. Standard VI: Technology-Assisted Professional Services Teletherapy, consent, confidentiality, location of services and practice, training Standard VII: Professional Evaluations Forensics, testimony, competence, informed consent, avoiding conflicts, child custody, professional opinions Standard VIII: Financial Arrangements Disclosure of financial policies, recovery procedures, bartering Standard IX: Advertising Professional representation, affiliations, educational credentials, qualifications National
AAMFT Code of Ethics Research Citations/A/@AAMFTCodeofEthics2015 Local State regulatory board, laws and codes When in doubt, consult! Reviews of psychotherapy outcome research document the empirical evidence supporting the effectiveness of psychotherapy. Wide range of presenting problems. Diverse therapeutic approaches Therapeutic is effective. Treated families fare better than untreated. We need to evaluate the evidence t - What is the typee of evidence? - Targeting what outcomess? - For whom? Technical/model factors “Influential Figures in CFT History.pdf” could not be found.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Family Theory I (8874)/Lecture/1. Introduction.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 4. Cognitive-Behavioral Family Therapy
item.description:
Engaging and making comfortable Joining Creating alliance Building rapport Active listening Open-ended questions Identifying strengths and why now Reinforcing positives Mapping family system/ Genogram Exploring family dynamics (assessment) Reflecting Summarizing Reframing Circular questioning Acknowledge/reinforce Thoughts and perceptions Acting or behaving Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is a form of psychological treatment that has been demonstrated to be effective for a range of problems including depression, anxiety disorders, alcohol and drug use problems, marital problems, eating disorders, and severe mental illness. Problems are based in unhelpful thinking and behavior. Families can learn better ways of coping, which improves symptoms. Behavior is maintained by its consequences. Consequences that increase behavior are reinforcers. Consequences that decrease behavior are punishers. Behavior is regulated by its consequences. Responses that are positively reinforced will increase. Responses that are punished or ignored will be extinguished. CBT/CBFT is a highly efficacious intervention to assist families in a variety of contexts (this model has empirical support) CBT has focused on family's cognitive processing and behavioral interactions, while minimizing the influences of individual differences between family members. CBT also addresses characteristics that each family member brings to their relationships, explaining why family members behave and interpret events in maladaptive ways. Scarcity of positive outcomes available for each family member. Deficits in communication and problem solving. High frequency of negative or punishing exchanges reciprocated by partners, parents, family members. Family members are more likely to track negative behavior selectively and to make negative attributions for such behavior. They reciprocate negative behavior with negative behavior. Primary distress results from unmet fundamental needs create secondary distress (withdrawal or verbally abuse among family members) Behavior is maintained by its consequences. Ratio of costs and benefits to behavior (something is maintianing it) Good relationships are under positive reinforcement ocntrol CBT recognizes the influence of both the family's behavioral interactions (processes) and the major themes (content) that serve as the basis for relationship discord. Thoughts change to promote behavioral change (thoughts -> behavior) Emotions and actions are mediated by cognitions (thoughts -> emotions) Understand cognition (beliefs, attributions, expectancies) makes it possible to identify triggers to behavioral patterns. Uncovering hidden/automatic assumptions that keep people stuck. Overgeneralizations Magnification and minimization Personalization Dichotomous thinking Labeling and mislabeling Also called black and white thinking, catastrophizing, defense mechanisms Help families become more active observers and evaluators of their own automatic thoughts, long-standing assumptions, and of their relationship standards. Individual family members vary in the extent to which they have a clear understanding of the factors affecting their relationships and clear goals for treatment and how their own contributions affect the achievement of their goals. Therapist determines the appropriate sequence of addressing goals in therapy. Extinguish undesired behavior and reinforce positive alternatives. Ignoring the tantrum; rewarding the child for putting feelings into words Redefine the family's goals of decreasing negative behavior into increasing positive responses. Families have difficulty describing the behavior they want to see more of The therapist helps by asking families to make a list of things the other person did that they liked throughout the week. Reviewing the list in session the next week provides an opportunity to emphasize the importance of positive feedback. This agenda of therapy is educational: Teach communication, problem-solving, and negotiation Behavior will change when the contingencies of reinforcement are altered. Identify behavioral goals Learn techniques to achieve these goals Facilitate social reinforcement of change Brief (about 20 weekly sessions) Use of homework assignments Phase out therapy gradually. Once the family shows evidence of substituting positive interactions for negative ones and goals are achieved. Booster sessions Collaborate with families in designing homework to complete between sessions. Homework is based on the learning principle that to replace existing ingrained dysfunctional interactional patterns with new ones, families rehearse the new patterns repeatedly, particularly under 'real life conditions.' CBFT has been popular in two primary sub-systems: All couples run into conflict. Conflict resolution is a critical skill. Healthy families are not problem free, but they can resolve conflicts when they arise. They describe their own feelings and request changes in the behavior of others rather than criticizing or complaining. Good relationships are not made in heaven, they are a product of learning effective coping behavior. Families need problem solving skills Therapy includes: Clinical interview Rating specific behaviors Relationship satisfaction questionnaires Couples are taught to express themselves in clear, behavioral descriptions, rather than in vague complaints. Couples are taught new behavior exchange procedures, emphasizing positive reinforcement. Couples are helped to improve their communication. Couples are encouraged to establish clear and effective decision-making. Couples are taught strategies to problem-solve future complaints to extend the benefits of therapy. Ask each partner to list three things they would like the other to do more often. Imagery Role-play Coaching (to switch places, to increase their empathy for one another's feelings) Communication training For example: Engaging in an argument without attacking
'I' statements (Using 'I' Statements.pdf)
Speaker listener exercises (Practice Exercise (Speaker Listener Activity)) Problem-solving training Homework assignments Mindfulness and meditation Sensate focus (p. 164) In vivo desensitization (p. 164) Parents ahve control over the rewards and punishment of children. If parents change the contingencies of reinforcement, the child's behavior will change. Skills are taught in sequence (shaping) Help parents define the child's positive and problematic behaviors in specific observable actions. Tracking target behaviors Reinforcing desired behavior through contigent encouragement with incentive charts.
Disciplinary tehcniques include Time-Out and ignoring the problem behavior. Observe/Assess the frequency of problem behavior, what precedes it, and what reinforcement follows (Behavior Chaining) Shaping (reinforcing small steps toward change)
Token Economy (reward good behavior) Contingency contracting (agreements by parents to make certain changes following changes made by their child)
Time-Out Once assessment is complete, the therapist decides which behaviors should be increased or decreased. Once effective rewards are chosen, parents are taught to shape desired behavior by reinforcing approximate behaviors. Ignoring Rewards Identifying Automatic Thoughts Assist family members in identifying automatic thoughts To improve the skills of identifying automatic thoughts, clients are encouraged to keep a diary to jot down situations that provoke the thoughts and the resulting emotional reactions. Joining with all members of the family simultaneously can be challenging. Families in conflict often desire to form an alliance with the therapist, each family member trying to convince the therapist that the other members are responsible for relationship problems. Do not be triangulated! CBFT therapists hear the seriousness of the concerns while not siding with individual family members. CBFT therapists use empathic reflective listening with one family member and then the other, followed by statements summarizing the reciprocal interwoven concerns of all members. CBFT therapists are a neutral party whose agenda is to help family members achieve their personal goals for family relationships. CBFT therapists often define relationship problems in 'dyadic terms.' Blocking (e.g., interrupting) if necessary Inclusion of other individuals if necessary Medication, and individual therapy can be used in conjunction with CBFT Co-therapy model is allowed Both individual and conjoint sessions are allowed. Clients may be more likely to divulge information about their past in private sessions. CBFT therapists tell clients they will keep this information confidential, but if it might be influencing the family's current interactions, they encourage the person to share it in a joint session Secrets Be up front with clients about the limits of confidentiality Assist them with sharing in a joint session (rather than outing them) Didactic role early on to strike a balance between directiveness and collaborationl Reviews homework assignments, model skills, coaches family members in practicing them, and fosters motivation. Balances alliances and interventions with all the family members or subsystems so that they feel supported. Sets the pace of sessions so that the goals of treatment are addressed in a timely and sequential fashion. Sets the agenda each session Monitors the use of time Responsible to stay on task and address the goals of session Teaches the clients to self monitor as well Maintains control of the session with confidence and credibility Assumes multiple roles: Director Educator Facilitator Collaborator Advocate Balances the alliance and interventions with all members, so they feel supported and invested. Primary Goals: Identify the concerns and potential areas of enrichment/growth. Clarify the cognitive, behavioral, and affective factors associated with family members, dyadic subsystems, and the family environment. Determine the appropriateness of family therapy Including each family members' level of commitment and goals for treatment. Information gathering: Self-report questionnaires, clinical interviews, observation of interactional patterns Initial conjoint interviews: How the couple met, what attracted them to each other, how they developed a deeper involvement, positive and negative life events, prior experiences in therapy. Inquires about the family members' current concerns and strengths of the relationship. Orients the family to the process of therapy by describing the structure and course of CBFT and the roles of therapist and family. Increasing the frequency and magnitude and positive behaviors Love days Date night Departing with a kiss "Work together with the family to develop a series of agreements on how they want to make changes in their relationships to meet the needs of the family members, to help their relationship function effectively, and to interact positively with their environment." (Gurman et al., 2015, p. 36) For sharing thoughts and emotions (p.38) For listening (p. 38) For decision-making conversations (p. 38) "The therapist provides the family with instruction in the use of particular behavioral skills, through didactic discussions and/or other media (e.g., readings, videos). The instruction is followed by opportunities for the family to practice behaving in the new ways." Selective Attention What each person notices about the partner and the relationship Attributions Inferences about determinants of relationship events Expectancies Predictions of what will occur in the relationship in the future Assumptions What each person believes people and relationships actually are like Standards What each person believes people and relationships should look like Socratic Questioning Understanding the underlying issues through evaluations of the logic of thinking Guided Discovery Clarify each person's standards. Discuss advantages and disadvantages of existing standards. If standards need alteration, help revise them to form new acceptable standards. Problem solve how new standards will be taken into account behaviorally. If partners standards continue to differ, discuss ability to accept differences. Normalize emotional experiences, positive and negative Clarify thoughts, then relate these to emotions Use questions, reflections, and interpretations to draw out primary emotions Describe emotions through metaphors and images Discourage attempts to distract the self from experiencing emotions Encourage acceptance of the individual's experience by family members For example, asking one family member to recount a particular incident in detail while helping the individual enrich their expression in a way that helps the individual and the family. Schedule times to discuss emotions and related thoughts with your partner/family member Practice 'health compartmentalization' Seek alternative means to communicate feelings and elicit support Tolerate distressing feelings Roles become familiar and predictable Knowledge and skill deficit Reluctant to change due to being hurt in the relationship Intimate partner aggression Infidelity Individual psychopathology Health problems Obsessive-compulsive disorder Anorexia nervosa Widely evaluated Found to be efficacious for distressed couples and families and improving relationship functioning Effective in alleviating distress and improving communication Effects have been found in relatively brief interventions (lasting 8-12 weeks) Finding generalize across continents with experienced and student therapists Most families appear to maintain gains in relational adjustment for up to 1 year.

item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 3. Structural Family Therapy
item.description:
Salvador Minuchin (1921-2017) Physician in the Israeli army Trained in psychoanalysis in the US Studied interpersonal psychiatry with Harry Stack Sullivan Worked with delinquent boys at the Wiltwyck School - where foundation for family therapy was laid. Director of the Philadelphia Child Guidance clinic Why did Minuchin go into family therapy? He sees families in terms of particular shapes, particular stages He sees himself as an instrument, a challenger of patterns
Family is depicted as a system that is comprised of Subsystems A family is functional to the degree that it nurtures its members to negotiate well the demands of the outside world. Boundaries set limits distinguishing subsystems from one another in varying permeability (from diffuse to rigid). Subsystems separated by a diffuse boundary are enmeshed, whereas subsystems separated by a rigid boundary are disengaged. Family
Structure Structure is expressed through transactional patterns such as:
Hierarchy
Power Alliances
Subsystem (couple, parent, sibling)
Boundaries
Coalition
Patterns
Triangles
Loyalties The family could have developed a structure different from the dysfunctional one now being displayed. The family processes adaptive resources in its relational repertoire that currently lie dormant. Therapy attempts to activate what is already there, but latent. Offers a framework that brings order and meaning to family transactions. The consistent patterns of family behavior reveal family structure. The emotional boundaries and coalitions that make up a family's structure are abstractions. The concept of family structure enables therapists to intervene in a systematic and organized way. Families seek help for a specific problem. Family therapists look beyond the specifics of those problems to the family's attempts to solve them. Exploring dynamics of interaction. Recognizing the overall organization of the family regulates those interactions. The model attends to subsystems and boundaries that regular contact between members. The model emphasizes enactments wherein family members are encouraged to deal directly with one another in session, permitting the therapist to observe and modify their interactions. Structural family therapy provides therapists with a blueprint for how to view patterns of family dynamics.
The three major concepts of structural family therapy are Structure, Boundaries, and Subsystems.
Subsystem (Couple; Parent; Sibling) Problems are symptomatic of the family's inability to be flexible and accommodating of changing needs. All family behavior, even destructive behavior, has the goal of balancing the system to ensure its survival. Family problems do not result from stresses in the system but from the effects of reactions and responses to the stresses. Structure is: The way a family is organized into subsystems whose interactions are regulated by interpersonal boundaries. The organized pattern in which families interact Patterns are formed based on rules that are implicit or explicit. Over time, as patterns develop, roles for family members are established. Patterns are isomorphic (i.e., interaction patterns are repeated in different relationships in a system). The focus of treatment is on changing the family structure rather than changing individual family members. The process of family interaction is like the patterns of conversation at the dinner table. The structure of the family is where family members sit in relation to one another. As family transactions are repeated, they foster expectations that establish enduring patterns. Family structure is reinforced by the expectations that establish rules in a family. Families are differentiated into subsystems based on generation, gender, or function. Adults are the 'organizational leaders' of the family system so whatever is present in the adult subsystem relationship will be felt throughout the whole system. Children are common 'symptom bearers' Organization is most healthy when there are 3 clearly defined systems: Marital/Couple Parental Child/Sibling Each subsystem is demarcated by interpersonal boundaries. Boundaries range from rigid to diffuse. Defined as rules for managing physical and psychological distance between family members and for defining regulation of closeness, hierarchy, and family roles. Rigid boundaries are restrictive and permit little contact with outside subsystems, resulting in disengagement. Disengaged systems are independent, but isolated. On the plus side, this fosters autonomy. But limits affection and support. Diffuse boundaries result in enmeshment. Enmeshed systems offer closeness, but at the expense of independence. Too much closeness can cripple initiative. Determines who (or which subsystem) has power in the system. Any structure in a family is not static, it is developed over time. Hierarchies can be rigid and unfair or weak and ineffective. Be aware of cross-generational coalitions. Accommodation requires the family system to be flexible and alert to changing needs of individuals in the family. Boundary making refers to the demarcation of subsystems as they are formed. In accommodating to each other, a couple must establish a boundary between them, as well as a boundary separating them from the outside. The addition of children transform the structure of a family into a parental subsystem and child subsystem. Even in healthy families, children often bring stress and conflict. Children require different styles of parenting at different ages. Minuchin warned therapists not to mistake growing pains for pathology. What distinguishes healthy families isn't the absence of problems, but a functional structure for dealing with them. "The problem behavior is a symptom of the dysfunctional structure of the family system." Disengaged or enmeshed subsystems Hierarchies are weak and ineffective; or rigid & arbitrary Conflict avoidance Detouring which results in a scapegoat Cross-generational coalition (where hierarchy may be inverted) Modifications in structure are required when a family or one of its members encounters external pressure (a parent is laid off) or a developmental transition occurs (e.g., parents retire). Healthy families accommodate to their changed circumstances, dysfunctional families increase the rigidity of structures that no longer work (e.g., strict parenting tightening up further when a child acts out and needs nurturance). Families are susceptible to develop a dysfunctional structure during periods of: Normative life cycle transition The arrival of a first child An adult child leaving home An acute stressor Natural Disaster Unemployment Single Adult Coupling Having Children Families with Young Children Families with School-Age Children Families with Adolescents Divorce Blended Families Launching Children Later Life Early on the model shifted from why family members interact the way they do, and the past, to how they learned to act that way. Now, the model considers not only how family members interact, but also how and why they learned to do so. All behavior makes sense in context. The mechanism of change is the production of new relational experiences for families. Families change each other by behaving differently toward each other.
Enactment refers to those moments in therapy when family members interact directly with each other.
Enactment is not necessarily a technique. It typically occurs naturally in session. It is the 'here-and-now' of the therapy session. Alter the organization of a family so that its members can solve their own problems. The goal is structural change; problem-solving is a by-product. Problems are embedded in dysfunctional structures. Activate adaptive patterns that are already in families repertoires. Create effective hierarchy: Parents should be in charge, not relate to their children as equals. Differentiate individuals and subsystems by strengthening the boundaries around them. Increase contact by making boundaries more permeable. The therapist produces change by joining the family, probing for areas of flexibility, and then activating formant structural alternatives. Joining conveys acceptance of family members and respect for their ways of doing things. Only after joining can the therapist attempt restructuring. Understand the family's view of their problems by tracking their perspectives (words they use to explain problems and the behavior with which they demonstrate them).
Enactment s reveal structural patterns and later change them. Take-Away: Observe and modify the structure of family transactions in the immediate context of the session. The therapist manages the nuts-and-bolts details of how the therapy process is structured including: Who should attend How often Referrals for psychiatric evaluation Therapy aims to change how family members experience each other. Family members are expected to be present together for sessions. Relational experiences can 'wash out' between sessions, therefore, therapy usually starts out weekly. Join the family accommodate to its members' style (building alliance) Map the family structure, boundaries, and hierarchy (evaluating and assessing structure) Intervene to transform the structure to diminish symptoms (addressing the problems identified in the assessment) Observe and assess how family members respond to their dilemmas. Because problems are a function of the entire family structure, it's important to include the whole group for assessment. Some problems may be treated individually. Problems can persist in individuals, in the social context, or the feedback between them. Individual problems need to be identified and appropriate. Structural therapists prefer to begin therapy with the entire family, but they do not insist on it. Once the family has been assessed, the therapist often meets with specific subsystems and individuals to achieve structured goals. Role of the symptoms in the family
Subsystems
Cross-Generational Coalition
Boundaries
Hierarchy
Complementarity
Family Life Cycle Strengths Ask questions about the presenting problem until family members begin to see that the problem goes beyond the symptom bearer to include the entire family. Assist family members in seeing how their interactions may be perpetuating the presenting problem. Briefly explore the past, focusing on how the adults in the family came to develop the perspectives that influence their interactions. Explore options that family members might take to interact in more productive ways to create a shift in the family structure and help resolve the presenting problem. Greet the family Ask for each person's view of the problem Listen carefully Acknowledge what you hear Model empathy that family members are temporarily not able to provide Acknowledgement (feeling heard and understood) releases family members from resentment Joining opens the way for family members to begin listening to one another and establishes a bond with the therapist that enables them to accept the challenges to come. Intervention Language: Joined with the Family Engaged in Reflective Listening Built Rapport Acknowledged Reflected Summarized Validated Elicited Emphasized Challenged Reinforced Maintain an outsider perspective to remain objective, while becoming familiar with family's experiential reality. Unless therapist is allowed to become part of the new system, no change will take place. Respect the family, and its individual members, despite presenting problem (i.e., abuse) The therapist joins the system in the sense that they accommodate to its style; how people talk, what words they use, how they walk, and so forth. Make contact with each member of the family Greeting, shaking hands (pre-COVID) Using names Noticing something unique about each of the members Find something similar about each person and then allow the family members to recognize the similarity Skills involved in joining: Accommodating: Matching the family's style of language with gestures or subject matter (being 'familiar' to the family) Being interested in the family's interests (i.e., baseball). Validating: Validate the worth of each family member. Searching for Competencies: Therapist enhances self-esteem by discovering and validating competencies.
During joining, assess the Family Structure:
Hierarchy Who has the most power? The position members take in relation to each other (emotional closeness between members).
Boundaries between Subsystem Assume authority for the structure of therapy. Maintain control so things do not go awry. Lead by following. Be able to interrupt. Make demands, rather than polite, requests. Inviting the family to schedule the next session. Validating ambivalence about coming again. Need to expand family's view of problem to include all family members. Therapist is less concerned with the content of the message than with how it is transmitted, to whom, and with what effect.
Process messages usually describe the power structure of the family, Hierarchy, Boundaries, emotional tone, and Family Rules. Attending to process = accommodation when the therapist responds to the underlying affect in the manner in which the statement is made. Process comments are better when kept general. The therapist notices a problematic sequence (a hunch). The therapist initiates an enactment (talk this over with your partner). The therapist guides the family to modify the enactment (offering encouragement as needed).
Enmeshment Watch for interruptions, speaking for one another, doing things for one another that they can do for themselves, arguing.
Disengagement Watch for passivity, absence of emotion, absence of conflict, ignoring, lack of concern for other's interests. When the enactment breaks down: Comment on what went wrong. Push them to keep going. Assess interactions in session. Families tend to quickly induct therapists in their culture. Take into account both the problem the family presents and the structural dynamics it displays. Once families begin to interact, problematic transactions emerge. Recognizing structure requires focusing on process, not content. Achieve intensity by selective regulation of affect, repetition, and duration. Tone, volume, pacing, and choice of words can be used to raise the affective intensity of interventions.
Pay attention to Coalitions Temper tantrums are maintained by parents who give in. They try not to give in; they just don't try long enough.
Empathy: Use empathy to go beneath defensiveness. Interrupt squabbling and using empathy talk with each family member at a time about what they're feeling.
Shaping Competence: A particular method of modifying interaction, reinforcing positives, reinforcing use of functional alternatives already in the family's repertoire. Invite family members to speak for themselves. Block interruptions. Assist dyads in finishing conversations without intrusion. Although structural family therapy begins with the whole family, subsequent sessions may be held with individuals or subgroups to strengthen boundaries. Asking family members to change seats. Asking family members to move seats further apart or closer together or turn toward one another. Having separate sessions with individuals or subsystems to strengthen boundaries. Asking one or more members to remain silent during an interaction. Asking questions that highlight a problem boundary area (e.g., do you always answer for your son when he is asked a question?) Blocking interruptions or encouraging pauses to enable less dominant persons to speak. The goal in unbalancing is to change the relationship within the subsystem. The therapist joins and supports one individual or subsystem. While taking sides seems like a violation of neutrality, this is done to unbalance and realign the system (note that fairness is achieved because the therapist sides with family members in turn). Tools/Techniques:
Reframing
Complementarity
Intensity
Enactment The therapist sometimes challenges the way clients see things. Act as a teacher, offering information and advice, often about structural matters. Stroke and a Kick: To mother, "You are very helpful." (Stroke) To daughter, "Mommy sometimes takes away your voice. Can you speak for yourself?" (Kick) After the family's view of the problem has been enlarged by process comments and family is familiar with therapeutic process. Therapist can present the family with a different perspective of the problem that allows them to activate new behaviors (in a new situation) To formulate a reframe the therapist brings together the verbal and nonverbal messages. Should take into account every member. Should like the family problem with the rules of the structure. Should not be explained to the family. As family members describe their problems, therapists reflect on their understanding systemic reframing, which takes into account all behavior as reciprocal. Use family's language. Use family's content. Include everyone. Ensure the reframe has a nonjudgemental, non-blaming focus, and better still, has positive connotations. Be prepared to restate the reframe in several different ways. Avoid intrapsychic interpretations and why-because aspects in forming the reframe. Realize that there is no perfect reframe. Structural mapping is used as an assessment tool for understanding interaction patterns. Blocking: Stopping usual transactions. Exaggerating: Encouraging or sustaining interactions. Silence: When a response is expected, doing the unusual by not giving one - thus demanding the family to act. All unbalancing, if successful, will heighten tension and intensity to fuel family to move toward change. Actively shift the focus of the family from solving the presenting problem to changing the family structure. The therapist must unbalance the family's old patterns. The model directs therapists to look beyond the content of problems and even beyond the dynamics of interaction to the underlying family organization that supports and contains those interactions. The most important tenet in that every family has a structure, and this structure is revealed only when the family is in action. Strongest empirical support comes from a series of studies on children with psychosomatic symptoms and young adults addicted to drugs. Early structural family therapy studies demonstrated effectiveness in treating disruptive behavior and adolescent substance use. More recent, studies have shown that structural family therapy can be effective when addressing problem behavior spanning the externalizing spectrum (e.g., disruptive behavior, adolescent substance use, conduct disorder, ADHD) Treatment is concerned only with the relief of the family's suffering. Interventions are limited to relief of suffering, thus treatment may be brief (<6 sessions) Therapist must be more flexible than the family. Focused on change not insight (how not why of dysfunction). Therapist should be in charge of all communications and coordination with collaborators. The self of the therapist is one of the primary tools for facilitating change. Therapists must use themselves to relate to the family, varying from being highly involved to professionally detached (depending on the family's needs).
Salvador Minuchin encouraged new therapists to reflect on aspects of their personal and relational lives that shape their therapeutic process and client behavior in session. Describe 'who you are' as a therapist. How will 'who you are' as a therapist impact therapy with families? What are your personal strengths? What are your growth areas? Strongest empirical support comes from a series of studies on children with psychosomatic symptoms and young adults addicted to drugs. Early structural family therapy studies demonstrated effectiveness in treating disruptive behavior and adolescent substance use. More recently, studies have shown that structural family therapy can be effective when addressing problem behavior spanning the externalizing spectrum (e.g., disruptive behavior, adolescent substance use, conduct disorder, ADHD). Similar to all family therapy approaches, structural family therapy is not effective in all cases. No research identifies readily observable characteristics shared by failed cases of structural family therapy. Developed to work with poor urban families, at all socioeconomic levels, ethnic groups, sexual orientations, and across countries. Indirect empirical support, as research on efficacy has focused on applicability to family treatment. Studies that directly test structural family therapy's efficacy in the treatment of various presenting problems and targeted populations are needed. Efficacy 'refers to treatment effects observed in randomized controlled trials.' Effectiveness 'refers to treatment effects in routine practice.' Currently, the evidence does not show that any of the demonstrably efficacious approaches to family therapy are more effective than other approaches, largely because there is a dearth of evidence on the efficacy of many widely used family therapy approaches. Family therapy research has had little impact on the day-to-day practice of family therapists. The disconnection between research and practice is alarming. This may be attributed to, 'An overemphasis by researchers.. On treatment packages and therapeutic models/techniques.' Insufficient attention has been paid to sources of influence on treatment outcomes (the skills of the the therapist themselves) Effective family therapy requires a good 'fit' between the person of the therapist and their primary theoretical orientation. Family therapy is shifting to research that addresses the process aspects of the therapeutic models. It is important to remember there are multiple ways of knowing what works: Randomized control trials Case studies data Observations of therapists and clients Collecting qualitative or quantitative Remember: Research lags behind practice in family therapy. Just because a model has been tested doesn't inherently mean it is superior. Heteronormative Pathologizing (seeing problems are embedded in dysfunctional family structures) Family mapping implies pathology resides in family structure, but this is not true. Problems are viewed as a failure to adjust to changing circumstances.
