item.title: GLM 2
item.description:
Multiple Linear RegressionSimple Linear Regression Analyze -> Regression -> Linear Define DV and IV (one IV for SLR) Drag Outcome variable into the 'Dependent' box
Drag the Predictor variable into the 'Block 1 of 1' box In the Statistics menu, select Estimates, Confidence Intervals, Model Fit, and Descriptive.
The default SPSS output has 3 sections: Model Summary (How much variance in DV is explained by the model) ANOVA Table (Model significance) Regression Coefficients (Equation for the regression line)
We use SLR to investigate how one variable (x or the Independent Variable) explains the variability (Variance) in the other variable (y or the Dependent Variable). If x is indeed a significant Predictor of y, we can use x to predict y.
We only have one Predictor (Independent Variable) in the model. In SLR, Multiple R = |rxy|
R-squared is the proportion of the variance in the Dependent Variable (y) that can be explained (accounted for) by the Independent Variable s / Predictor s in the model (x's) In SLR, R-squared equals the square of the Pearson correlation between x and y (r-squared). 'Ballpark' estimates for Pearson correlation coefficient r: r = ± .2 (weak) r = ± .4 (moderate) r = ± .8 (strong) It also depends on the nature of variables, studies, and fields (literature review). Cohen's (1988) standards for Pearson correlation coefficient r: r = ± .1 (weak) r = ± .3 (moderate) r = ± .5 (strong) R-squared = .448 in the example above. 44.8% of the variation in kid's scores on the cognitive test is accounted for by their mother's IQ. Total variability (variance) in DV is partitioned into two parts: - What we can explain by the model (regression) - What we still cannot explain (error)
Mediation Is the regression model good enough to be used to explain/predict DV? Since we are comparing variances (SSR and SSE), the sample statistics is compared to a critical F statistics, given the significance level (usually α=. 05). General idea: Large observed F means much variance in DV can be explained by the model (desired)! H0: β1 = 0 H1: β1 ≠ 0 H0: y-hat = y-bar H1: y-hat = b0 +b1x (DV cannot be predicted by model) H0: ρ = 0 (ρ is the population correlation between model and data, estimated by Multiple R) H1: ρ > 0 H0: ρ2 = 0 H1: ρ2 > 0 Compare Fobs to the critical F(1, n -2) Reject H0 if Fobs > F(1, n -2) Alternatively, reject H0 if p < α For APA style writing, make sure you report the F statistic along with both degrees of freedom and the p-value.
For the example, the Omnibus test results in the ANOVA table show that the model significantly predicts the Dependent Variable, (F(1,432) = 108.643, p < .001) Pasted image 20250129080138.png
MLR is used when you want to understand the relationship between one Dependent Variable and two or more Independent Variable. It is commonly applied in scenarios such as: Predicting Outcomes For example, predicting house prices based on square footage, number of bedrooms, and location. Understanding Relationships For example, analyzing how factors like advertising spend, produce price, and customer satisfaction influence sales. Controlling for Confounding Variables For example, studying the effect of education level on income while controlling for age and work experience.
The residuals (errors) have constant Variance across all levels of Independent Variable s. How to Check Plot residuals vs. Predicted values Look for a random scatter. In SPSS: request Linear Regression Plots. Y > ZPred X > Z Resid If the scatterplot shows no overall pattern, the assumption is met.
Example Check if the spread of residuals is consistent across predicted house prices. Solution Apply transformations or use weighted least squares. Testing Homoscedasticity
Pasted image 20250129081552.png
Include Model Fit, R-squared change, Descriptives, Part and Partial Correlations, and Collinearity Diagnostics Confidence intervals are not necessary but can be helpful. Utilize Cook's Distance under the 'Residuals Statistics' Table
If the maximum Cook's distance is below 1.0, then the assumption is met. Other tests may give a different cutoff point, but for our purposes we will use 1.0. Testing for Extreme Outliers
Observations are independent of each other (no Autocorrelation) How to Check Use the Durbin-Watson test. If the Durbin-Watson test falls within the range of 1.5 - 2.5, the assumption is met. Examples
For this example, we'll say 1.482 is close enough to 1.5 and the assumption is met. Ensure house prices are not influenced by neighboring houses. Solutions
Use Time-Series Design if data is Autocorrelation. Testing the Independence of Error
In Multiple Linear Regression (MLR) multicollinearity is said to exist when two or more of the independent variables are themselves highly correlated, a situation that makes it difficult to establish the effect each has on the dependent variable. How to Check
Calculate the Variance Inflation Factor (VIF). Values above 5-10 indicate multicollinearity. Example Check if square footage and number of bedrooms are highly correlated. Solution Remove or combine correlated variables.
Autocorrelation Multicollinearity
Dependent Y variable Block Use next and previous buttons for blocks of variables Independent (s) x-variables Method Allows you to use stepwise, never use this Always use paste to send the analysis to the syntax editor and save your work. Analyze -> Regression -> Linear
Move Dependent Variable to Dependent. Move Independent Variable (s) to the Independent (s). In Statistics, select Estimates (Under Regression Coefficients), Model Fit, Descriptives, and Durbin-Watson (Under Residuals). Click Continue. In Plots, select Histogram and Normal Probability Plot (Under Standardized Residual Plots). Move ZPRED under Y. Move ZRESID to X. Click Continue. In Save, select Cook's (Under Distances). Click Continue. Click OK. An assessment of the normality of data is a prerequisite for many statistical tests because normal data is an underlying assumption in parametric testing. SPSS allows you to test all of these procedures within Explore command. The Explore command can be used in isolation if you are testing normality in one group or splitting your dataset into one or more groups. If you have 2 or more categorical, independent variables, the Explore command on its own is not enough and you will have to use the Split File command also. Click Analyze -> Descriptives -> Explore
Transfer the variable that needs to be tested for normality into the Dependent List box. Click on Statistics. Leave Descriptives selected. Click the Plots. Select Factor Levels Together under Boxplots. Select Stem-and-Leaf under Descriptive. Select Normality Plots with Tests. When testing for normality, we are mainly interested in the Tests of Normality table and the Normal Q-Q Plots, our numerical and graphical methods to test for the normality of data, respectively.
The above table presents the results from two well-known tests of normality, namely the Kolmogorov-Smirnov Test and the Shapiro-Wilk. The Shapiro-Wilk Test is more appropriate for small sample sizes (<50 samples), but can also handle sample sizes as large as 2000. If the Sig. value of the Shapiro-Wilk Test is greater than p = .05, the data is normal. If it is below 0.05, the data significantly deviate from a normal distribution.
In order to determine normality graphically, we can use the output of a normal P-P plot. If the data are normally distributed, the data points will be close to the diagonal line. If the data points stray from the line in an obvious non-linear fashion, the data are not normally distributed. If the points are generally along the diagonal, the assumption is met. If you are at all unsure of being able to correctly interpret the graph, rely on the numeric methods instead because it can take a fair bit of experience to correctly judge the normality of data based on plots.
If the histogram is approximately normal, the assumption is met. The distribution curve is normal/bell shaped. The assumption is met if the skewness and kurtosis is between +2 and -2. The Explore command on its own cannot separate the dependent variable into groups based on not one but two or more independent variables. However, we can perform this feat by using the Split File command. Click Data -> Split File Click Organize Output by Groups. Transfer the independent variables you wish to categorize the dependent variable on into the Groups Based On box. Proceed as above. Testing for Normality
The relationship between the Dependent Variable and each Independent Variable is linear. How to Check Use scatterplots to visualize relationships. Click Graphs > Legacy Dialogs > Scatter/Dot. Click Simple Scatter. Click Define.
Move your Dependent Variable (Outcome) to the Y-Axis. Move your Independent Variable (Predictor) to the X-Axis If the scatterplot is approximately linear, the assumption is met.
Example Plot house price against square footage to see if the relationship linear. Solution If not linear, apply transformations (e.g., log, square root) Testing Linearity
You can save residuals as their own variables to detect multivariate outliers. Predicted values tell you what SPSS thinks the y value should be based on the x-values of the case. Residual values are how far off SPSS was Mahalanobis distance tells you how far away a case is from the 'cloud' of other values.

item.title: Project Outline
item.description: The capacity to maintain one's own identity (thoughts, values, and beliefs) while remaining emotionally connected to others. Murray Bowen introduced this concept to explain how individuals manage anxiety and stress by separating thinking from emotional reactivity. Refers to the intensity and immediacy of emotional responses. Highly reactive individuals may be overwhelmed by stress, clouding rational thinking. Example. An individual who becomes instantly upset over minor criticism, indicating difficulty in self-regulating. A strategy to manage anxiety by distancing oneself from emotionally charged relationships. Example. An adult who avoids family reunions to escape unresolved conflicts. Although cutoff can reduce immediate distress, it prevents long-term resolution and growth. Describe overly close, undifferentiated relationships where boundaries are blurred. Example. A person who mirrors a parent's moods and opinions to the point of losing their own identity. The ability to assert one's own beliefs and maintain a distinct sense of self even under pressure from family members. Clinical implication Strengthening the I-position is a key therapeutic goal, helping clients balance intimacy with independence. Lower differentiation is associated with chronic anxiety, dependency, and interpersonal difficulties. Studies on dyadic adjustment (e.g., Lampisa's work) show that higher differentiation correlates with more satisfying intimate relationships. A triangle is formed when a two-person (dyadic) relationship becomes unstable due to anxiety, prompting the includsion of a third party to diffuse tension. Triangles are considered the smallest stable emotional unit in a family. They serve to distribute and manage anxiety but can also perpetuate problematic dynamics.

item.title: Assignment 4
item.description: This classwork/homework assignment is a multiple imputation activity. You will continue to use data from the Early Childhood Longitudinal Study-Kindergarten 2011 Cohort. The classwork/homework write-up is due by Tuesday at 11:59PM (3/18). The data you need come from two sources. The first is the data file you have been working on for class activities the last several week. The second is located in this week's folder. A researcher wants to know whether maternal depressive symptoms are associated with children’s early learning and development. But before the researcher can address this question, you are asked to think about and address missing data. The researcher has provided you with several variables in addition to the variables you have worked with thus far: You are asked to include an overall composite of depressive symptoms. The research provides you with 12 items that you are asked to composite (P2BOTHER P2APPETI P2BLUE P2KPMIND P2DEPRES P2EFFORT P2FEARFL P2RESTLS P2TALKLS P2LONELY P2SAD P2NOTGO). You will also include three child variables: a) a variable capturing children’s academic achievement, b) a variable capturing children’s socioemotional skills, and c) a variable capturing children’s executive functioning. For the academic achievement measure, you will need to create a new composite variable that is composed of reading, math, and science (X2RSCALK4 X2MSCALK4 X2SSCALK4). For socioemotional skills, you will need to create a new variable that is the average of teacher reports of self-control, interpersonal skills, externalizing behavior, and internalizing behavior (i.e., X2TCHINT X2TCHEXT X2TCHCON X2TCHPER). Children’s executive functioning skills are captured with a single item: X2DCCSTOT. The researcher also wants you to include covariates/indicators for race/ethnicity (X_RACETH_R), child sex (X_CHSEX_R), income (X2INCCAT_I), parents’ marital status (P1CURMAR), parents physical health (P2HEALTH), household members under 18 (X1LESS18), and household members over 18 (X1OVER18) . With that in mind...Step 1: You need to merge the new data into the dataset you have been working with. This requires a 1 to 1 merge using CHILDID. This step will be graded via your do/log files (.25 points)Step 2: Once the data are merged, examine your data. Orient yourself to the old and new variables (e.g., are they continuous, categorical etc etc) and recode any new variables as appropriate. Recall how Stata recognizes missing data. Please also create the appropriate composites prior to imputation. The composites will be what you will use in your imputation. If you recode other variables, please provide a justification. This step will be graded via your do/log files and your justification in your word document. (.25 points) Step 3: Once you have cleaned your data, run some descriptives for all of your variables (including your covariates) and determine the degree of missing values for each variable. Please also estimate a correlation matrix for your focal independent and dependent variables (do not include the list of covariates for your correlation matrix). What  patterns you notice from the descriptive statistics? How much missing data are there for the variables? What patterns do you notice from the correlation matrix? (1.00 point) Step 4: Determine whether data are MCAR. Examine and discuss the missing data patterns. Are there common patterns of missing data? Are there uncommon patterns of missing data? Anything you notice worth discussing? If data are not MCAR, discuss whether the data may meet assumptions of MAR or MNAR. Why or why not? If you have any concerns proceeding to imputation, discuss it here. (1.25 points) Step 5: Run an imputation model with 10 datasets. Make sure you specify each variable correctly. And remember to upload your do and log files (for the entire assignment). This step will be graded via your do file (1.00 point) Step 6: After you have run your imputation, estimate descriptives within the 10 imputed datasets. You do not have to do this for every variable. Run these descriptives for the focal variables of interest (depressive symptoms, children's academic achievement, social skills, and executive functioning). Use the mi xeq command (e.g., mi xeq: sum XYZ). Discuss what you notice about the means/SDs across the imputations. (1.00 point)Step 7. Estimate correlations (use mi xeq: corr) among your focal variables from step 1, but this time within your 10 datasets. Are there any similarities between the imputed and non-imputed data? Are there any other differences you notice? (.75 points) Step 8. Upload your word document, log file, and do file. Please upload stata versions of your log/do files (not copied/pasted into word).
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Mediation
item.description:
Single Mediation
Moderation Mediation examines how the effect of an independent variable (IV) on a dependent variable (DV) is transmitted through a third variable, called the mediator (M). In simple mediation, there is one mediator. To determine if the IV influences the DV directly and/or indirectly via the mediator. The model splits the total effect into The portion of the effect of IV on DV that is not explained by the mediator. The portion of the effect that is transmitted from IV to DV through the mediator. Relationships among IV, mediator, and DV are linear. Scatterplots: Go to Graphs > Legacy Dialogs > Scatter/Dot and plot DV vs. IV and DV vs. M. Look for a straight-line pattern. Residuals vs. Predicted Plot: Run Analyze > Regression > Linear…; click Plots… to assign standardized predicted values (X-axis) and standardized residuals (Y-axis). Criteria: No systematic pattern (i.e., randomness, with any curve test yielding p > .05). Residuals have constant variance across all levels of predictors. Examine the same residuals vs. predicted plot for an even spread (no funnel shape). Residuals are approximately normally distributed. Create histograms and Q–Q plots using Graphs > Legacy Dialogs > Histogram or Q–Q plot options. Criteria: Skewness values less than |2.0| and kurtosis values less than |7.0|; Q–Q plot points should lie near the diagonal line. Observations are independent. Confirm via your study design. Review the Durbin–Watson statistic from your regression output (values between 1.5 and 2.5 are acceptable). There are no unmeasured variables that confound the relationship between the mediator and DV. This is primarily a design issue; however, consider including control variables if needed. Go to Analyze > Regression > PROCESS vX by Andrew Hayes Choose Model 4 (designed for simple mediation). Set the DV, IV, and mediator in the appropriate boxes. Enable bootstrapping (commonly set to 5,000 samples) to obtain robust confidence intervals (CIs) for the indirect effect. Click OK. Direct Path (IV → M): Example: a = 0.40, SE = 0.10, p = .001 Path from Mediator to DV (M → DV, controlling for IV): Example: b = 0.50, SE = 0.12, p = .002 Indirect Effect (a × b): Example: 0.40 × 0.50 = 0.200.40 \times 0.50 = 0.20 Bootstrapped 95% CI: [0.08, 0.35] (does not include zero → significant mediation). Direct Effect (IV → DV controlling for M): Example: c′ = 0.25, SE = 0.09, p = .005 Total Effect (IV → DV without mediator): Example: c = 0.45, SE = 0.10, p < .001 A mediation analysis was conducted using the PROCESS macro (Model 4) with 5,000 bootstrap samples to examine whether [Mediator] mediated the relationship between [IV] and [DV]. The total effect of [IV] on [DV] was significant (b = 0.45, SE = 0.10, p < .001). When [Mediator] was entered into the model, the direct effect decreased (b = 0.25, SE = 0.09, p = .005). The indirect effect was significant (b = 0.20, SE = 0.07, 95% CI [0.08, 0.35]), indicating that [Mediator] partially mediated the relationship between [IV] and [DV]. Parallel mediation involves multiple mediators that operate simultaneously. Each mediator is theorized to transmit the effect of the IV on the DV independently. To examine whether different processes (mediators) independently contribute to the effect of the IV on the DV. This model allows you to assess which mediator(s) play a significant role and to what extent. IV → Mediator 1 → DV IV → Mediator 2 → DV (Mediators do not influence one another) Generate scatterplots for DV vs. each mediator. Run separate regression analyses for each mediator (DV as outcome, mediator as predictor) and inspect residuals vs. predicted plots. Criteria: Residuals should show no systematic pattern. Create histograms and Q–Q plots for the residuals of each regression. Criteria: Skewness < |2.0| and kurtosis < |7.0|. Run a correlation matrix (Analyze > Correlate > Bivariate) among the mediators. Criteria: Inter-mediator correlations should be moderate (ideally, r < 0.80) to avoid redundancy. As with simple mediation, verify study design and check the Durbin–Watson statistic (1.5–2.5). Navigate to Analyze > Regression > PROCESS vX. Use Model 4; PROCESS allows entering multiple mediators simultaneously. Enter the IV, DV, and list all mediators. Enable bootstrapping (e.g., 5,000 samples) to obtain confidence intervals for each indirect effect. Click OK. Example: a1 = 0.30, b1 = 0.40 → Indirect effect = 0.30 × 0.40 = 0.12 Bootstrapped 95% CI: [0.03, 0.22] (significant if CI does not include zero, p = .012). Example: a2 = 0.25, b2 = 0.35 → Indirect effect = 0.25 × 0.35 = 0.0875 Bootstrapped 95% CI: [0.01, 0.18] (significant, p = .025). Sum of individual indirect effects (if both are significant). Example: c′ = 0.30, SE = 0.08, p < .001 A parallel mediation analysis was conducted using the PROCESS macro (Model 4) with 5,000 bootstrap samples to evaluate whether [Mediator 1] and [Mediator 2] independently mediated the relationship between [IV] and [DV]. The indirect effect through [Mediator 1] was significant (b = 0.12, SE = 0.06, 95% CI [0.03, 0.22], p = .012), as was the indirect effect through [Mediator 2] (b = 0.09, SE = 0.05, 95% CI [0.01, 0.18], p = .025). The direct effect of [IV] on [DV] remained significant (b = 0.30, SE = 0.08, p < .001), suggesting that both mediators contributed uniquely to the overall relationship.” Serial mediation (also called chain mediation) involves two or more mediators arranged in a specific sequential order. The IV affects the first mediator, which in turn affects the second mediator, and so on, eventually influencing the DV. To investigate the process by which the IV impacts the DV through a chain of mediators, highlighting the step-by-step mechanism and temporal ordering of effects. Generate scatterplots and residual vs. predicted plots for each link: IV → M1, M1 → M2, and M2 → DV. Use histograms and Q–Q plots for residuals in each regression. Criteria: As before, look for random dispersion, skewness < |2.0|, kurtosis < |7.0|, and Durbin–Watson between 1.5 and 2.5. There must be theoretical or empirical support for the hypothesized order (e.g., M1 influences M2). Run intermediate regressions (e.g., regress M2 on M1) and ensure that coefficients are significant (p < .05) in line with your theory. Consider and control for variables that may confound the relationships between mediators if necessary. Go to Analyze > Regression > PROCESS vX. Choose Model 6 (designed for serial mediation). Enter the IV, DV, and mediators in the specific sequential order. Click Options: Enable bootstrapping (e.g., 5,000 samples) to obtain confidence intervals. Click OK. Path IV → Mediator 1: Example: a1 = 0.35, SE = 0.09, p = .001 Path Mediator 1 → Mediator 2: Example: d = 0.45, SE = 0.10, p = .001 Path Mediator 2 → DV (controlling for IV and M1): Example: b2 = 0.30, SE = 0.08, p = .002 Sequential Indirect Effect (IV → M1 → M2 → DV): Calculation: a1 × d × b2 = 0.35 × 0.45 × 0.30 = 0.0473 Bootstrapped 95% CI: [0.01, 0.10] (if CI does not include zero, the effect is significant, e.g., p = .018). Direct Effect (IV → DV controlling for mediators): Example: c′ = 0.35, SE = 0.09, p < .001 A serial mediation analysis was conducted using the PROCESS macro (Model 6) with 5,000 bootstrap samples to test whether [Mediator 1] and [Mediator 2] sequentially mediated the relationship between [IV] and [DV]. The analysis indicated that [IV] significantly predicted [Mediator 1] (b = 0.35, SE = 0.09, p = .001), and [Mediator 1] significantly predicted [Mediator 2] (b = 0.45, SE = 0.10, p = .001). Furthermore, [Mediator 2] significantly predicted [DV] (b = 0.30, SE = 0.08, p = .002). The sequential indirect effect was significant (b = 0.047, SE = 0.02, 95% CI [0.01, 0.10], p = .018), indicating that the effect of [IV] on [DV] was transmitted via [Mediator 1] and [Mediator 2] in sequence. The direct effect of [IV] on [DV] remained significant (b = 0.35, SE = 0.09, p < .001), suggesting partial mediation. Check Assumptions in SPSS: Generate scatterplots, residual vs. predicted plots, histograms, and Q–Q plots. Verify diagnostic values: skewness (< |2.0|), kurtosis (< |7.0|), Durbin–Watson (1.5–2.5), and inter-mediator correlations (r < 0.80 for parallel mediation). For serial mediation, confirm intermediate regression steps are significant (p < .05). Conduct Mediation Analysis with PROCESS: Use the appropriate model: Model 4 for simple and parallel mediation; Model 6 for serial mediation. Enter variables as specified and enable bootstrapping (commonly 5,000 samples) to generate 95% confidence intervals. Interpret Output: Evaluate p-values for each path (significant if p < .05). For indirect effects, confirm that bootstrapped confidence intervals do not include zero.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 7. Sampling & Complex Designs
item.description:
Why should we strive for population representative sampling? Important for policy or practice. We do not want to recommend changes that are not based on research that is representative of the full population those changes would impact. How? Narrow our populations of interest (e.g., Columbus instead of the US) Work on large teams Use secondary data Normally used to compensate for over- and under-sampling of individuals Example It is common to over-sample minority groups... If we doubled the size of our minority sample, then each minority case would get a design weight of 1/2 or .5. We use the design weight when we want the statistics to be representative of the population. Used to compensate for the fact that persons with certain characteristics are not as likely to respond to the survey. Example Most population surveys have substantially more female than male respondents; because surveys over-represents females and under-represents males in the population, a weight is used to compensate for this bias. There are many responsent characteristics that are likely to be related to the propensity to respond such as age, education, race/ethnicity, place of residence. Dataset with cases Simple mean (4 + 2 + 1 + 5 + 2) / 5 = 2.8 Weighted mean {(4 1) + (2 2) + (1 4) + (5 1) + (2 * 2)} / 10 = 2.1 With unweighted data, each case is counted equally With weighted data, each case is counted relative to its representation in the population Unweighted data represent only those in the sample who provide data Weights allow analyses that represent the target population Most STATA commands can deal with weighted data, where the weight is a variable in the dataset. You need to specify the type of weight and the weight variable, using brackets at the end of your command, as in: summarize x [weight=weightvarname] tab x [weight=weightvarname] regress y x [weight=weightvarname] There are 4 types of weights in STATA, but for most data analyses you will use one of the following: Probability pweights, for observations sampled with unequal probability of selection. Use this for inferential analyses. Analytic aweights, for data containing averages where the average is weighted by the # obs used in calculating the average…. Use this for your descriptive statistics.
Different studies create different types of weights... Some data create weights depending on: Level of analysis (child, teacher, or school) Type of analysis (cross-sectional vs. Longitudinal) Source of data (child assessment, parent interview, teacher questionnaires, etc.) For example, the ECLS-K has ~ 105 different options Many suggest you use combination weights when estimating longitudinal analyses because they assume that these users will not adjust for attrition on their own. I suggest avoiding the use of attrition weights. Instead, use modern missing data procedures for attrition bias, and use the appropriate sample weight to adjust for sampling bias I make this recommendation because attrition weights have two key disadvantages Attrition weights often reduce the analytical sample size, and thereby, statistical power. If many non-model variables related to missing data are incorporated, missing data techniques adjust for attrition bias more effectively than attrition weights Use weights whenever possible, but some methods do not allow weights Steps to follow to avoid vias in unweighted analyses
Include as Independent Variable that might account for the sample design or non-response
If a weight is available, it can also be included as an IV If the weight is associated with the outcom ein a model including the design variables, then the weight is likely to have been constructed in a way related to your outcome; bias is possile. E.g., some multilevel models, some structural equation programs, etc. National samples are first divided into primary sampling units... What these units are depends on the study. - E.g., in many data of the US the PSUs are geographic areas consisting of counties or groups of counties
After identifying PSUs, then PSUs are stratified into groups. These groups are formed to keep similar units together... How many and what types of strata are determined by study goals.
Then within each strata, and within PSUs, you sample Software can make the adjustment... A few different approaches with the easiest being the Taylor Series approach Use primary sampling unit (PSU) and strata variables in the data file. The strata and PSU identifiers are often associated with a specific sampling weight variable. For example, in the ECLS-K the weight C1CW0 has the following strata and PSU: C1TVWSTR and C1TCWPSU svyset PSU [pweight = WEIGHT], strata(STRATA) Then use svy: before your subsequent commands (e.g., svy: tab or svy: mean or svy: regress) svy: will NOT work with all commands svy: mean and mean [weight = weight] yield the same mean estimates… it is the SEs that are different)

Weights should be used when analyzing data from national samples; otherwise, you cannot make claims about representativeness The appropriate weight should be selected based on: Level of analysis Round (s) of data Source (s) of data There may not be a 'perfect' weight for many analyses All statistical tests should be based on standard errors that account for complex sample design
item.guid: University Resources/Current/Secondary Data Analysis/7. Sampling & Complex Designs.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 6. Variable Selection & Data Relationships
item.description:
Big data allows for complex analyses and many (undocumented) decisions are made during the research project, including what IV, DV, and covariates to include.


https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/p-hacking/ What are covariates and why do we include them? Conditioning on such risk factors is necessary to remove bias. Do NOT use p-values to determine covariate inclusion. Use a priori theory! Achieving statistical significance with covariates and without transparency
As you are making decisions regarding your variables, consider the following questions: How will constructs be operationalized? What items will be used and which measures are critical to the tests? If multiple measures are available, what will be done? These issues often require quite a bit of conceptual considerations and defending in the peer-review process. In big datasets, measures are often abbreviated. Measurement problems arise when The concept to be measured are vague or poorly defined Indicators are imperfect measures of the underlying construct Individual responses are inaccurate (e.g., distraction, illness, poor comprehension) Errors lead to erroneous values Accuracy The closeness of the measurement to the true value Bias A systematic variation of measurements from the quality being measured Precision The closeness of repeated measurements to one another

Inaccurate and unreliable measurement results in serious concerns regarding the Validity and Reliability of the hypotheses tested using given measures.
The vast majority of constructs require more than one item, Why? Low content validity (sensitivity and reliability) The primary objective of creating a series of composite scales is to avoid the exclusive use of, or dependence on, single item constructs where possible. The use of several variables as indicators provides an opportunity to represent differing facets of a given concept, with the aim of yielding a more well-rounded perspective and, arguably, a better measure. X1 = I often feel alone X2 = I am often sad X3 = I often feel like crying X4 = I cannot shake off the bluesalpha X1 X2 X3 X4, std item alpha X1 X2 X3 X4, std gen (depress) alpha X1 X2 X3 X4, std (depress) min(3)

Cronbach's Alpha (One metric of reliability) - 0.90 or greater = great - 0.80 - 0.89 = good - 0.70 - 0.79 = acceptable - 0.60 - 0.69 = marginal - 0.59 or less = not acceptable sem (Depress-> X1, ) (Depress-> X2, ) (Depress-> X3, ) (Depress-> X4, ) standardized latent(Depress ) nocapslatent (CFA code) factor x1 x2 x3 x4 (EFA code) Alpha approach takes the average, whereas factor approach allows different weighting of items.

Bwt_tm 5 - bag_tmx 5, as well as column wjpvwcx 5 - wjpcwcx 5 Convergent Validity
(wjpvwcx 5, bag_tmx 5) Discriminant Validity Within indicator correlations should exceed 0.50. Always look at your data Data collection issues: recording errors ~60 different ways of spelling Philadelphia in one dataset browse (stata syntax)
sum (Continuous variables)
tab (Categorical Variable)

http://guessthecorrelation.com/​ Guess that correlation is a game with a purpose. It is entertaining, but data on our guesses are collected and used to analyze how we perceive correlations in scatterplots. So, the more people that play, the more data generated. Always plot your data.
Outliers are anomalous objects or values Data that have characteristics different from most others Values of an attribute that are unusual This is not just noise! An outlier is an event that is suspected of not being generated by the same mechanisms as the rest of the data.
Deviates significantly from the rest of the dataset Deviates significantly with respect to a specific context of the object The individual data objects may not be outliers, but the object as a whole deviate significantly from the entire dataset.
Departures from normality are usually not serious in large samples, but there may be some bias in standard errors and test statistics. One solution is to transform the non-normal data (e.g., log, square root, etc.) Other methods are potentially more rigorous
Estimates of standard errors are robust against non-normality because assumptions of Normality are relaxed. Several different ways to get robust standard errors. Huber-White sandwich method, use the option vce (robust)

Why do we test for reliability in subpopulations? Establish the psychometric properties of a new or existing measure/assessment tool Means for determining generalizeability Are we measuring the same construct in the same way across groups or across time? Increase confidence that observed differences between groups reflect true differences and not those ties to measurement. Reliability within subgroups is often assumed but rarely tested and is a big issue for many datasets that do not use previously validated meaures. Why use existing composites? Data availability: you often may not have all necessary data to create the composite Reproducibility: everyone uses the same construct Convenience: time and effort spent on identifying possible composites and determining best source of information to creating them But first, always read the user's guide and when item level data are available, check yourself!

item.title: Global Outliers
item.description: Deviates significantly from the rest of the dataset
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Contextual Outlier
item.description: Deviates significantly with respect to a specific context of the object

item.title: 5. STATA Basics and Data Management
item.description:
Great for data management Very powerful and flexible, for most models. STATA can Handle Continuous, Categorical, and count variables Evaluate group differences via multiple group analysis Evaluate complex survey data and make necessary adjustments (e.g., clustering, weights) Handle missing data through full information maximum likelihood or multiple imputations
Run more basic (Regression, EFA, CFA) and more complex analyses (MLM, LGCM, GMM)
The big window Results of all STATA commands appear here (except graphs) Records all STATA commands that have been entered. A previous command can be repeated by double-clicking the command in the Review window Shows a record of all variables in the dataset Across the top of the screen
Click the (editor) button. All data are visible here. Note that no commands can be executed when the data editor is open. There are two ways to operate STATA Commands can be types directly into the Command window and executed by pressing Enter. Commands can be written in a separate file (called a do-file) and executed together in one step. List of all the commands you need for your project No need to repeat work; recreate your dataset by running the do-file Easy to correct mistakes you find later To create / edit do-file: Starting a new do-file: doedit Editing an existing do-file: doedit DOFILENAME.do Type in commands Save do-file (control + s) To use Do DOFILENAME.Do Try to be organized Use headings For all test in do-flies that are not commands, begin the line with * Log records all commands and output during the session To use: Open new log Log using LOGNAME.log / cmdlog using CLOGNAME.log Write over an existing log Log using LOGNAME.log / cmdlog using CMDLOGNAME.log, replace Add to an existing log Log using LOGNAME.log / cmdlog using CMDLOGNAME.log, append To close log Log close / cmdlog close To read a file using the command window Use "C:...\sample.dta", clear use sample.dta, clear To save a file Save "C:...\sample.dta" [, replace] Type 'browse' in the command window Column holds the variable Row holds the observation Cell of a particular variable for a particular observation is a value Allows you to edit the data The number of observations in the dataset Number of variables in the dataset The amount of memory the dataset is using and how much memory you still have to work with Basic information about the variables in our dataset
Variable name, label and type Some basic descriptive statistics for variable
The general syntax for all STATA commands is: [prefix:] cmdname [varlist] [=exp] [if exp] [in exp] [weight] [using filename] [, options] Elements in square brackets are optional for some commands Sometimes cmdname is all that is required, for example, codebook or describe STATA is case sensitive
New variables can be created using generate Gen racev2 = race New variable can contain functions or combinations of existing variables Gen income = inc1 + inc2 + inc3 You can use *, +, -, /, ^ Replace may be used to change the contents of an existing variable Replace oldvar = exp1 [if exp2] Always recommend that you do not save over original values. 'If' is used to restrict the command to a desired subset of observations: Replace race =. If race == 999 The double == sign is used to test for equality, while the single sign is used for assignment Operators can be used after if: & denotes 'and' | denotes 'or' ~ or ! Denote 'not' Rename may be used to rename variables Rename oldvarname newvarname To drop a variable or variables, type Drop varlist Alternatively, keep varlist eliminates everything but varlist To drop certain observations, use Drop if exp For example, drop if unemplrate== Dataset in memory is called 'master dataset' Dataset filename is called 'using dataset' Variables with same name will be combined Variables in only one dataset will have missing values for observations from the other dataset. To join corresponding observations from a STATA dataset with those in the dataset in memory, type: Merge 1:1 varlist using filename
If more than one observations has the same value of varlist in the master dataset, use: Merge m: 1 varlist using filename To add another STATA dataset below the end of the dataset in memory, type: Append using filename

For Mean, Standard Deviation (SD) use sum: Sum bex_tm54 For stats by subgroup, add bysort: in option section Bysort csex_m01: sum bex_tm54
For Categorical Variable s use tab: Tab csex_m01 Syntax using correlate Correlate bex_tm54 bex_tm1s bex_tmg3
pwcorr provides significance levels
Syntax using ttest ttest bex_tm54, by (csex_m01) Results using regress: Regress bex_tm 54 meducm 01 inc_6_54 csex_m01
Coef. = Beta Coefficient Std. Err. = Standard error T = Ratio of beta to standard error P>|t| = significance level [95% conf. Interval] = Confidence Interval Critial Ratio The most basic form of a statistical test of significance 1.96 for p < .05 2.58 for p < .01 3.24 for p < .001 If you know the name of a command, enter Help cmdname If you don't know it, enter Findit word 1 [word2] ... This queries a database and some of the official internet sources (such as STATA FAQs, STATA articles) Google Email or call STATA Technical services Statalist archives / forums
Check the cheat sheets (statacheatsheets.pdf)

item.title: Serial Mediation
item.description: Serial mediation (also called chain mediation) involves two or more mediators arranged in a specific sequential order. The IV affects the first mediator, which in turn affects the second mediator, and so on, eventually influencing the DV. To investigate the process by which the IV impacts the DV through a chain of mediators, highlighting the step-by-step mechanism and temporal ordering of effects. Generate scatterplots and residual vs. Predicted plots for each link: IV → M 1, M 1 → M 2, and M 2 → DV. Use histograms and Q–Q plots for residuals in each regression. Criteria: As before, look for random dispersion, skewness < |2.0|, kurtosis < |7.0|, and Durbin–Watson between 1.5 and 2.5. There must be theoretical or empirical support for the hypothesized order (e.g., M 1 influences M 2). Run intermediate regressions (e.g., regress M 2 on M 1) and ensure that coefficients are significant (p < .05) in line with your theory. Consider and control for variables that may confound the relationships between mediators if necessary. Go to Analyze > Regression > PROCESS vX. Choose Model 6 (designed for serial mediation). Enter the IV, DV, and mediators in the specific sequential order. Click Options: Enable bootstrapping (e.g., 5,000 samples) to obtain confidence intervals. Click OK. Path IV → Mediator 1: Example: a 1 = 0.35, SE = 0.09, p = .001 Path Mediator 1 → Mediator 2: Example: d = 0.45, SE = 0.10, p = .001 Path Mediator 2 → DV (controlling for IV and M 1): Example: b2 = 0.30, SE = 0.08, p = .002 Sequential Indirect Effect (IV → M 1 → M 2 → DV): Calculation: a 1 × d × b 2 = 0.35 × 0.45 × 0.30 = 0.0473 Bootstrapped 95% CI: [0.01, 0.10] (if CI does not include zero, the effect is significant, e.g., p = .018). Direct Effect (IV → DV controlling for mediators): Example: c′ = 0.35, SE = 0.09, p < .001 A serial mediation analysis was conducted using the PROCESS macro (Model 6) with 5,000 bootstrap samples to test whether [Mediator 1] and [Mediator 2] sequentially mediated the relationship between [IV] and [DV]. The analysis indicated that [IV] significantly predicted [Mediator 1] (b = 0.35, SE = 0.09, p = .001), and [Mediator 1] significantly predicted [Mediator 2] (b = 0.45, SE = 0.10, p = .001). Furthermore, [Mediator 2] significantly predicted [DV] (b = 0.30, SE = 0.08, p = .002). The sequential indirect effect was significant (b = 0.047, SE = 0.02, 95% CI [0.01, 0.10], p = .018), indicating that the effect of [IV] on [DV] was transmitted via [Mediator 1] and [Mediator 2] in sequence. The direct effect of [IV] on [DV] remained significant (b = 0.35, SE = 0.09, p < .001), suggesting partial mediation.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Parallel Mediation
item.description: Parallel mediation involves multiple mediators that operate simultaneously. Each mediator is theorized to transmit the effect of the IV on the DV independently. To examine whether different processes (mediators) independently contribute to the effect of the IV on the DV. This model allows you to assess which mediator (s) play a significant role and to what extent. IV → Mediator 1 → DV IV → Mediator 2 → DV (Mediators do not influence one another) Generate scatterplots for DV vs. Each mediator. Run separate regression analyses for each mediator (DV as outcome, mediator as predictor) and inspect residuals vs. Predicted plots. Criteria: Residuals should show no systematic pattern. Create histograms and Q–Q plots for the residuals of each regression. Criteria: Skewness < |2.0| and kurtosis < |7.0|. Run a correlation matrix (Analyze > Correlate > Bivariate) among the mediators. Criteria: Inter-mediator correlations should be moderate (ideally, r < 0.80) to avoid redundancy. As with simple mediation, verify study design and check the Durbin–Watson statistic (1.5–2.5). Navigate to Analyze > Regression > PROCESS vX. Use Model 4; PROCESS allows entering multiple mediators simultaneously. Enter the IV, DV, and list all mediators. Enable bootstrapping (e.g., 5,000 samples) to obtain confidence intervals for each indirect effect. Click OK. Example: a 1 = 0.30, b 1 = 0.40 → Indirect effect = 0.30 × 0.40 = 0.12 Bootstrapped 95% CI: [0.03, 0.22] (significant if CI does not include zero, p = .012). Example: a 2 = 0.25, b 2 = 0.35 → Indirect effect = 0.25 × 0.35 = 0.0875 Bootstrapped 95% CI: [0.01, 0.18] (significant, p = .025). Sum of individual indirect effects (if both are significant). Example: c′ = 0.30, SE = 0.08, p < .001 A parallel mediation analysis was conducted using the PROCESS macro (Model 4) with 5,000 bootstrap samples to evaluate whether [Mediator 1] and [Mediator 2] independently mediated the relationship between [IV] and [DV]. The indirect effect through [Mediator 1] was significant (b = 0.12, SE = 0.06, 95% CI [0.03, 0.22], p = .012), as was the indirect effect through [Mediator 2] (b = 0.09, SE = 0.05, 95% CI [0.01, 0.18], p = .025). The direct effect of [IV] on [DV] remained significant (b = 0.30, SE = 0.08, p < .001), suggesting that both mediators contributed uniquely to the overall relationship.”
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 5. Conditional Process Analysis
item.description:
Disordinal (when the moderation slopes cross) An interaction/moderation occurs when the effect of an independent variable (x) on an Outcome variable (y) depends on the values of another independent variable (w).

Controlling for the other predictors in a model, does x predict y? The above is logical only if the relation between x and y does not depend on another predictor in the model. If a relation does depend on a moderating variable (w), then moderation has occurred and the relations need to be explored.
Moderation can occur between categorical predictors, categorical and one continuous predictor, or between continuous predictors. How you decide if its a moderator? If x and y AND w and y we know are related, we could include in the moderation. Categorical & Categorical

Continuous & Categorical

Continuous & Continuous
Model will be misspecified Inflates the MSE residuals F-test will be invalid (F = MSR / MSE) Mathematical transformation of variables to center around the mean instead of zero (e.g., making the mean equal zero) Subtract the mean of a variable from all observations for that variable.
Increases interpretability and decreases Multicollinearity Changes the interpretation of the intercept The value of the dependent variable when the independent variables are at their averages rather than zero. Debated in the literature, so choose for yourself what makes the most sense. Just report it correctly! Pro mean centering (Aiken & West, 1991) Against mean centering (Hayes, 2018)
A mediation (indirect effect) occurs when an Independent Variable (x) relates to an outcome variable (y) through a mediating variable (m).
a = first-stage relation (effect of x on m) b = Second-stage relation (effect of m on y) c = total effect (e.g., regression/correlation coefficient) c' = Direct effect (effect of x on y controlling for m) Indirect effect = a x b (a multiplied by b) The effect of x on y does not need to be significant for a mediation to be possible (e.g., x significantly relates to m, which significantly relates to y, but x does not predict y directly)
Multiple mediators may be present operating either in tandem (Parallel Mediation) or in sequence (Serial Mediation) Parallel Mediation
Controls for two covariates Serial Mediation
It is possible that x and y are not direct (partial or complete mediation) The examination of both moderation and mediation processes occurring at the same time.
Mediations can be moderated Index of mediation = a value of the distance between two indirect effects If significant, evidence of moderated mediation. If not significant, mediation is not moderated.
If you want to replicate the findings of an ANOVA via Regression exactly, be sure to code your Nominal Variable s around zero (-1, 1, or -. 05, .05) to achieve Main Effects Parameterization. This yields coefficients that represent the main effects of predictor variables.
Using Simple Effects Parameterization (0, 1) yields the same interpretation as dummy coding. The effect of x when w = 0, or the effect of w when x = 0. Which one to choose is a matter of preference and what research question (s) and hypotheses you are trying to address.
A tool developed by Andrew Hayes to easily run Conditional Process Analysis
Download files at (Download - The PROCESS macro for SPSS, SAS, and R) or from our Carmen site Extract all files from the zipped folder and move files to somewhere you can easily access Process y=outcome/x=independent/m=mediators/w=moderator/z-second moderator/cov=covariate list/model number from Hayes text/seed = any number you want that locks the random number generator. PROCESS includes 5000-sample bootstrapped confidence intervals by default
Conf = 99 increases to 99% confidence interval, which is more conservative. Useful for biased estimates, non-normal data, Multicollinearity, etc. You MUST include seed = some number so that the findings remain the same. If the random number generator is allowed to freely draw, the findings will be different every time. For moderation
For mediation
For Conditional Process Analysis
Scenario We want to find out whether the effect of mom's IQ on kid's score on a cognitive test is impacted by mom's high school status. In simple terms, do mother's high school status moderate the relationship between mother's IQ and kid's performance on a cognitive test? Model 1
Analyze -> Regression -> PROCESS v 4.2 by Andrew F. Hayes - Note: Make sure each variable name is not more than 8 characters

Drag the Dependent Variable into the 'Y variable' box (kid_score)
Drag the Independent Variable to the 'X variable' box (mom_iq) If you have any covariate(s), move it to the covariate(s) box
Drag the Moderator to the 'moderator variable w' box (mom_hs) Remember not to use the 'Paste' button! - If you want to use the syntax, you will have to generate the syntax by yourself.

If your Moderator or Independent Variable (x) is Categorical, click on 'Multicategorical' and select the coding scheme of your choice. A variable specified as 'Multicategorical' must have at least 3 categories.
You don't have to manually recode your Nominal Variable s. Process y = kidscore/ x=mom_iq/ w=mom_hs/ model=1/ center=2/ plot=1. Code Generated for the Graph
You will have to copy the 'DATA LIST FREE/' and to the period and paste into your syntax window
Although there is a positive effect of mom_iq on kidscore, the magnitude of the effect (the slope) is higher for children whose parents did not graduate high school (the blue line). Let's say that we have a theory that the more time you spend with a puppy, the happier you are. Also, the amount of love you have for puppies will moderate that effect. We will use the puppy_love dataset to run this scenario in PROCESS, but there are a few things to note: Make sure all variables you are using are 8 characters or less in length We will also set up the problem to create a plot We are interested in any points of W (the moderator) where the significance changes. This will be determined by the Johnson-Neyman approach. Go to Analyze > Regression > PROCESS
Move over your y, x, and w variables. Typically, we would change the model #, but given that we are working with Model 1, we are keeping it the default of 1. Click on 'Options'
This is the Options pop-up. To generate the code for making your plot, select Generate code for visualizing interactions. To get Johnson-Newman results, click on the box that is circled below for 'Johnson-Newman Output' Click Continue then OK Process y = Happy/ x= Dose/w=puplove/model=1/center=0/jn=1/plot=1/moments=0. Jn=1 We want to get the Johnson-Newman output, if any. Jn=0 Omitting it from the syntax means we do not want the J-N output. Plot=1 We want the syntax for the plot to be provided to us. Plot=0 Omitting it from the syntax means we do not want the syntax. Model=1 The simplest model where we have one moderator moderating the relationship between the focal predictor and the outcome variable. Please check the 'Appendix A' document for Process Macro to learn more about other models and their numbers. Moments=1 We want to create three categories of the moderator by using the mean, 1 SD above the mean, and 1 SD units below the mean (the most common approach).
(NB: only do this when your moderator is a continuous variable) This is done to help with interpretation Moments=0 Omitting it from the syntax means we are creating three categories of the moderator by using the 16th percentile, 50th percentile, and the 84th percentile. This is the default. If your moderator is a categorical with more than 2 categories, you can add /MCW=1 to the syntax to automatically create dummy variables for you. Check the appendix file for other coding schemes and their corresponding numbers. Center=0 Omitting it from the syntax Means NO CENTERING Center=1 All variables that define products should be automatically mean-centered Center=2
Only the continuous variables that defines products should be automatically mean-centered. Recommendation, if you are thinking about mean-centering, then:
Choose Center=2, if the moderator or the focal predictor is a continuous variable.
Choose Center=1 if both the moderator or the focal predictor are a continuous variables. Choose Center=0 if both the moderator or the focal predictor are a categorical variable
This first part of the output shows us the model we built including the model number, our N, and the model summary. Model summary includes the R2 value, which in this case shows a significant amount of variance explained (37.63%) Below, in the 'Model' table, you can see the coefficients for the intercept as well as for the slopes of Dose, Love of Puppies, and the automatically created interaction term. Just below that you see that the interaction term is dose x puppylove
This next significant table shows us the conditional effects of W at the 16 th, 50 th, and 84 th percentiles. Here, we see that when puppy love is at the 16 th percentile (puppy love = 1), the effect is 1.81 (p = .0013). Likewise, when puppy love is at the 50 th percentile (2.5), the effect is also significant (p = .0046) at 1.1694. However, the effect is no longer significant at the 84 th percentile for puppy love, (p > .05).
The next table is the Johnson-Newman results. The Johnson-Newman approach looks for the values of W, where the p-values of the conditional effect changes to above/below the chosen significance level (. 05). So, it looks for the values of W that cause t-crit value to equal zero for when determining the conditional effect of X, where the p-value is exactly the alpha, or .05 in most cases. At what values of W, do the results go from significant to non-significant, or vice-versa, in terms of conditional effect? Your results can either be of one, two, or zero values. If there is one value, that means there is only one value of W where the conditional effect either becomes significant or loses significance. If there are two values, that means there are two points at which W will change in significance. This will either mean the middle range is significant, but not the high and low values of W, or that the high and low values of W are significant, but not the middle range. The middle range is determined by the W values themselves. If there are no values, then the conditional effect is either always significant or never significant for all values of W. Next are graphical representations for what different types of Johnson-Newman results may look like. Where the line cross .05, that's where this approach looks for the value of W, giving us more insight into what extent our moderator... Well, moderates.
Graphs for two or no solutions to JN approach

See that the Johnson-Newman technique gave us only one value, 3.3364. By finding the value in the table below, we can see that the conditional effect is significant before W = 3.3364, but non-significant after that point. So, it is significant with lower levels of puppy love. (First column, row 3.3364)
The moderator (puplove) has significant impact on the relationship between time spent with Puppies and Happiness, only at its low values (i.e., from 0.00 to 3.3364) This implies that, the less an individual loves a puppy, the more time spent with puppy affect (increases) their happiness. At its higher values, the moderator (puplove) does not have a significant effect on the relationship between time spent with Puppies (focal predictor) and Happiness (outcome variable) This implies that, increasing the time spent with Puppy does not affect/change (increases) happiness for individuals who already love Puppies. The next part of the table give us the syntax to generate the plot
Double click on the matrix table and it will allow you to highlight and copy parts of the text. Highlight and copy from the DATA LIST FREE/ until the period at the end. Once you copy the code, paste it into a new syntax file. There is nothing you need to change. Just highlight and play the syntax. The results will look like the graph below, a plot with points but no lines.
To create plot lines, double click on the plot itself. A 'Chart Editor' pop-up will appear.
Click on the Add lines at Subgroups button (It looks like a scatterplots with TWO lines through it, not one) (circled in red) You will get the properties pop-up now, but by default, it will give you the lines you need, as you can see now in the red boxed area. Just close the properties box and the chart editor box.
This is what your chart should look like now. You can now have lines that can help you to visualize the changes in X vs. Y, given the subgroups of W. Pretend that literature shows that the more someone loves puppies, the happier they are. We would like to test that theory, but with a moderator of time spent with puppies during a trial (dose). Here, we are recognizing that Dose is a multi-categorical variable for control group (0 minutes, 15 minutes, or 30 minutes with puppies). Typically, we would need to dummy-code these variables, but PROCESS does it for you, provided you remember one extra step. First, set up the model as usual in PROCESS. Note. Where the variables are in the image based on the new hypothesis. Next click on 'Multicategorical'
The next pop-up you will get is the multicategorical box. Here, you will select the checkbox under 'Variable W' to indicate that your moderator is multicategorical. Note. The other options, indicating that you can also do this for any X or Z variables(s) that have 3 or more categories. Click Continue.
Click OK. One of the changes is the dummy coding. The coding scheme is provided just below the model overview and will look something like the table below.
The next change is the model and product terms key tables. Just keep in mind the W coding scheme from before when interpreting each line, since now we are recognizing the separate levels of our W. The final change is the set-up of the conditional effects table. Usually, this will either be representative of the 16 th, 50 th, and 84 th percentile (default), or the means +/- 1 SD (if selected). However, now since we are recognizing W as a categorical variable, the doses are listed as the separate categories. - Note how there is no mention of the percentiles in the 'Analysis Notes and Errors' section.

item.title: Two-Way ANOVA
item.description:
To examine the main effects of two Independent factors and their interaction effect on a Continuous dependent variable.
A two-way (or factorial) ANOVA is used to examine the main effects of two Categorical Independent Variable (factors) on a Continuous Dependent Variable as well as their interaction effect. Investigating the effects of 'Teaching Method' (Traditional vs. Experimental) and 'Gender' (Male vs. Female) on exam scores. ""

item.title: 2. Multiple Regression Review
item.description:
Method of minimizing overall error in a particular model by producing estimates that have the least ' Sum of Squares of Error (SSE) ' (SSE = the sum of squared residual effects). Residual effects Unexplained variation in the outcome variable Error can be positive or negative, but negative residual is illogical, so we square the residuals. Best estimates for the b's are the one's that provide minimal error over any other collection of b's. The model with the smallest SSE will be the best fitting model.



The model with the smallest Sum of Squares of Error (SSE) will be the best fitting model
Least squares regression line
These values will always give us the smallest overall error, compared to any other line draw through the set of points.
Partitioning sum of squares into regression (explained) and error (unexplained)
Partitioning sum of squares into between (explained) and within/error (unexplained)
Testing regression coefficient
- T-test is based on the F-Tests (t-squared). We are testing if the beta weight of the coefficient is big enough to account for variation in Y compared to error.
- Error in estimate = Standard Error
Omnibus test How well does the model fit the actual data? Good fit Minimized error and strong correspondence between observed and predicted values (e.g., a large R-squared) F MSR / MSE provides overall statistical test of model fit H0 (Null Hypothesis) (x variable (s) do not predict y) With no better predictions than population mean of y H1 (Alternative Hypothesis) (x variable (s) do predict y) with better predictions than population mean of y. Mathematically accounting for the influence of another parameter on the relation between x and y. When predictors are correlated, they potentially have shared or overlapping explained variance in Y. We need to consider the unique contribution of each. Pearson’s correlation coefficient (r) does NOT do this. Squaring an r statistic is only useful when there is only one predictor (R-squared) Unique correlations are needed to account for multiple predictors: Partial (first-order) Correlation Semi-partial (part) Correlations

Partial (First-Order) Correlations The correlation between x and y while controlling for x2 (on both x and y)
Semi-Partial (Part) Correlation The correlation between x and y while controlling for x2 (on x1 only) The relative strength of the association between x and y. Squaring the partial correlation yields the proportion of the variance in Y remaining after removing the effects of all other predictors (Not very useful) Squaring the semi-partial correlation yields the proportion of the variance in y uniquely explained by x while controlling for all other predictors.
Useful as a measure of Effect Size x and y are unrelated before and after No variables are related to each other The relation between x and y remains stable x2 is irrelevant The relation between x and y drops to zero x2 completely accounts for the variation between x and y Signs of confounded predictors, spurious correlation, 'complete' mediation, statistical suppression The relation between x and y becomes stronger or flips signs x2 and x are so strongly related that findings become masked/suppressed The relation between x and y becomes smaller but still significant x only partly accounts for the variation in y Most common! Predicting variation in an outcome variable (y) based on changes in predictor variables (x1, x2, etc.) Can be simple (one y, one x), or multiple (one y, many x's) Can be simultaneous (all x's predicting y at the same time) or hierarchical (x's predicting y in pre-determined blocks)
Regular Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) regression assumes that x and y are linearly related and are normally distributed. Special cases require special analyses. The sample regression coefficients are statistics They are estimates of the population values of variable effects on y (how much variation in y is predicted by changes in x) Different samples will yield different values for the regression coefficients
Known as Sampling Error Coefficients are estimates, and therefore always include some error We want to minimize this error Parameters can be unstandardized (useful for raw interpretation) or standardized (useful for comparing parameters to each other) Unstandardized (b) coefficients are in the original scale and must be interpreted as a function of the original units. It is in the units you started with.

Standardized (𝛽) coefficients are based on z-scores (distances in Standard Deviation (SD) units from the mean) and can be compared across parameters.

The values of all parameters are influenced by the other parameters in the model. b0 (the intercept) Predicted score on y when all predictor variables are at zero. b1 (the slope of x1) The change in predicted y values for every 1 unit increase in x1 (holding x2 constant) b2 (the slope of x2) The change in predicted y values for every 1 unit increase in x1 (holding x1 constant)
When more than one predictor variable is included (either continuous or categorical) Often one of three types
Simultaneous Multiple Regression (E.g., all predictors at once)
Hierarchical Multiple Regression (e.g., variables added by research in theory-driven blocks)
Stepwise Multiple Regression (e.g., significant variables added in first or last; data driven) Regression coefficients for each predictor are 'partial,' in that they control for any other predictors present in the model (they 'control' for other parameters) All predictors are added at once All parameters control for all other parameters R-squared is one static value that represents the variance explained in the outcome variable by the collective set of predictors
Continuous Variable added as is
Nominal Variable must be dummy coded Variables with non-zero values should be 'centered' Predictors are added in theory-driven blocks (e.g., social-ecological models) A series of multiple-regression are performed, with each block being added to the next until all variables are included The final block of hierarchical multiple regression = simultaneous multiple regression Very useful to look at change in R-squared for each variable or blocks of variables Squared semi-partial correlation provides the unique variance explained by a given variable. Predictors are added in data-driven blocks
Forward Stepwise Regression Most predictive variables are added first
Backward Stepwise Regression Least predictive variables are trimmed Mathematically derives the highest R-squared value with the least number of predictors. NEVER USE THIS METHOD UNLESS STUDY IS ABSOLUTELY EXPLORATORY
Squared Semi-Partial (Part) Correlation Adjusted R-squared values Standardized regression coefficients Standardized coefficients are harder to interpret but more meaningful with multiple predictors (and there almost always are). Change in R-squared represents the amount of unique variance each block of variables explains above and beyond the other variables already included.
Random Sampling is preferable, but also less feasible (biased estimates) Reliable measurement of constructs is crucial, and checking psychometric properties of scales is important! Check for assumptions Linear Associations
Normality (Testing for Normality)
Multicollinearity (Multicollinearity) Check descriptive statistics and correlations between all included variables Confirm missing value codes Three core pieces of information for every data set you open: Number of cases Number of variables Date of last manipulation

Dependent Y variable Block Use next and previous buttons for blocks of variables Independent(s) x-variables Method Allows you to use stepwise, never use this Always use paste to send the analysis to the syntax editor and save your work.
Include Model Fit, R-squared change, Descriptives, Part and Partial Correlations, and Collinearity Diagnostics Confidence intervals are not necessary but can be helpful.
You can save residuals as their own variables to detect multivariate outliers. Predicted values tell you what SPSS thinks the y value should be based on the x-values of the case. Residual values are how far off SPSS was Mahalanobis distance tells you how far away a case is from the 'cloud' of other values.
Correlation tables are clunky in regression output. Generate them separately. Variables entered/removed only relevant when doing stepwise (ignore otherwise)
R-square tells you the proportion of variance explained in y by all of your x variables. Adjusted R-square takes sample size into account (weighting). Often not used.
R-squared changed useful for Hierarchical Multiple Regression. Shows how much more variance in y was explained by additional x variables (in the next block) Sig. F change signifies if the block significantly improved variance predictions.
Standard f-table that signifies if the omnibus test is significant (useful for parenthetical stats in manuscripts)
Where the action is. Each row conveys information about the regression equation that SPSS produced as the 'best fitting' model. Unstandardized coefficients are easier to interpret, but standardized coefficients are more useful for including in manuscripts (apples to apples instead of apples to oranges) Significance level of .05 is standard, though more stringent p-values can be employed to address weaknesses in design. Zero-order correlations represent the standard correlation between each x and y Partial and part correlations should be squared manually prior to interpretation. Squared partial correlation represents the variance remaining in y after factoring out the x variable. Squared part (semi-partial) correlation represents the unique variance explained in y by the x variable. Tolerance reflects the proportion of the variance in x that is not predictable from other x predictor variables. 0-1 with zero meaning no new contribution and one meaning completely uncorrelated with the other predictors.
VIF indicates the degree of similarity between an x variable and at least one other x variable in the model. Scores of higher than 5 are seen as evidence of Multicollinearity and action must be taken (e.g., variable removal or combining).

For Predictor (x) variables that are categorical, the standard procedure cannot be followed. The variable must be 'dummy coded.' Think of dummy coding as light switches. 1 ('on') means group membership and 0 ('off') means no group membership. Dummy coding means giving every case k-1 variables that indicate group membership. For the school variable So, someone from Cline elementary would have the following values for group membership: AEC = 0, Campbell County High = 0, Campbell County MS = 0, Campbell County Elementary = 0, Cline = 1, Crossroads = 0, Grants Lick = 0, Reiley = 0 k-1 groups are used to fully capture group membership. A 'reference' category is selected to represent group membership when all values are zero. Typically, the reference category is the most often selected category. For example, Campbell County High School has roughly 49% of the data in our sample dataset, meaning that category should be selected as the referent. Coefficients are interpreted as the mean differences between the reference category and the category in question.
Students in Campbell County Middle School have -.177 less global satisfaction than students at Campbell County High School, controlling for hope scores. The hat over y says we are looking at the predicted values. We are predicting y from x.
y = b0 + b1X1 + e (Simple Linear Regression (SLR))
y = b0 + b1X1 + b2X2 + ... + bnXn + e (Multiple Linear Regression (MLR))
y hat is our outcome variable (Dependent Variable)
x is our Predictor (Independent Variable)
b is our slope (Regression Coefficient s) b0 is our y-intercept Analyze -> Regression -> Linear
Drag Outcome variable into the 'Dependent' box > drag the Predictor variable into the 'Block 1 of 1' box In the Statistics menu, select Estimates, Confidence Intervals, Model Fit and Descriptive. “Linear Regression Analysis in SPSS.png” could not be found. Click on Paste to generate the syntax rxy = .448 “Linear Regression SPSS Output.png” could not be found. “Linear Regression SPSS Output 2.png” could not be found. Multiple R = corr (y, y-hat)
In Simple Linear Regression (SLR), Multiple R = |rxy|
R2 is the proportion of the variance in the dependent variable (y) that can be explained (accounted for) by the Independent Variable (s)/ Predictor (s) in the model (x's).
In SLR, R2 equals the square of the Pearson correlation between x and y (r2). 44.8% of variation Kid's score on cognitive test is accounted for by their mothers IQ.
The Omnibus test results in the ANOVA table shows that the model significantly predicts the Dependent Variable, (F(1,432) = 108.643, p < .001).
Constant (b0) 25.8 Slope (Regression Coefficient) (b1) .61 Estimated Model Kid's Score = 25.8 + 0.61 (Mother's IQ) Intercept (b0) At mom's IQ score of zero, the predicted kid's score is 25.8. Regression Coefficient (b1) For every unit increase (or decrease) in mom's IQ score, kid's score is predicted to increase (or decrease) by .61 unites. Do we have an IQ of zero? Sometime, interpreting the intercept becomes difficult or meaningless, especially when we are dealing with variables like IQ, SAT scores, etc. We have to use what is termed as 'mean-centering' That is creating a new variable by simply subtracting the mean from each individual observation E.g., Centered IQi = IQi - IQ-bar (mean of IQ scores) ** Centering mom_iq. ** Note that the mean for mom's IQ is 100 COMPUTE iq_c = mom_iq - 100 ** Running a simple linear regression using the centered variable REGRESSION /DEPENDENT kid_score /method=ENTER iq_c
Slope does not change (b1 = .610) The predicted kid's score when mom's IQ score is at the mean (i.e., 100) is 86.797. The interpretation of the intercept now makes more sense. REGRESSION /DESCRIPTIVES CORR SIG N /DEPENDENT kid_score /method=ENTER iq_c mom age.
Intercept (b0) At mom's IQ score of zero, the predicted kid's score is 25.8. Regression Coefficient (b1) For every unit increase in mom's IQ score, kid's score is predicted to increase by .6 units. Regression Coefficient (b2) For every one unit increase in mom's age, kid's score is predicted to increase by .39 units. Useful when we want to know the contribution of each variable to the model.
R2 change is not statistically significant Under Model Summary, row 2 (Model 2), under R2 (.003, p = .235) The R2 of .204 for Model 2 indicates that mom's age accounts for the additional .003 variation in kid's score after accounting for the variance explained by mom's IQ. This change is however not statistically significant (p = .235). In other words, mom's age did not significantly improve the model.
In order to ensure Model Parsimony, mom's age can be dropped from the model (i.e., maintain Model 1) REGRESSION /DESCRIPTIVES CORR SIG N /STATISTICS COEFF OUTS CI (95) R ANOVA CHANGE /DEPENDENT kid_score /method=ENTER iq_c /method=ENTER mom_age. Multicollinearity can be checked using
Variance Inflation Factor (VIF) Using variance proportion and condition index Mostly reported in articles Smaller VIF values indicate no meaningful collinearity (< 4 or < 10 if being conservative) VIF = 1/tolerance 1 / .884 = 1.131 in the example below
Our model can be said to be free from multicollinearity since the VIF value for all Independent Variable s are below cutoff value of 4.

Condition Index A way to summarize the size of each eigenvalues relative to largest eigenvalue
If condition index is greater than 30 AND more than one Predictor loads (or correlates) (> .4) on a single variance proportion, these together signal a potential multicollinearity problem. When assessing multicollinearity with the collinearity diagnostics, report on both the variance proportions and the condition indexes.
